Rapidly increasing cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the European Union/European Economic Area and the United Kingdom, 1 January to 15 March 2020

Motango ya bato oyo bazobela maladi ya coronavirisi (COVID-19) ezokoma mingi noki na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni, banda mokolo ya 1 sanza ya yambo kino mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato 2020

The cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases is showing similar trends in European Union/European Economic Area countries and the United Kingdom confirming that, while at a different stage depending on the country, the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in all countries.

Soki totali bato nyonso oyo bazobela maladi ya coronavirisi (COVID-19) bazomonisa bilembo ya ndenge moko na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni, yango ezondimisa ete, ata eza na banivo ekeseni na kotalela mokili mokomoko, maladi ya COVID-19 ezopanzana noki na mikili nyonso.

Based on the experience from Italy, countries, hospitals and intensive care units should increase their preparedness for a surge of patients with COVID-19 who will require healthcare, and in particular intensive care.

Na kotalela makambo oyo esalemi na Italie, mikili, balopitalo mpe bisika ya soins intensifs basengeli mpenza kobongama mpo na koyamba bato mingi ya maladi ya COVID-19 oyo ekosenga ete basalisa bango, mingimingi na soins intensifs.
On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown aetiology was reported in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
Na mokolo ya 31 sanza ya zomi na mibale 2019, bakangaki bato mingi na maladi ya mpema oyo eyebani te na mboka Wuhan, na etuka ya Hubei, na Chine.

On 9 January 2020, the China Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported the causative agent as being a novel coronavirus now referred to as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

Na mokolo ya 9 sanza ya yambo 2020, Centre ya Chine oyo ebundisaka mpe ebatelaka maladi elobaki ete maladi yango eutaki na lolenge ya sika ya coronavirisi oyo babengi sikoyo maladi ya makasi ya mpema coronavirisi 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Since, the illness resulting from SARS-CoV-2 infection has been named coronavirus disease (COVID-19).
Banda wana, bazobenga maladi oyo eutaka na SARS-CoV-2 ete maladi ya coronavirisi (COVID-19).
Evidence to date is that ca 80% of individuals with COVID-19 have a mild disease, i.e. a respiratory tract infection with or without pneumonia, and most of these recover.
Bilembeteli tozali na yango lelo emonisi ete bato 80% oyo baza na COVID-19 baza na maladi ya mwa moke, ndakisa maladi ya mpema elongo to kozanga mpasi ya kopema, mpe mingi na bango bazobika.
In ca 14% cases, COVID-19 develops into a more severe disease requiring hospitalisation while the remaining 6% cases experience critical illness requiring intensive care.
Na bato 14%, COVID-19 ezouta na maladi makasi oyo ezosenga bakota lopitalo, ebongo bato 6% bazobela maladi makasi mpenza mpe ezosenga bazala na soins intensifs.
The mortality of patients hospitalised due to COVID-19 is ca 4%.
Motango ya bato bakoti lopitalo mpo na COVID-19 oyo bazokufa eza 4%.

In this study, we assess the trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 in each European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) country and the United Kingdom (UK) and compare them to that of Hubei Province, China.

Na bolukiluki oyo, tozotala ndenge makambo ezosalema na makambo nyonso ya COVID-19 na mokili mokomoko ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni (UK) mpe tozokokokanisa yango na oyo ya etuka ya Hubei, na Chine.
We also compare the current number of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK with that in Italy during 31 January–15 March 2020.

Tozokokanisa mpe motango ya sikoyo ya bato bazobela COVID-19 na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa pe na Royaume-Uni na oyo ya Italie banda na mokolo ya 31 sanza ya yambo kino na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato 2020.
COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK
Bato bazobela COVID-19 na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni
Subsequent to China, COVID-19 underwent further geographical spread and the dynamic of the COVID-19 pandemic in the rest of the world currently follows that of this country.
Ndenge esalemaki na Chine, COVID-19 epanzanaki na bamboka mosusu mpe maladi wana ya COVID-19 ezopanzana ndenge moko na mikili mosusu kaka ndenge esalemaki mboka wana.
On 11 March 2020, the Director General of the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic.
Na mokolo ya 11 sanza ya misato 2020, diretere ya organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) alobaki ete COVID-19 eza maladi mabe.
In the 5 March issue of Eurosurveillance 2020, Spiteri et al. reported on the first European confirmed COVID-19 cases according to the WHO case definition.
Na mokolo ya 5 sanza ya misato likambo ya Eurosurveillance 2020, Spiteri mpe baninga na ye, elobelaki bato ya Eropa ya liboso oyo babeli COVID-19 na kotalela ndimbola oyo OMS ezopesa.
In the EU/EEA, the first three confirmed cases were reported by France on 24 January 2020 in persons returning from Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.

Na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa, bato misato ya liboso oyo bazwaki maladi elobamaki na France na mokolo ya 24 sanza ya yambo 2020; eza bato oyo bautaki na Wuhan, na etuka ya Hubei, na Chine mpe bazongaki na France.

As at 15 March 2020, COVID-19 cases had been detected in all 30 EU/EEA countries and the United Kingdom (UK), whereby between 31 December 2019 and that date included, 39,768 cases and 1,727 deaths had been reported, with 17,750 cases and 1,441 deaths from Italy alone.

Na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato 2020, bato bazalaki kobela maladi ya COVID-19 na mikili nyonso 30 ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni (UK), mpe banda mokolo ya 31 sanza ya zomi na mibale 2019 mpe kotanga dati wana, bato 39 768 babeli yango mpe bato 1 727 bakufaki na maladi wana mpe na Italie mpamba bato 17 750 bazwaki yango kasi bato 1 441 bakufaki.
Obtaining cumulative number and cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases
Kozwa motango nyonso mpe bato nyonso oyo bazwi COVID-19

At the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the notified COVID-19 case counts in each country worldwide, obtained from only official sources such as the countries’ Ministry of Health, national and regional health authorities and the WHO, are updated each day at 8:00 a.m.

Na centre ya Eropa oyo ebundisaka mpe ebatelaka maladi (ECDC), motango ya bato ya COVID-19 na mokili mokomoko, oyo bazwaka kaka na ba source officiel na ndakisa ministere ya santé ya mikili nyonso, bakonzi ya santé ya mokili mpe ya etuka mpe na OMS, etyamaka ya sika mokolo nyonso na 8H00 na ntongo.
These data were used for assessing the trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA and the UK, and comparing them to that in Italy.
Basalelaki bansango wana mpo na koyeba ndenge COVID-19 ezopanzana na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni, mpe bakokanisaka yango na ya Italie.

As a proxy of the prevalence of active COVID-19 cases, we calculated the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases, thus taking into account the natural course of COVID-19, in each EU/EEA country and the UK, during the 1 January–15 March 2020 period.

Na oyo etali ndenge bato oyo baza mpenza na maladi ya COVID-19, totalelaka mikolo 14 oyo yango ekomaka makasi mpo na bato ya COVID-19, yango wana totalelaka ndenge COVID-19 ekolaka, na mokili mokomoko ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni, na eleko ebandi na 1 sanza ya liboso kino 15 sanza ya misato 2020.
We also presented the cumulative number of notified cases of each country as at 15 March 2020 8:00 a.m. compared with that of Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.

Topesaki mpe motango nyonso ya bato ya maladi na mokili mokomoko na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato 2020 na 8H00 na ntongo, tokokanisaki yango na motango ya Italie banda na mokolo ya 31 sanza ya yambo kino na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato 2020.
Trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA countries and the UK
Ndenge bato bazobela COVID-19 na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni
The trends in the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK generally followed that of Hubei Province (China) (Figure 1).
Ndenge bato bazokolisa maladi COVID-19 na mikolo 14 na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni ezolanda ndenge esalemaki na etuka ya Hubei (Chine) (Motango1).
For the EU/EEA and the UK overall, the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 started to increase around 21 February and then increased sharply around 28 February 2020 (Supplementary material).

Mpo na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe Royaume-Uni, maladi ya COVID-19 ebandaki kokoma mingi pene ya mokolo ya 21 sanza ya mibale mpe na nsima ekomaki mwa mingi pene ya mokolo ya 28 sanza ya mibale 2020 (Bansango mosusu).

This was mostly driven by the rapid increase in the number of reported cases from Italy, but all other EU/EEA countries and the UK showed similar increasing trends of the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 (Supplementary material).

Esimbamaki mingi na motango ya bato mingi oyo bazalaki kozwa maladi yango na Italie, kasi na mikili nyonso ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa motango ya bato ya maladi COVID-19 ezalaki mpe komata ndenge moko (Bansango mosusu).
Figure 2 shows the cumulative number of COVID-19 cases, in EU/EEA countries and the UK compared with that in Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.

Motango 2 ezomonisa motango nyonso ya bato bazobela COVID-19, na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni soki tokokanisi yango na oyo ya Italie banda na mokolo ya 31 sanza ya yambo kino na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato 2020.
It highlights that, as at 15 March 8:00 a.m., 15 other EU/EEA countries and the UK had already reported a total number of cases comparable to that of Italy just 3 weeks prior or less.

Ezomonisa ete, na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya misato na 8H00 na ntongo, mikili 15 mosusu ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni ezalaki na motango ya bato ya maladi wana ndenge moko na Italie kaka mwa bamposo 3 to moke liboso.
Our results indicate that the number of notified cases of COVID-19 is rapidly increasing in the EU/EEA and the UK.
Ba résultat na biso ezolakisa ete motango bato oyo bazwi COVID-19 ezomata makasi na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni.
The observed trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 suggest that the pandemic is progressing at a comparable speed in all countries.
Makambo tomoni na bato nyonso bazobela COVID-19 ezolakisa ete maladi mabe ezopanzana ndenge moko na mikili misusu.

This is despite countries being at different stages, variations in national public health responses, and possibly different case definitions in countries and different protocols for selecting patients that must be tested for confirmation of COVID-19, including catch-up testing.

Eza bongo ata mikili eza na banivo ekeseni, bato oyo basalaka mosala ya monganga bazosunga bato ndenge moko te, mpe mbala mosusu kolimbola maladi na ndenge mosusu na mikili mpe mibeko ekeseni mpo na kopona bato ya maladi oyo basengeli kosalisa ekzame mpo na koyeba soki baza na COVID-19, ata mpe kosala ekzame na nsima.

Early March 2020, doctors in the affected regions of Italy described a situation in which ca 10% of patients with COVID-19 required intensive care and media sources reported that hospitals and intensive care units in these regions had already reached their maximum capacity.

Na ebandeli ya sanza ya misato 2020, minganga ya Italie bisika maladi ezalaki, balobaki ete bato ya maladi 10% oyo baza na COVID-19 baza na mposa ya soins intensifs mpe bapanzi-nsango balobaki ete soins intensifs ya balopitalo ya bituka wana etondaki koleka ndelo.
Data on admission of COVID-19 cases in a hospital and/or an intensive care unit are currently available at EU/EEA level for only 6% and 1% cases, respectively (data not shown).
Bansango ya bato ya COVID-19 oyo bakotaki lopitalo mpe/to na soins intensifs eza sikoyo na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpo na bato 6% mpamba mpe 1%, (bansango elakisami te).
They should, however, be collected in a systematic fashion to complement current surveillance data that focus on the number of reported cases and the number of deaths.
Kasi, basengeli kosangisa yango malamumalamu mpo na kobakisa yango na bansango ya sika oyo ezolobeli mingi motango ya bato oyo baza na maladi mpe motango ya baoyo bakufi.

A study performed in 2010–11 showed a large variation in the availability of intensive care and intermediate care beds in Europe, ranging from 29.2 in Germany to 4.2 beds per 100,000 population in Portugal.
Bolukiluki moko oyo esalemaki na 2010–11 emonisaki mbongwana monene na soins intensifs mpe ya bambeto ya katikati na Eropa, ezalaki 29,2 na Allemagne mpe bambeto 4,2 mpo na bato 100 000 na Portugal.
This means that countries may have more or less resources than Italy (12.5 intensive care and intermediate care beds per 100,000 population in 2010–11).
Elimboli ete mikili ekoki kozala na makoki mingi to moke koleka Italie (12,5 soins intensif mpe bambeto ya katikati mpo na bato 100 000 na 2010–11).

Modelling scenarios related to healthcare capacity saturation, with estimates for each EU/EEA country and the UK of the prevalence of hospitalised COVID-19 cases associated with a > 90% risk of exceeding intensive care bed capacity, are provided in the sixth update of the ECDC rapid risk assessment on COVID-19.

Kobongisa makambo ya kosalisa bato ya maladi elekeli minganga, mpo motango ya pene mpo na mokili nyonso ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe Royaume-Uni na kotalela bato bakoti lopitalo mpo na COVID-19 mpe mpo na a > 90% ya likama ya kozanga bambeto na soins intensif, epesami na makambo ya sika ya motoba ya ECDC mpo na botaleli ya lombango ya likama ya COVID-19.

Since cases have so far clustered in certain regions in EU/EEA countries and the UK, and hospitals and intensive care units usually serve a defined regional catchment population, information about cases and intensive care beds should preferably be made available at the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics 2 (NUTS-2) level.

Mpo bato ya maladi bakomi mingi na bisika mosusu na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni, mpe balopitalo na bisika ya soins intensifs esalelamaka mbala mingi mpo na kobomba bato ya etuka moko boye, bansango etali bamaladi mpe bambeto ya soins intensifs esengeli ezala libre na eteni ebengami Nomenclature ya biteni ya nivo ya bansango 2 (NUTS-2).
The experience from Italy and the current trends in other countries show that the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in the EU/EEA and the UK.
Makambo esalemi na Italie mpe oyo ezosalema sikoyo na mikili mosusu emonisi ete maladi mabe ya COVID-19 ezopanzana noki na mikili ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa mpe na Royaume-Uni.

Countries, hospitals and intensive care units should thus prepare themselves for a scenario of sustained community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an increase in the number of patients with COVID-19 requiring healthcare, and in particular intensive care, such as the one occurring in the affected regions of Italy.

Mikili, balopitalo mpe bisika ya soins intensifs esengeli komibongisa na ndenge ya bakosala makambo soki bato mingi bazwi SARS-CoV-2 mpe soki motango ya bato oyo bazwi COVID-19 oyo bazoluka lisalisi ekomi mingi, mpe mingimingi na soins intensif, na ndakisa oyo ezosalema na bamboka ya Italie esika maladi wana ezali.

As pointed out in the recent ECDC rapid risk assessment, a rapid, proactive and comprehensive approach is essential to delay the spread of SARS-COV-2, with a shift from a containment to a mitigation approach, as the anticipated rapid increase in the number of cases may not provide decision makers and hospitals enough time to comprehend, accept and adapt their response accordingly if not implemented ahead of time.

Ndenge bamonisaki yango na botaleli ya lombango ya likama oyo esalemaki kala te na ECDC, metode ya noki, ya malamu mpe ebongi mpenza eza ntina mpo na kokanga SARS-COV-2 nzela epanzana te, kolongola likebi na bato oyo bazozwa maladi mpe kotya yango na kokitsa ntalo ya contamintaion; mpo koluka koyeba liboso ndenge bato mingi bakobela ekosalisa mpenza te bato bazwaka bikateli mpe balopitalo bakozala te na ntango ya kokanga ntina na yango, kondima yango mpe kobongama na kosunga soki bameki yango te liboso.
The rapid risk assessment also lists the public health measures to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.
Botaleli ya lombango ya likama ezolobela mpe bibongiseli ya sante ya bato mingi mpo na kolembisa bokoli ya maladi mabe.

There is a short window of opportunity during which countries have the possibility to further increase their control efforts to slow down the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and decrease the pressure on healthcare.
Eza na mwa libaku moke na ntango oyo mikili ezali na libaku ya kobakisa controle ya milende bazosala mpo na kosala ete SARS-CoV-2 epanzana mingi te mpe kokotisa pression na minganga.
Failing this, it is likely that the healthcare systems of other EU/EEA countries will face a surge of patients that require intensive care within the coming days or weeks.

Soki basali yango te, bibongiseli ya sante ya mikili mosusu ya Eropa/Esika ya Nkita ya Eropa ekozala na bato mingi lisusu oyo bakobela mpe ekosenga batya bango na soins intensifs na mikolo to na bamposo ezoya.

The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has thus far killed over 3,000 people and infected over 80,000 in China and elsewhere in the world, resulting in catastrophe for humans.

Kobima ya maladi ya coronavirisi 2019 (COVID-19), oyo euti na maladi makasi ya mpéma (SARS) coronavirirsi 2 (SARS-CoV-2), esi ebomi bato koleka 3 000 mpe ezwi bato koleka 80 000 na Chine mpe na bisika mosusu na mokili mobimba, yango esali ete ekoma likama monene mpo na bato.

Similar to its homologous virus, SARS-CoV, which caused SARS in thousands of people in 2003, SARS-CoV-2 might also be transmitted from the bats and causes similar symptoms through a similar mechanism.

Na boyokani na ndeko na yango virisi, SARS-CoV, oyo esalaki bankoto ya bato babela SARS na 2003, ekoki kozala ete SARS-CoV-2 eutaki mpe na bangembo mpe eza na bilembo ya ndenge moko mpe ekotaka na ndenge moko.
However, COVID-19 has lower severity and mortality than SARS but is much more transmissive and affects more elderly individuals than youth and more men than women.
Atako bongo, COVID-19 eza makasi mingi te mpe ezoboma bato mingi te lokola SARS kasi ezopanzana na bato mingi mpe ezonyokola mingi mibange koleka bilenge mpe ezozwa mingi mibali koleka basi.
In response to the rapidly increasing number of publications on the emerging disease, this article attempts to provide a timely and comprehensive review of the swiftly developing research subject.
Ndenge mikanda oyo ezolobela maladi yango ezokoba kokoma mingi, mokano ya lisolo oyo eza ya kopesa bansango eyei na ntango malamu mpe na kolobela misala ya bolukiluki oyo ezosalema na likambo oyo.
We will cover the basics about the epidemiology, etiology, virology, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of the disease.
Tokolobela makambo ya ntina na oyo etali epidemiologie, etiologie, virologie, ndenge ya koyeba yango, ndenge ya kobikisa, pronostique, mpe libateli na maladi yango.
Although many questions still require answers, we hope that this review helps in the understanding and eradication of the threatening disease.
Ata soki mituna mingi eza nanu te na biyano, tokanisi ete lisolo oyo ekosalisa yo na koyeba mpe kosilisa maladi oyo ya mabe.

The Spring Festival on January 25, 2020 has become an unprecedented and unforgettable memory to all Chinese who were urged to stay indoors for all the holiday and for many weeks after due to the outbreak of a novel viral disease.

Fete ya printemps ya mokolo ya 25 sanza ya yambo 2020 ekomi oyo ekokani na moko te mpe oyo bato nyonso ya Chine bakobosana te, mpo bayebisaki bango babima libanda te na fete mobimba mpe na eleko ya bamposo mingi nsima mpo na kobima ya maladi moko ya sika ya makasi.

The virus is highly homologous to the coronavirus (CoV) that caused an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003; thus, it was named SARS-CoV-2 by the World Health Organization (WHO) on February 11, 2020, and the associated disease was named CoV Disease-19 (COVID-19).

Virisi yango ekokani mingi na coronavirisi (CoV) oyo ezalaki maladi ya makasi ya mpema (SARS) na 2003; ebongo babengaki yango SARS-CoV-2 na organisation mondiale de la sante (OMS) na mokolo ya 11 sanza ya mibale 2020, mpe maladi oyo yango ebimisi babengi yango CoV Maladi-19 (COVID-19).
The epidemic started in Wuhan, China, and quickly spread throughout the entire country and to near 50 others all over the world.
Maladi yango mabe ebandaki na mboka Wuhan, na Chine, mpe epanzanaki noki na Chine mobimba mpe na pene ya mikili 50 na mokili mobimba.
As of March 2, 2020, the virus has resulted in over 80,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19, with more than 40,000 patients discharged and over 3,000 patients who died.
Na mokolo ya 2 sanza ya misato 2020, virisi wana esalaki ete bato koleka 80 000 babela COVID-19, ebongo bato koleka 40 000 babikaki mpe babimiaki na lopitalo kasi bato koleka 3 000 bakufaki.
WHO warns that COVID-19 is “public enemy number 1” and potentially more powerful than terrorism.
OMS akebisi ete COVID-19 eza “monguna ya nimero 1 ya bato” mpe ekoki kozala makasi koleka terorizme.

According to PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), in less than two months, over 200 papers have been published on COVID-19 including its virology, epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and treatment since the first report on January 7, 2020 that determined the sequence of the virus isolated from multiple patients.

Na kotalela PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), na nse ya sanza mibale, bato basi babimisaki masolo koleka 200 oyo ezolobela COVID-19 ata mpe virologie, epidemiologie, etiologie, ndenge ya koyeba yango, mpe ndenge ya kosalisa yango, banda basalaki rapore ya liboso na mokolo ya 7 sanza ya yambo 2020 oyo ezolimbola ndenge virisi ezopanzana na bato mingi.
This review attempts to summarize the research progress in the new and swiftly developing subject area.
Lisolo oyo ezomeka kolobela na mokuse bolukiluki oyo ezosalema na likambo oyo ya sika oyo ezopanzana noki.
Whenever possible, we will try to compare COVID-19 with SARS and another CoV-caused disease, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS, an outbreak in 2012).
Soki likoki ezali, tokomeka kokokanisa COVID-19 na SARS mpe maladi mosusu oyo eutaki na CoV, maladi ya mpema ya moyen-orient (MERS, oyo ebimaki na 2012).
We will also discuss what we have learned so far regarding the prevention and prognosis of the disease as well as some remaining yet urgent questions.
Tokolobela mpe makambo oyo tosi toyekoli na oyo etali kobundisa mpe pronostique ya maladi wana mpe mituna mosusu ya ntina mingi.
CoVs have been traditionally considered nonlethal pathogens to humans, mainly causing approximately 15% of common colds 4.
Bato balobaka ete CoVs eza mpenza te maladi oyo ebomaka bato, mingimingi esalaka ete bato 15% bayoka malili 4.

However, in this century, we have encountered highly pathogenic human CoVs twice, i.e., SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, which caused an outbreak originally in China in 2003 and Saudi Arabia in 2012, respectively, and soon spread to many other countries with horrible morbidity and mortality.

Kasi, na siekle oyo, tosi tokutani na bavirisi CoVs oyo ebelisaka bato mbala mibale, na ndakisa, SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV, oyo ebimisaki maladi oyo eutaki na Chine na 2003 mpe na Arabie Saudite na 2012, mpe epanzanaki noki na mikili mosusu mpe ezalaki kozwa bato mingi mpe koboma bato ebele mpenza.
Therefore, the current COVID-19 is the third CoV outbreak in the recorded history of humans.
Yango wana, COVID-19 ya sikoyo eza CoV ya misato oyo ebima na lisolo ya bomoi ya bato.
As shown in Fig. ​Fig.1,1, clusters of pneumonia that had unknown origins were first reported from Wuhan on December 31, 2019 to the China National Health Commission.

Ndenge bamonisi yango na motango. ​Motango 1,1, liboke ya maladi ya mpema oyo esika euta eyebani te elobelamaki na mbala ya liboso na Wuhan na mokolo ya 31 sanza ya mibale 2019 na lisanga ya Chine oyo etalaka makambo ya kolongono ya nzoto.
Seven days later the sequence of the CoV was released.
Mikolo nsambo na nsima babimisaki ndenge CoV ebandaka.
On January 15, 2020 the first fatal case from Wuhan was reported.
Na mokolo ya 15 sanza ya yambo 2020 moto ya liboso akufaki na Wuhan.
Meanwhile, the epidemic rapidly spread to the neighboring cities, provinces, and countries.
Na ntango wana, maladi yango ezalaki kopanzana noki na bingumba, na bituka mpe na mikili ya pene.
On January 20, the infection of health-care providers was reported, suggesting that human-to-human transmission was possible.
Na mokolo ya 20, balobaki ete minganga bazwi maladi yango, yango emonisaki ete moto akoki kopesa yango na moto mosusu.
On January 23, the city of Wuhan was locked down with all its public transportation stopped.
Na mokolo ya 23 sanza ya yambo, bakangaki engumba Wuhan mpe transpore ya bato nyonso ezalaki kosala lisusu te.

On January 24 the first clinical study on the disease reported that, out of 41 patients with confirmed cases, only 21 had direct contact with the Wuhan seafood market that was considered the starting site of the infection from an unknown animal source.

Na mokolo ya 24 sanza ya yambo, babandaki kosala bolukiluki ya maladi wana, na kati ya bato 41 oyo bazalaki kobela yango, bato 21 mpamba bakomaki na zando ya mbisi ya mbu ya Wuhan esika oyo maladi yango ebandaki na nyama moko oyo eyebani te.
On January 30, WHO declared the outbreak a global health emergency.
Na mokolo ya 30 sanza ya yambo, OMS elobaki ete maladi wana eza likama mpo na mokili mobimba.
By the time of this report, the disease has already spread throughout China and near 50 other countries all over the world (Fig. ​(Fig.2).2).
Na ntango tozosala rapore oyo, maladi yango esi epanzani na Chine mobimba mpe na mikili misusu pene ya 50 na mokili mobimba (Motango. ​(Motango.2).2).
As the situation is rapidly evolving, the final scope and severity of the outbreak remain to be determined.
Ndenge makambo ezondongwana noki, bonene na yango ya nsuka mpe makasi na yango eyebani nanu te.

On February 11, 2020, a multi-center study on 8,866 patients including 4,021 confirmed COVID-19 patients presented a more updated illustration of the epidemic as follows (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).

Na mokolo ya 11 sanza ya mibale 2020, bolukiluki na bato ya maladi 8 866 tanga mpe bato 4 021 oyo bazalaki mpenza na COVID-19 emonisaki makambo ya sika na ntina na maladi mabe ndenge eza na nse (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).
SARS-CoV-2 infected people of all ages, but mainly at the age of 30-65.
SARS-CoV-2 ezozwa bato ya mbula nyonso, kasi mingimingi bato ya mbula 30-65.
Almost half (47.7%) of the infected individuals were over 50 years old, very few were under 20, and only 14 infected individuals were under the age of 10.
Pene ya katikati (47,7%) ya bato oyo babelaki baza na mbula koleka 50, moke mpenza baza na mbula na nse ya 20, mpe bato 14 mpamba ya maladi bazalaki na mbula na nse ya 10.
SARS-CoV-2 infected more men (0.31/100,000) than women (0.27/100,000).
SARS-CoV-2 ezwaki mingi mibali (0,31/100 000) koleka basi(0,27/100 000).
COVID-19 expanded in clusters mainly in and around Hubei.
COVID-19 epanzanaki na bituluku mingimingi na Hubei mpe pene na yango.
COVID-19 took an average of 5 (2-9) days from onset to diagnosis.
COVID-19 ezwaki na mwayene mikolo 5 (2-9) banda ebandeli kino mokolo bamonaki yango.
The average incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days.
Mwayene ya mikolo oyo maladi esalaka liboso emonana eza mikolo 4,8 (3,0-7,2).
The average time from onset to death was 9.5 (4.8-13) days.
Mwayene ya mikolo banda ebandeli na yango kino liwa eza mikolo 9,5 (4,8-13).
The basic reproductive number (R0) was 3.77 (95% CI: 3.51-4.05), and the adjusted R0 was 2.23-4.82.
Motango ya kobotisa yango (R0) eza 3,77 (95% CI: 3,51-4,05), mpe kobongwana ya R0 ezalaki 2,23-4,82.
The number of infected people increased exponentially before 23 Jan. 2020, matching the time of massive transportation before the Spring Festival in China.
Motango ya bato oyo bazwi maladi emataki mingi liboso ya mokolo ya 23 ya sanza ya yambo 2020; yango ekokani na ntango oyo bato basalelaki transpore mingi na fete ya printemps na Chine.
The mortality of patients with confirmed cases was 1.44% (95% CI: 1.10-1.86%), and the adjusted mortality of all the patients was 3.06% (95% CI: 2.02-4.59%).
Bato ya maladi oyo kokufa ezalaki 1,44% (95% CI: 1,10-1,86%), mpe kobongwana ya motango ya bato bakufaki eza 3,06% (95% CI: 2,02-4,59%).
Three major risk factors for COVID-19 were sex (male), age (≥60), and severe pneumonia.
Makambo misato ya minene ya likama ya COVID-19 ezalaki sexe (mobali), mbula (≥60), mpe mpema makasi.
CoVs are a subfamily of large and enveloped viruses containing a single strand of sense RNA.
CoVs eza na kati ya libota monene ya bvirisi mpe na kati ya bavirisi oyo eza na mwa boyokani na RNA.
They can be divided into four genera, i.e., alpha, beta, gamma, and delta, of which alpha- and beta-CoVs are known to infect humans.
Tokoki kokabola yango na biteni minei, na ndakisa., alpha, beta, gamma, mpe delta, ebongo alpha- na beta-CoVs eyebani ete ezwaka bato.

The envelope spike (S) glycoprotein binds to its cellular receptors angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) and dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, respectively, and then membrane fusion occurs.

Nsonge ya (S) glycoproteine ekangamaka na ba recepteur na yango ya angiotensine mpe ebongalaka enzyme 2 (ACE2) mpe dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) mpo na SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV, mpe na nsima membrane esanganaka.

The viral RNA genome is released into the cytoplasm; after replication of the viral genome, genomic RNA accompanied by envelope glycoproteins and nucleocapsid proteins forms virion-containing vesicles, which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release the virus.

Virisi RNA ebimaka na cytoplasme; nsima ya kopanzana ya virisi wana, virisi RNA eyaka na kati ya anvelope ya glycoproteine mpe baproteine nucleocapside esalaka vesicule oyo eza na virion, oyo esanganaka na plazma mpo na kobimisa virisi.
The first genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 was reported on January 10, 2020.
Genome ya liboso ya SARS-CoV-2 emonanaki na mokolo ya 10 sanza ya yambo 2020.

SARS-CoV-2 was found to be a new type of beta-CoV with more than 99.98% genetic identity among 10 sequenced samples collected from the original site of the outbreak, the Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan.

Bamonaki ete SARS-CoV-2 ezalaki lolenge ya sika ya beta-CoV oyo ezalaki na na identité 99,98% ya makila na kati ya bandakisa 10 oyo bazwaki na esika oyo yango ebimaki na mbala ya liboso, na zando Huanan ya koteka banyama ya mbu na Wuhan.
SARS-CoV-2 is genetically more similar to SARS-CoV than to MERS-CoV.
SARS-CoV-2 ekokani mpenza na SARS-CoV kasi na MERS-CoV te.
Through transmission electron microscopy, SARS-CoV-2 particles were found in ultrathin sections of human airway epithelium.
Na nzela ya kopanzana ya electron ya mikroskope, biteni ya SARS-CoV-2 emonanaka na nzoto ya bato na nzela ya kopema.
Human ACE2 was found to be a receptor for SARS-CoV-2 as well as SARS-CoV.
Bamonaki ete ACE2 ya bato ezalaki eloko ezwaka SARS-CoV-2 mpe SARS-CoV.
However, the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds to human ACE2 more weakly than that of SARS-CoV, which is coincident with the fact that SARS-CoV-2 causes less severe infection in patients than SARS-CoV.
Kasi, proteine S ya SARS-CoV-2 ekangami makasi te na ACE2 ya bato koleka ya SARS-CoV, oyo eyokani na likambo oyo ete SARS-CoV-2 ezopesa bato maladi ya makasi te lokola SARS-CoV.
SARS-CoV-2 can also form a novel short protein encoded by orf3b and a secreted protein encoded by orf8.
SARS-CoV-2 ekoki mpe kosala proteine ya moke ya sika oyo euti na orf3b mpe ebimisaka proteine euti na orf8.
The orf3b of SARS-CoV-2 may play a role in the viral pathogenicity and inhibit the expression of IFNβ; however, orf8 does not contain any known functional domain or motif.
Lolenge orf3b ya SARS-CoV-2 ekoki kozala na mokumba makasi na kobima ya virisi wana mpe komonisa bilembo ya IFNβ; kasi, orf8 ezalaka te na mosala to motif oyo eyebana.
On February 18, 2020, Zhou, et al., reported the cryo-EM structure of the full-length human ACE2 at 2.9 Å resolution in complex with the amino acid transporter B0AT1.
Na mokolo ya 18 sanza ya mibale 2020, Zhou, mpe baninga, elobelaki nzoto ya cryo-EM ya ACE2 ya bato ya molai mpenza na 2,9 Å ya mindondo ezalaki na eloko ememaka aside amino B0AT1.

They found that the complex, which had open and closed conformations, was assembled as a dimer and the ACE2-B0AT1 complex can bind two S proteins, which provides evidence for CoV recognition and infection.

Bamonaki ete mindondo wana, oyo ezalaki kofungwama mpe kokangama, esangisamaki esika moko mpe ACE2-B0AT1 ya mindondo ekoki kosangisa baproteine S mibale, oyo ezopesa bilembeteli ya koyeba CoV mpe maladi wana.
B0AT1 may become a therapeutic target for drug screening to suppress SARS-CoV-2 infection.
B0AT1 ekoki kokoma eloko ya kosalela bankisi mpo na kosilisa maladi ya SARS-CoV-2.
The origin and intermediate host
Esika eutaka mpe esika ya mibale oyo efandaka
It has been known that both SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV originated from bats and were transmitted to humans via civet cats and camels, respectively.
Eyebani ete SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV eutaki na bangembo mpe epesamaki na bato na nzela ya banyau civet mpe bakamela.

Through a phylogenetic comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with other CoVs, bats were considered the native host of SARS-CoV-2 as the new virus is 96% identical to two SARS-like CoVs from bats called bat-SL-CoVZX45 and bat-SL-CoVZX21.

Soki tosali bokokanisi na kati ya SARS-CoV-2 na ba CoVs mosusu, bangembo nde bato bazalaki na SARS-CoV-2 mpo virisi oyo ya sika ekokani na 96% na bavirisi CoVs oyo ekokokani na ba SARS mibale oyo eutaki na bangembo oyo babengaka bat-SL-CoVZX45 mpe bat-SL-CoVZX21.
However, what intermediate host helped the virus cross the species barrier to infect humans remains unknown, and the transmission route is yet to be elucidated.
Kasi, eloko oyo esalisaki virisi na kolongwa na banyama mpo eya kokota na bato eyebani nanu te, mpe toyebi nanu te ekotaki na nzela nini.
Ji, et al., proposed snakes as a carrier of the virus from bats to humans which involved homologous recombination within the S protein.
Ji, mpe baninga na ye, balobaki ete banyoka nde ememaki virisi wana uta na bangembo mpe ekotisaki yango na bato; mpe esanganaki na kati ya proteine S.

According to a study, researchers in Guangzhou, China, suggested that pangolins - long-snouted, ant-eating mammals often used in traditional Chinese medicine - are the potential intermediate host of SARS-CoV-2 based on 99% genetic homology in a CoV discovered in pangolins and SARS-CoV-2.

Na kotalela bolukiluki moko, balukiluki esalemaki na Guangzhou, na Chine, balobaki ete bapangolin - oyo ezali banyama ebengami mamifere oyo basalelaka mbala mingi lokola bankisi ya bokoko na Chine - eza oyo mbala mosusu esika ya mibale oyo SARS-CoV-2 efandaka na kotalela 99% ya makila ya ndenge moko na CoV oyo bamonaki na bapangolin mpe na SARS-CoV-2.
However, 1% difference spread all over two genomes is still a big difference; thus, conclusive results for concrete evidence are awaited (Fig. ​(Fig.33).
Kasi, bokeseni ya 1% etaleli bavirisi mibale eza kaka bokeseni monene; yango wana, tozokoba kozela bosukisi ya solosolo (Mot. ​(Mot.33).
The physicochemical properties of SARS-CoV-2 are largely not yet known.
Makambo ya physique mpe ya chimie ya SARS-CoV-2 eyebani nanu ata moke te.
SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV can survive in vitro for 48 hours in a dry environment and up to 5 days under 20 °C and 40%-50% humidity.
SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV ekoki kozala na bomoi na libanda ya esika oyo bazalaka na bomoi na bangonga 48 na esika ya kokauka mpe kino na mikolo 5 na nse ya 20 °C mpe na 40%-50% na esika ya malili.
SARS-CoV-2 may possess similar properties.
SARS-CoV-2 ekoki kozala na bizaleli ya ndenge moko.

It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 is sensitive to ultraviolet rays and heat at 56 °C for 30 minutes; ether, 75% ethanol, chlorine-containing disinfectant, peracetic acid, chloroform, and other fatty solvents, but not chlorhexidine, can effectively inactivate the virus.

Bato bazoloba ete SARS-CoV-2 ekokaka te na ba rayons ultraviolet mpe moto na badegre 56 °C na miniti 30; to, 75% ya ethanole, desinfectant oyo eza na chlore, aside perasetique, chloroforme, mpe bankisi mosusu ya koboma mikrobe, kasi te chlorhexidine, ekoki mpenza koboma virisi wana.
The entire human population generally lacks immunity to SARS-CoV-2 and hence is susceptible to the novel virus.
Bato nyonso bazangi mikrobe oyo ebundisaka SARS-CoV-2, yango wana virisi oyo ya sika ekoki kozwa bango.
Currently, no detailed study has been reported regarding the immunological response to SARS-CoV-2.
Sikoyo, basali nanu te bolukiluki ya mozindo na oyo etali ndenge ya kobundisa SARS-CoV-2.
Thus, we can only refer to previous studies on other CoVs, especially SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV (Fig. ​(Fig.4).4).
Yango wana, tokoki kolobela kaka bolukiluki ya kala na oyo etali ba CoVs mosusu, mingimingi SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV (Mot. ​(Mot.4).4).

In general, after a virus invades the host, it is first recognized by the host innate immune system through pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) including C-type lectin-like receptors, Toll-like receptor (TLR), NOD-like receptor (NLR), and RIG-I-like receptor (RLR).

Mbala mingi, soki virisi ekoteli eloko moko, mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi mabe eyebaka yango na nzela ya mayele ya koyeba biloko mosusu (PRRs) tanga mpe lolenge na yango C ya biloko oyo ememaka yango, biloko ememaka yango oyo eza neti Toll(TLR), mpe oyo eza neti NOD (NLR), mpe oyo eza neti RIG-I (RLR).

Through different pathways, the virus induces the expression of inflammatory factors, maturation of dendritic cells, and synthesis of type I interferons (IFNs) which limit the spreading of the virus and accelerate macrophage phagocytosis of viral antigens.

Na lisalisi ya banzela ekeseni, virisi ebimisaka mpasi na nzoto, ekolisaka baselile dentritique, mpe esangisaka na mokuse ba interferon oyo eza neti I (IFNs) oyo ekangaka virisi nzela mpo epanzana te mpe esalaka ete biloko oyo ekangaka virisi nzela ebima noki.
However, the N protein of SARS-CoV can help the virus escape from the immune responses.
Kasi, proteine N ya SARS-CoV ekoki kosalisa virisi na kokima bopusi ya mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi.
Soon, the adaptive immune response joins the fight against the virus.
Kala mingi te, mikrobe oyo ebundisaka virisi esanganaka mpo na kobundisa yango.
T lymphocytes including CD4+ and CD8+ T cells play an important role in the defense.
Balymfosite T tanga mpe CD4+ mpe CD8+ baselile T esalaka mosala makasi na kobundisa maladi.
CD4+ T cells stimulate B cells to produce virus-specific antibodies, and CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected cells.
CD4+ baselile T elendisaka baselile B mpo na kobimisa mikrobe oyo ebundisaka virisi, mpe CD8+ baselile T ebomaka mbala moko baselile oyo virisi ekoteli yango.
T helper cells produce proinflammatory cytokines to help the defending cells.
Baselile ya kosalisa T ebimisaka ba cytokine oyo ebimisaka mokusa mpo na kosalisa baselile oyo ebundaka.
However, CoV can inhibit T cell functions by inducing apoptosis of T cells.
Kasi, CoV ekoki kopekisa selile T esala mosala na yango na modele ya kokufa baselile T.
The humoral immunity including complements such as C3a and C5a and antibodies is also essential in combating the viral infection.
Mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi oyo esanganaka ndakisa C3a mpe C5a mpe ba anti corps eza mpe ntina mpo na kobundisa virisi oyo.
For example, antibodies isolated from a recovered patient neutralized MERS-CoV.
Na ndakisa, ba anti corps oyo balongolaki na bato oyo babikaki ebomaki MERS-CoV.

On the other hand, an overreaction of the immune system generates a large number of free radicals locally that can cause severe damages to the lungs and other organs, and, in the worst scenario, multi-organ failure and even death.

Kasi, reaction ya koleka ndelo ya mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi ekoki kobimisa ba radicale mingi koleka na nzoto mpe yango ekoki kobebisa bapoumon mpe binama mosusu, mpe likambo ya mabe koleka, ekoki kosala ete binama mingi esala lisusu te mpe nkutu ekoki komema na liwa.
The SARS-CoV-2 infection, featured by clustering onset, is more likely to affect elderly people with comorbidities and pregnant women.
Maladi ya SARS-CoV-2 , oyo ekabwanaka na ebandeli, ezozwa mingi mibange oyo baza na maladi mosusu mpe basi ya zemi.
It is common that for people who are exposed to a large number of viruses or whose immune functions are compromised, they have higher chance to be infected than others.
Mbala mingi bato oyo bakutanaka na bavirisi mingi to oyo mikrobe na bango oyo ebundisaka maladi elemba, baza na likama mingi ya kozwa maladi oyo koleka bato mosusu.
The estimated mean incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 is 1-14 days, mostly 3-7 days based on a study of the first 425 cases in Wuhan.
Eleko oyo maladi ya SARS-CoV-2 esalaka mpo emonana eza mikolo 1-14, mingimingi mikolo 3-7 na kotalela bolukiluki esalemaki na bato 425 ya liboso oyo bazwaki yango na Wuhan.
However, a study on 1,099 cases demonstrates that the incubation period was 3 days on average and ranged from 0 to 24 days.
Kasi, bolukiluki oyo esalemaki na bato 1 099 emonisi ete eleko oyo maladi esalaka mpo emonana ezalaki mikolo 3 na mwayene mpe ebandaki na mikolo 0 kino na 24.
A more recent study, as described above, demonstrates that the incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days based on the demography of 8,866 cases.
Bolukiluki moko ya sika mpenza, ndenge balobeli yango na likolo, elakisi ete eleko oyo maladi esalaka mpo emonana ezalaki mikolo 4,8 (3,0-7,2) na kotalela bato 8 866 oyo balandelaki.

It is very important for health authorities to adjust the effective quarantine time based on the most accurate incubation period, thus preventing infected but symptomless people from transmitting the virus to others.

Eza na ntina mingi mpo na minganga na kobongola eleko ya kotya moto na quarantaine na kotalela eleko ya solo oyo maladi esalaka mpo emonana, ebongo ekokanga nzela mpo bato oyo baza na bilembo ya maladi bapesa bato mosusu virisi te.
As a common practice, individuals exposed to, or infected by, the virus are usually required to be quarantined for 14 days.
Ndenge esalemaka mbala mingi, mpo na bato oyo bakutanaki na bato ya maladi oyo to baza na maladi yango, virisi wana esengaka ete batya yango na quarantaine mikolo 14.
Should the quarantine time be extended to 24 days?
Esengeli nde mikolo ya quarantaine ekoma mikolo 24?

Fever is often the major and initial symptom of COVID-19, which can be accompanied by no symptom or other symptoms such as dry cough, shortness of breath, muscle ache, dizziness, headache, sore throat, rhinorrhea, chest pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

Fievre eza mbala mingi elembo ya ntina mingi mpe ya liboso ya COVID-19, oyo ekoki koya yango moko to na bilembo mosusu na ndakisa kosukosu ya makasi, kokatana ya mpema, mpasi na misisa, vertige, moto mpasi, mongongo mpasi, kokangama ya zolo, mpasi na ntolo, pulupulu, mposa ya kosanza, mpe kosanza.
Some patients experienced dyspnea and/or hypoxemia one week after the onset of the disease.
Bato mosusu ya maladi bapemaka na mpasi mpe/to bazangaka mpema mwa moke mposo moko na nsima ya ebandeli ya maladi.
In severe cases, patients quickly progressed to develop acute respiratory syndrome, septic shock, metabolic acidosis, and coagulopathy.
Na bandakisa ya makasi, bato ya maladi bakomaki noki na mpasi ya kopema, motema ebetaka malamu te, nzoto ebimisaka aside mingi, mpe makila ezokoka kokangama te.
Patients with fever and/or respiratory symptoms and acute fever, even without pulmonary imaging abnormalities, should be screened for the virus for early diagnosis.
Bato oyo baza na fievre mpe/to mpasi ya kopema mpe fievre ya makasi, ata soki bakanisi ete baza na mpasi na poumon, basengeli kosala bango ekzame mpo na koyeba soki baza na maladi wana.

A demographic study in late December of 2019 showed that the percentages of the symptoms were 98% for fever, 76% for dry cough, 55% for dyspnea, and 3% for diarrhea; 8% of the patients required ventilation support.

Bolukiluki na mwa ndambo ya bato oyo esalemaki na nsuka ya sanza ya zomi na mibale 2019 emonisaki ete bilembo ya maladi ezalaki 98% mpo na fievre, 76% mpo na kosukosu, 55% mpo na vertige, mpe 3% mpo na pulupulu; 8% ya bato bazalaki na mposa ya lisalisi ya mopepe.
Similar findings were reported in two recent studies of a family cluster and a cluster caused by transmission from an asymptomatic individual.
Bazwaki makambo ya ndenge moko na bolukiluki mibale ya sika oyo basalaki na biloko oyo ebimisaka maladi mpe oyo epanzaka yango na bato oyo baza na yango te.
Comparably, a demographic study in 2012 showed that MERS-CoV patients also had fever (98%), dry cough (47%), and dyspnea (55%) as their main symptoms.
Kasi, bolukilluki oyo esalemaki na 2012 emonisaki ete bato oyo bazobela MERS-CoV mpe mingi bazalaki na fievre (98%), kosukosu ya makasi (47%), mpe mpema mokuse (55%) na kati ya bilembo ya minene.
However, 80% of them required ventilation support, much more than COVID-19 patients and consistent with the higher lethality of MERS than of COVID-19.
Kasi, 80% na bango bazalaki na mposa ya lisalisi ya mopepe, mingi koleka bato oyo bazobela COVID-19 mpe ezoboma bato ndeko moko na MERS kasi lokola COVID-19.
Diarrhea (26%) and sore throat (21%) were also observed with MERS patients.
Pulupulu (26%) mpe mongongo mpasi (21%) emonanaki mpe na bato oyo bazalaki kobela MERS.

In SARS patients, it has been demonstrated that fever (99%-100%), dry cough (29%-75%), dyspnea (40%-42%), diarrhea (20-25%), and sore throat (13-25%) were the major symptoms and ventilation support was required for approximately 14%-20% of the patients.

Na bato oyo bazalaki kobela SARS, emonanaki ete fievre (99%-100%), kosukosu ya makasi (29%-75%), vertige (40%-42%), pulupulu (20-25%), mpe mongongo mpasi (13-25%) ezalaki bilembo ya minene mpe bato pene ya 14%-20% bazalaki na mposa ya lisalisi ya mopepe.
By February 14, the mortality of COVID-19 was 2% when the confirmed cases reached 66,576 globally.
Na mokolo ya 14 sanza ya mibale, bato bakufaki na COVID-19 bazalaki 2% ntango motango ya bato ekomaki 66 576 na mokili mobimba.
Comparably, the mortality of SARS by November 2002 was 10% of 8,096 confirmed cases.
Soki tosali bokokanisi, bato oyo bakufaki na SARS na sanza ya zomi na moko 2002 bazalaki 10% na kati ya bato 8 096 oyo babelaki yango.
For MERS, based on a demographic study in June 2012, the mortality was 37% of 2,494 confirmed cases.
Mpo na MERS, na kotalela bolukiluki na motango ya bato oyo esalemaki na sanza ya motoba 2012, bato oyo bakufaki bazalaki 37% na kati ya bato 2 494 oyo babelaki yango.
An earlier study reported that the R0 of SARS-CoV-2 was as high as 6.47 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 5.71-7.23, whereas the R0 of SARS-CoV only ranged from 2 to 4.
Bolukiluki ya liboso emonisaki ete R0 ya SARS-CoV-2 ezalaki 6,47 mpe 95% interval ya confiance (CI) ya 5,71-7,23, kasi R0 ya SARS-CoV ezalaki kaka banda 2 kino 4.
A comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with MERS-CoV and SARA-CoV regarding their symptoms, mortality, and R0 is presented in Table ​Table1.1.
Kokokanisa SARS-CoV-2 na MERS-CoV mpe SARA-CoV na oyo etali bilembo, motango ya bakufi, mpe R0 emonisami na Tablo​Tablo 1.1.
The above figures suggest that SARS-CoV-2 has a higher ability to spread than MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, but it is less lethal than the latter two.
Mitango oyo eza likolo emonisi ete SARS-CoV-2 eza na makoki mingi ya kopanzana koleka MERS-CoV mpe SARS-CoV, kasi ezoboma bato moke koleka mibale oyo ya nsuka.
Thus, it is much more challenging to control the epidemic of SARS-CoV-2 than those of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV.
Yango wana, eza mpasi mingi na kobundisa maladi mabe ya SARS-CoV-2 koleka oyo ya MERS-CoV mpe SARS-CoV.
Clustered onset often happens in the same family or from the same gathering or vehicle such as a cruise ship.
Mbala mingi maboke ebimaka na libota moko to na esika moko to eyaki neti masuwa.
Patients often have a history of travel or residence in Wuhan or other affected areas or contact with infected individuals or patients in the recent two weeks before the onset.
Mbala mingi bato ya maladi eza bato oyo basalaki mobembo na to bafandaka kuna to bisika mosusu oyo maladi yango ekotaki to bazwaki yango na bato na bamposo mibale liboso ete ebanda.

However, it has been reported that people can carry the virus without symptoms longer than two weeks and cured patients discharged from hospitals can carry the virus again, which sends out an alarm to increase the time for quarantine.

Kasi, emonani ete bato bakoki komema virisi wana kozanga kozala na bilembo na eleko eleki mposo mibale mpe bato oyo babikaki oyo babimaki na lopitalo bakoki kozala lisusu na virisi wana, yango wana esengeli kobakisa mikolo ya quarantaine.
Patients have normal or reduced number of peripheral white blood cells (especially lymphocytes) at the early stage.
Bato ya maladi oyo baza na motango ya baselile ya mpembe ya makila ya normal to moke (mingimingi balymphocyte) na ebandeli mpenza ya maladi.
For example, lymphopenia with white blood cell count < 4×109/L including lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, and elevated aspartate aminotransferase levels and viremia were found in 1,099 COVID-19 patients.

Ndakisa, lymphopenia na selile ya mpembe ya makila count < 4×109/L elongo na lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, mpe motango mingi ya aspartate aminotransferase mpe viremia emonanaki na bato ya maladi 1 099 ya COVID-19.
The levels of liver and muscle enzymes and myoglobin were increased in the blood of some patients, and C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation were increased in the blood of most patients.
Nivo ya foie mpe ya misisa ya ba-enzyme mpe myoglobine ezalaki komata na makila ya bato mosusu ya maladi, mpe baproteine C na erythrocyte emataki na makila ya bato mingi ya maladi.
In patients with severe cases, the level of D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product present in the blood, was elevated, and lymphocyte count was progressively reduced.
Na bato oyo bazalaki kobela makasi, nivo ya dimer D, kolemba ya mosisa moko oyo ezalaka na makila, emataka, mpe lymphocyte ebandaki kokita malembemalembe.
Abnormalities in chest radiography are found in most COVID-19 patients and featured by bilateral patchy shadows or ground glass opacity in the lungs.
Bampasi na ntolo emonanaki na bato mingi oyo babelaki COVID-19 mpe emonisaki bisika ya molili ya ndenge moko te to bisika ya molili na bapoumon.
Patients often develop an atypical pneumonia, acute lung injury, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
Mbala mingi bato ya maladi bazalaki na maladi ya mpema, kozoka makasi na poumon, mpe mpasi makasi ya kopema (ARDS).
When ARDS happens, uncontrolled inflammation, fluid accumulation, and progressive fibrosis severely compromise the gas exchange.
Soki ARDS esalemi, mpasi ya makasi, komata ya mai, mpe kobeba ya fibrose esalaka ete mopepe eleka na mpasi.
Dysfunction of type-I and type-II pneumocytes decreases the surfactant level and increases surface tension, thus reducing the ability of the lungs to expand and heightening the risk of lung collapse.

Kosala malamu te ya lolenge I mpe II ya pneumocytes ekitisaka nivo ya surfactant mpe ematisaka esika ya mpasi, yango wana ekitisaka makoki ya bapoumon ya kofungwama mpe esalaka ete likama ya kopanza poumon ekoma mingi.
Therefore, the worst chest radiographic findings often parallel the most severe extent of the disease.
Yango wana, maladi makasi ya bapoumon oyo bazwaki ezalaki mbala mingi na boyokani na mpasi makasi ya maladi wana.

On February 18, 2020, the first pathological analysis of COVID-19 demonstrated the desquamation of pneumocytes, hyaline membrane formation, and interstitial lymphocyte infiltration, and multinucleated syncytial cells in the lungs of a patient who died of the disease, consistent with the pathology of viral infection and ARDS and similar to that of SARS and MERS patients.

Na mokolo ya 18 sanza ya mibale 2020, analyse ya liboso ya COVID-19 emonisaki kobeba ya ba pneumocyte, biteni ya hyaline, mpe kotoboka ya kati ya lymphocyte, mpe mwa bambuma na selile na bapoumon ya bato oyo bakufaki na maladi yango; eyokani na pathologie ya virisi yango mpe ARDS mpe ekokani na oyo ya bato oyo babelaki SARS mpe MERS.
The detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used as the major criteria for the diagnosis of COVID-19.
Koyeba SARS-CoV-2 RNA na nzela ya makambo oyo esalemaka mpe ememaka na (RT-PCR) esalelamaki neti elembo ya ntina mingi mpo na koyeba COVID-19.

However, due to the high false-negative rate, which may accelerate the epidemic, clinical manifestations started to be used for diagnosis (which no longer solely relied on RT-PCR) in China on February 13, 2020.

Kasi, mpo na nivo ya makasi ya makambo ya lokuta, oyo ekoki kosala ete maladi mabe ekoma makasi mingi, babandaki kosalela bilembo ya maladi mpo na koyeba yango (bazalaki kosuka kaka te na RT-PCR) na Chine na mokolo ya 13 sanza ya mibale 2020.
A similar situation also occurred with the diagnosis of SARS.
Likambo ya ndenge moko esalemaki mpo na koyeba SARS.
Therefore, a combination of disease history, clinical manifestations, laboratory tests, and radiological findings is essential and imperative for making an effective diagnosis.
Yango wana, kosangisa masolo ya maladi oyo, ndenge ebimaki, baekzame ya laboratoire, mpe makambo bamonaki na radiographie eza ntina mingi mpe ekosalisa mpo na koyeba makasi diagnostique.

On February 14, 2020, the Feng Zhang group described a protocol of using the CRISPR-based SHERLOCK technique to detect SARS-CoV-2, which detects synthetic SARS-CoV-2 RNA fragments at 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (10-100 copies per microliter of input) using a dipstick in less than an hour without requiring elaborate instrumentation.

Na mokolo ya 14 sanza ya mibale 2020, lisanga Feng Zhang balimbolaki mayele moko na kosalelaka mayele esimbami na CRISPR SHERLOCK mayele ya koyeba SARS-CoV-2, mpo na koyeba SARS-CoV-2 RNA na 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (motango 10-100 na microlitre moko) basalelaki jauge na nse ya ngonga moko kozanga basala makambo ya mindondomindondo.
Hopefully, the new technique can dramatically enhance the sensitivity and convenience if verified in clinical samples.
Tozolikya ete, mayele oyo ya sika ekoki kobongola makasi sensibilite mpe lolenge malamu ya kosalela yango, soki endimami nsima ya kotalela yango.

Due to the lack of experience with the novel CoV, physicians can mainly provide supportive care to COVID-19 patients, while attempting a variety of therapies that have been used or proposed before for the treatment of other CoVs such as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV and other viral diseases (Table ​(Table2).2).

Mpo bayebi malamu te CoV ya sika, minganga bakoki kaka kosalisa mwa moke bato oyo bazobela COVID-19, ntango bazozela bankisi mingi oyo basi basalela to oyo bazalaki kokanisa liboso kosalela mpo na kobikisa bato ya CoVs mosusu na ndakisa SARS-CoV mpe MERS-CoV mpe maladi euti na virisi (Tablo ​(Tablo2).2).
These therapies include current and potential treatments with antiviral drugs, immunosuppressants, steroids, plasma from recovered patients, Chinese medicine, and psychological support.

Bankisi yango eza bankisi ya sika mpe oyo bakoki kosalela oyo eza na nkisi ya bambuma, immunosuppresseurs, basteroide, plazma euti na bato ya maladi, nkisi ya bokoko ya Chine, mpe lisalisi ya minganga.
Even plasma from recovered patients was proposed to be used for treatment.
Balobaki bakoki kosalela ata plazma oyo euti na moto ya maladi lokola nkisi.
Pharmaceutical companies are racing to develop antibodies and vaccines against the virus.
Bakompani oyo esalaka bankisi bazosala makasi mpo na kosala bankisi mpe mangwele ya virisi oyo.
SARS-CoV-2 mainly attacks the lungs in the beginning and probably also attacks, to a lesser degree, other organs that express ACE2, such as the gastrointestinal system and the kidneys.
SARS-CoV-2 ebundisaka mingimingi bapoumon na ebandeli mpe mbala mosusu ebundisaka mwa moke binama mosusu ya nzoto oyo ezalaka na ACE2, na ndakisa estoma na misopo mpe bangeyi.
Nevertheless, respiratory dysfunction and failure are the major threat to the patients and the major cause of death.
Atako bongo, mpasi ya kopema mpe kobungisa makanisi eza makama minene mpo na bato mingi ya maladi mpe yango nde ezoboma mingi.

Thus, respiratory support is critical to relieve the symptoms and save lives and includes general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, and invasive mechanical ventilation depending on the severity of the disease.

Yango wana, kosalisa na kopema eza ntina mingi mpo na kolembisa bilembo ya maladi mpe kobikisa bato mpe yango etaleli kopesa oxygene lokola nkisi, kopesa oxygene mingi, kokotisa mopepe kozanga kokotisa eloko na nzoto ya moto, mpe kokotisa na nzoto eloko ezokotisa mopepe na kotalela makasi ya maladi.

Patients with severe respiratory symptoms have to be supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), a modified cardiopulmonary bypass technique used for the treatment of life-threatening cardiac or respiratory failure.

Bato ya maladi oyo baza na mpasi ya makasi ya kopema, basalisaki bango na eleko moko oyo ekotisaka oxygene (ECMO), mayele moko ya sika ya kokotisa eloko na motema oyo basalelaki mpo na kobikisa maladi makasi ya motema to bato oyo mpema ekatanaki.

In addition, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, the prevention and treatment of secondary infection and septic shock, and the protection of the functions of the vital organs are also essential for SARS-CoV-2 patients.
Lisusu, kobatela equilibre ya electrolyte, kobundisa mpe kobikisa maladi ya mibale mpe maladi makasi, mpe kobatela binama ya bomoi eza ntina mingi mpo na bato oyo bazobela SARS-CoV-2.
It has been known that a cytokine storm results from an overreaction of the immune system in SARS and MERS patients.
Eyebani ete komata ya cytokine na reaction ya koleka ndelo ya mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi ya bato oyo bazobela SARS mpe MERS.
Cytokine storm is a form of systemic inflammatory response featured by the release of a series of cytokines including TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, and MCP-1.
Cytokine eza lolenge moko ya mpasi oyo ebimaka na ba cytokine mingi na ndakisa TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, mpe MCP-1.
These cytokines induce immune cells to release a vast number of free radicals which are the major cause of ARDS and multiple organ failure.
Ba cytokine epusaka baselile oyo ebundisaka maladi na kobimisa ba radicale mingi oyo ekeseni oyo ebimisaka mbala mingi ARDS mpe kobebisa binama.
Immunosuppression is essential in the treatment of cytokine storms, especially in severe patients.
Immunosuppresseur eza ntina mingi mpo na kobikisa cytokine, mingimingi na bato oyo bazobela makasi.
Corticosteroids and tocilizumab, an anti-IL6 monoclonal antibody, have been used to treat cytokine storm.
Corticosteroide mpe tocilizumabe, IL6 moko oyo ebundisaka maladi, basalelaki yango mpo na kobikisa cytokine.

Other immunosuppression treatments for cytokine storm include the modulation of T cell-directed immune response; the blockade of IFN-γ, IL-1, and TNF; JAK inhibition; blinatumomab; suppressor of cytokine signaling 4; and HDAC inhibitors.

Bankisi mosusu ya immunosuppresseur mpo na cytokine ezali kosalela selile T oyo eza na boyokani na mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi; blockade ya IFN-γ, IL-1, mpe TNF; JAK inhibation; blinatumomabe; suppresseur ya cytokine oyo ezolakisa 4; mpe HDAC ba inhibateur.
Steroids, as immunosuppressants, were widely used in the treatment of SARS to reduce the severity of inflammatory damage.
Ba steroide, lokola ba immunosuppresseur, basalelaki yango mingi lokola nkisi ya SARS mpo na kokitisa mpasi oyo esalemi.
However, steroids at high dosages were not beneficial to severe lung injury in SARS and COVID-19 patients.
Kasi, basteroide oyo ezalaka na doze mingi ezalaki ntina te mpo na mpota ya poumon na bato oyo babelaki SARS mpe COVID-19.
Instead, they may cause severe side effects, especially avascular osteonecrosis, dramatically affecting the prognosis.
Kasi, ekoki komema bampasi mosusu, mingimingi na baselile ya makila, mpe ebebisaki mingi pronostique.
Nevertheless, short courses of corticosteroids at low-to-moderate doses have been recommended to be used prudently for critically ill COVID-19 patients.
Atako bongo, badoze ya moke ya corticosteroide, basengaki kopesa yango na mayele mpo na bato ya maladi ya COVID-19 oyo bazalaki kobela makasi.
At the time of writing, no effective antiviral therapy has been confirmed.
Na ntango tozokoma, eza nanu te na nkisi oyo eyebani mpo na virisi oyo.
However, intravenous administration with remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, has been found to be efficacious in an American patient with COVID-19.
Kasi, kopesa na misisa remdesivir, analogue ya nucleotide, emonanaki ete ezosalisa mingi bato ya Amerika oyo bazobela COVID-19.
Remdesivir is a novel antiviral drug developed by Gilead initially for the treatment of diseases caused by Ebola and Marlburg viruses.
Remdesivir eza nkisi ya kobundisa virisi oyo esalemaki na ebandeli na Gileadi mpo na kosalisaka bato oyo bazalaki kobela Ebola mpe Marlburg.
Later, remdesivir also demonstrated possible inhibition of other single stranded RNA viruses including MERS and SARS viruses.
Na nsima, remdesivir mpe emonisaki ete ekoki kosalisa mpo na bavirisi mosusu ya RNA ata mpe virisi MERS na SARS.
Based on these, Gilead has provided the compound to China to conduct a pair of trials on SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals, and the results are highly anticipated.
Na kotalela makambo wana, Gilead epesi biloko wana na Chine mpo na komeka yango na bato oyo bazobela SARS-CoV-2, mpe bato bazozela mpenza resultat na yango.
In addition, baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ribavirin have been suggested as potential therapies for patients with acute respiratory symptoms.
Lisusu, bato balobaki ete baricitinbe, interferone-α, lopinavire/ritonavire, mpe ribavirin, ekoki kosalisa bato oyo baza na mpasi makasi ya kopema.
Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, liver damage, and other adverse reactions can occur following combined therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir.
Pulupulu, mposa ya kosanza, kosanza, kobeba ya foie, mpe ba reaction mosusu ya mabe ekoki komonana soki basangisi nkisi wana na lopinavire/ritonavire.
The interaction of these treatments with other drugs used in the patients should be monitored carefully.
Kosangisa bankisi oyo na bankisi mosusu oyo basalelaki mpo na bato mosusu ya maladi, esengeli kokengela yango malamu mpenza.
Plasma from recovered patients and antibody generation
Plazma ya bato oyo babikaki mpe biloko ebundisaka maladi

The collection of the blood from patients who recovered from a contagious disease to treat other patients suffering from the same disease or to protect healthy individuals from catching the disease has a long history.
Kosangisa makila ya bato oyo babikaki na maladi mabe mpo na kosalisa bato mosusu oyo bazobela maladi wana moko to mpo na kobatela bato oyo baza nzoto kolongono mpo bazwa te maladi wana ebanda kala.
Indeed, recovered patients often have a relatively high level of antibodies against the pathogen in their blood.
Ya solo, mbala mingi bato oyo babika baza na ba-anti corps ya makasi mpo na kobundisa mikrobe na makila na bango.
Antibodies are an immunoglobulin (Ig) produced by B lymphocytes to fight pathogens and other foreign objects and they recognize unique molecules in the pathogens and neutralize them directly.
Ba anticorps eza immunoglobuline (Ig) oyo euti na ba lymphocytes B mpo na kobundisa mikrobe mpe biloko mosusu ya mabe mpe eyebaka bamolekile oyo eza na mikrobe mpe na nsima koboma yango.
Based on this, plasma was collected from the blood of a group of patients who recovered from COVID-19 and was injected into 10 seriously ill patients.
Na kotalela makambo oyo, bazwaka mbala mingi plazma na makila ya bato oyo babelaki kasi babika na COVID-19 mpe botiubaki yango na bato 10 oyo bazalaki kobela makasi.
Their symptoms improved within 24 hours, accompanied by reduced inflammation and viral loads and improved oxygen saturation in the blood.
Bayokaki malamu nsima ya bangonga 24; mpasi na virisi ekitaki mpe esalaki ete oxygene ekita te na makila.
However, verification and clarification are necessary to propose the method for large-scale use before specific therapies are not yet developed.
Kasi, verification mpe clarification eza ntina mingi mpo na topesa likanisi ya kosalela metode wana mpo na kosalela yango liboso babimisa nkisi ya solo.
In addition, given the therapeutic effects, some disadvantages associated with the plasma should be considered carefully.
Lisusu, mpo na mabe oyo nkisi ememaka, esengeli kotalela malamumalamu makama mosusu ya plazma.
For example, antibodies can overstimulate the immune response and cause cytokine release syndrome, which is potentially a life-threatening toxicity.
Na ndakisa, anticorps ekoki kolendisa mikrobe oyo ebundisaka maladi mpe ekoki kosala ete cytokine ebima; oyo eza mabe mingi mpo na bomoi.
The concentration of antibodies in the blood is usually low, and the demand for the plasma is large to treat critically ill patients.
Kosangisa ba anticorps na makila ezalaka mbala mingi na nse, mpe bosengi ya plazma eza mingi mpo na kosalisa bato bazobela.
It is difficult to develop and produce specific antibodies rapidly enough to fight against a global epidemic.
Eza mpasi na kosala mpe kobimisa ba anticorps ya sikisiki mpo na kobundisa maladi mabe ya monene.

Thus, it is more critical and practical to isolate B cells from recovered patients and identify the genetic codes encoding effective antibodies or screen for effective antibodies against essential proteins of the virus.

Yango wana, eza ntina mingi mpe ebongi na kokabola baselile B ya bato oyo babiki mpe koyeba bokasi ya ba anticorps wana to komema yango mpo na koyeba soki ba anticorps wana ekoki kobundisa baproteine ya virisi.
This way, we can readily scale up the production of the antibodies.
Na ndenge wana, tokokoka nde kosala noki ba anticorps.
TCM has been used to treat a variety of diseases in China for thousands of years.
Babanda kosalela TCM mpo na kosalisa maladi mingi na Chine banda bambula mingi.
However, its effects largely rely on a combination of multiple components in a formula that varies depending on the diagnosis of a disease based on the theories of TCM.
Kasi, makama na yango eutaka na ndenge basangisaka biloko mingi na ndenge ekeseni na kotalela lolenge maladi ezali na kolandaka makanisi ya TCM.
Most of the effective components remain unknown or are vague as it is difficult to extract and verify such components or their optimal combinations.
Biloko mingi oyo esalisaka eyebani nanu te to eyebani bongobongo mpo eza mpasi na kobimisa mpe ko verifier biloko yango mpe ndenge malamu ya kosangisa yango.

Currently, due to the lack of effective and specific therapy for COVID-19, TCM has become one of the major alternative treatments for patients with light to moderate symptoms or for those who have recovered from severe stages.
Sikoyo, mpo tozangi nkisi ya makasi mpe ya sikisiki mpo na COVID-19, TCM ekomi moko ya bankisi mpo na bato oyo baza na bilembo ya mike to ya pete to baoyo babiki na maladi makasi.
For example, Shu Feng Jie Du capsules and Lian Hua Qing Wen capsules were found to be effective for COVID-19 treatment.
Na ndakisa, bato bamonaki ete nkisi ya capsule Shu Feng Jie Du mpe Lian Hua Qing Wen ezosalisa mingi na kobikisa bokono ya COVID-19.

Top cure rates in the treatment of COVID-19 patients were observed in several provinces in China that used TCM in 87% of their patients, including Gansu (63.7%), Ningxia (50%), and Hunan (50%), whereas Hubei province, which used TCM in only approximately 30% of its COVID-19 patients, had the lowest cure rate (13%).

Bato mingi oyo babikaki na kozwaka nkisi ya COVID-19, emonanaki na bituka mingi ya Chine oyo basalelaka TCM na bato ya maladi 87%, na ndakisa Gansu (63,7%), Ningxia (50%), mpe Hunan (50%), kasi na etuka ya Hubei, oyo esalelaki TCM kaka na bato pene ya 30% oyo bazalaki kobela COVID-19, bato moko nde babikaki (13%).
However, this is quite a rough comparison as many other impact factors such as the number and severity of the patients should be included in the evaluation.
Kasi, bokokanisi oyo eza mpasi mpo makambo mosusu na ndakisa motango ya bato ya maladi mpe makasi ya maladi esengeli kotalelama mpe ntango ya botaleli wana.
On February 18, 2020, Boli Zhang and coworkers published a study to compare western medicine (WM) treatment alone with combined treatment of WM and TCM.
Na mokolo ya 18 sanza ya mibale 2020, Boli Zhang mpe baninga na ye babimisaki bolukiluki moko mpo na kokokanisa kimonganga ya eropa (WM) yango moko na nkisi ya WM mpe TCM.
They found that the times needed for body temperature recovery, symptom disappearance, and hospitalization were remarkably shorter in the WM+TCM group than in the WM only group.
Bamonaki ete ntango oyo baza na yango mposa mpo chaleur ekita na nzoto, mpo bilembo esila, mpe na lopitalo ezalaki moke na etuluku WM+TCM koleka na etuluku WM mpamba.

Most impressively, the rate for symptomatic worsening (from light to severe) was remarkably lower for the WM+TCM group than for the WM only group (7.4% versus 46.2%) and the mortality was lower in the WM+TCM group than WM only group (8.8% versus 39%).

Eloko ezokamwisa mingi eza ete ndenge bilembo ezokoma makasi (banda na moke kino na makasi) ezalaki na nse mingi mpo na etuluku WM+TCM koleka na etuluku WM mpamba (7,4% kontre 46,2%) mpe bato oyo bakufaki bazalaki moke na etuluku WM+TCM koleka na etuluku WM mpamba (8,8% kontre 39%).
Nevertheless, the efficacy and safety of TCM still await more well-controlled trials at larger scales and in more centers.
Atako bongo, bokasi mpe bolamu ya TCM ezozela kaka endimisama nsima ya komeka yango na bato mingi mpe na bisika mingi.
It would also be intriguing to characterize the mechanism of actions and clarify the effective components of TCM treatments or their combinations if possible.
Ezobenda mpe likebi na koyeba ndenge makambo esalemaka mpe kolimbola makasi ya biloko oyo eza na bankisi ya TCM to ndenge basangisaka yango soki likoki ezali.
Patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 mostly experience great fear of the highly contagious and even fatal disease, and quarantined people also experience boredom, loneliness, and anger.

Bato oyo bakanisi bakoki kozala na COVID-19 to oyo baza na yango, mbala mingi babangaka mingi maladi oyo ebomaka, mpe bato oyo batye na quarantaine bamitungisaka mingi, bamiyokaka bango moko mpe bazalaka na nkanda.

Furthermore, symptoms of the infection such as fever, hypoxia, and cough as well as adverse effects of the treatments such as insomnia caused by corticosteroids can lead to more anxiety and mental distress.

Lisusu, bilembo ya kozwa maladi na ndakisa fievre, kozanga oxygene, mpe kosukosu mpe bampasi mosusu eutaka na nkisi na ndakisa kozanga mpongi oyo corticoseroide ebimisaka ekoki komema basusi mingi mpe kotungisama na makanisi.

In the early phase of the SARS outbreak, a range of psychiatric morbidities including persistent depression, anxiety, panic attacks, psychomotor excitement, psychotic symptoms, delirium, and even suicidality were reported.

Na ebandeli ntango SARS ebimaki, balobaki ete bato yango bamonisaki bizaleli mingi na ndakisa kotungisama mingi na makanisi, basusi, kosutuka, kosala makambo bisalasala, kobosana makambo, kobungisa makanisi, mpe nkutu koluka komiboma.

Mandatory contact tracing and quarantine, as a part of the public health responses to the COVID-19 outbreak, can make people more anxious and guilty about the effects of the contagion, quarantine, and stigma on their families and friends.

Koluka bato oyo moto azobela akutanaki na bango mpe kotya bato na quarantaine mpo na kobatela bango na COVID-19, ekoki kosala ete bato bamitungisa mingi mpe bazala na ngambo mpo bapesi bato mosusu maladi, kozala na quarantaine, mpe mpasi bamemi na mabota mpe baninga.
Thus, mental health care should be provided to COVID-19 patients, suspected individuals, and people in contact with them as well as the general public who are in need.
Yango wana, basengeli kopesa lisalisi ya maladi ya moto na bato oyo baza na COVID-19, baoyo bakanisi bakoki kozala na yango, mpe na bato nyonso oyo baza na mposa na yango.

The psychological support should include the establishment of multidisciplinary mental health teams, clear communications with regular and accurate updates about the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak and treatment plans and the use of professional electronic devices and applications to avoid close contact with each other.

Lisalisi ya maladi ya moto esengeli kotalela kopona ekipi ya bato mingi oyo basalisaka bato ya maladi ya moto, kosolola mbala na mbala na polele nyonso mpe kopesa bansango ya sika ya solo mpo na kobima ya SARS-CoV-2 mpe bankisi bazokana kobimisa mpe kosalela ba-apareyi mpe baprograme mpo na koboya kozala pembeni na bato mosusu.

Effective vaccines are essential for interrupting the chain of transmission from animal reservoirs and infected humans to susceptible hosts and are often complementary to antiviral treatment in the control of epidemics caused by emerging viruses.

Mangwele ya solo eza na ntina mingi mpo na kosukisa kopanzana ya virisi na banyama mpe na bato oyo baza na yango mpe na biloko mosusu mpe mbala mingi eyokanaka na nkisi ya virisi mpo na kobundisa maladi makasi oyo euti na bavirisi ya sika.
Efforts have been made to develop S protein-based vaccines to generate long-term and potent neutralizing antibodies and/or protective immunity against SARS-CoV.
Milende ezosalema mpo na kobimisa mangwele uta na proteine S mpo na kobimisa ba anticorps ya ntango molai mpe oyo ekoki koboma mpe/to kobatela bato na SARS-CoV.
Live-attenuated vaccines have been evaluated in animal models for SARS.
Basi bameki mangwele oyo ezosalisa bomoi na bambisi mpo na SARS.

However, the in vivo efficacy of these vaccine candidates in elderly individuals and lethal-challenge models and their protection against zoonotic virus infection have yet to be determined before a clinical study is initiated.

Kasi, bokasi ya solo ya mangwele wana na mibange mpe na bato oyo baza na maladi makasi mpe libateli na bango na bavirisi euti na banyama eyebani nanu te liboso bolukiluki ya solo ebanda na nzoto ya bato.
This is probably because SARS died down 17 years ago and no new case has been reported since.
Eza mbala mosusu mpo SARS eisilaki mibu 17 ekoki mpe moto mosusu te abela maladi yango banda na ntango wana.
In contrast, sporadic cases and clusters of MERS continue to occur in the Middle East and spread to other regions owing to the persistence of zoonotic sources in endemic areas.
Na bokeseni, bato mokomoko mpe mwa bituluku ya bato bazokoba kozwa virisi MERS na moyen orient mpe ezopanzana na bisika mosusu mpo eutaka na banyama.

Vaccination strategies have been developed for MERS by using inactivated virus, DNA plasmids, viral vectors, nanoparticles, virus-like particles and recombinant protein subunits and some have been evaluated in animal models.

Basi basali mayele ya kotobola mangwele ya MERS na kobomaka virisi wana, DNA ya baselile, biloko oyo ememaka bavirisi, na biloko ya mike mpenza, biloko oyo eza neti virisi mpe biteni ya proteine ya virisi mpe bameka mosusu na banyama.
The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 for non-immune individuals is an urgent and critical task for controlling the ongoing epidemic.
Kosala mangwele ebongi mpe ya makasi mpo na kobundisa SARS-CoV-2 mpo na bato oyo baza na mangwele na yango te eza ntina mingi mpe mosala makasi mpo maladi mabe oyo ekende mosika te.
However, it is challenging to overcome the difficulty because of the long period of time (averaged 18 months) needed for vaccine development and the dynamic variations of CoVs.
Kasi, eza mpasi na kolonga mikakatano mpo esengaka ntango mingi (pene ya basanza 18 ) mpo na kosala mangwele mpe mpo lolenge mingi ya CoVs.
As a novel disease, COVID-19 has just started to manifest its full clinical course throughout thousands of patients.
Mpo eza maladi ya sika, COVID-19 ebandi kaka komonisa bokasi na yango na bato mwa mingi.
In most cases, patients can recover gradually without sequelae.
Na bandakisa mingi, bato oyo babeli yango bakoki kobika malembemalembe kozanga kotikala na bilembo na yango.
However, similar to SARS and MERS, COVID-19 is also associated with high morbidity and mortality in patients with severe cases.
Kasi, ndenge ezalaki mpo na SARS mpe MERS, COVID-19 ezobangisa bato oyo bazobela yango mpe ezoboma bato oyo bazobela yango makasi.
Therefore, building a prognosis model for the disease is essential for health-care agencies to prioritize their services, especially in resource-constrained areas.
Yango wana, kosala modele mpo na koyeba maladi oyo eza ntina mingi mpo na minganga mpo batya na esika ya liboso mosala na bango, mingimingi na bisika oyo makoki eza mingi te.
Based on clinical studies reported thus far, the following factors may affect or be associated with the prognosis of COVID-19 patients (Table ​(Table33):
Na kotalela bolukiluki oyo basi basali na nzoto ya bato, makambo oyo ekoki kozala na bopusi to na boyokani na ndenge ya koyebela bato oyo baza na COVID-19 (Tablo ​(Tablo33):
Age: Age was the most important factor for the prognosis of SARS, which is also true for COVID-19.
Mbula: Mbula eza likambo ya ntina mingi mpo na koyeba pronostique ya SARS, oyo eza mpe solo mpo na COVID-19.
COVID-19 mainly happened at the age of 30-65 with 47.7% of those patients being over 50 in a study of 8,866 cases as described above.
COVID-19 ebimaki mingimingi na bato ya mibu 30-65 mpo 47,7% ya bato oyo babelaka bazalaki na mibu koleka 50 na bolukiluki oyo basalaki na bato 8 866 ndenge balimboli yango likolo.

Patients who required intensive care were more likely to have underlying comorbidities and complications and were significantly older than those who did not (at the median age of 66 versus 51), suggesting age as a prognostic factor for the outcome of COVID-19 patients.

Bato ya maladi oyo baza na mposa ya soins intensifs bamonisaki bilembo mosusu ya mabe mpe mpasi mpe bazalaki mikolo mingi koleka baoyo bamonisaki yango te (soki tokokanisi mibu 66 mpe 51), emonisi ete mbula eza moko ya makambo oyo ekosalisa koyeba soki moto oyo azobela COVID-19 akobika to te.
Sex: SARS-CoV-2 has infected more men than women (0.31/100,000 versus 0.27/100,000), as described above.
Sexe: SARS-CoV-2 ezozwa mibali mingi koleka basi (0,31/100 000 kontre 0,27/100 000), ndenge balimboli likolo.
Comorbidities and complications: Patients with COVID-19 who require intensive care are more likely to suffer from acute cardiac injury and arrhythmia.
Bilembo mosusu mpe bampasi: Bato oyo bazobela COVID-19 oyo baza na mposa ya soins intensifs bakonyokwama mingi na mpasi ya mpema mpe motema ekobeta malamu te.
