Tokobimisa mayele moko mpo na kobimisa bansango ya mokili mpe tablo mpo na kozwa makanisi ya bato na oyo etali ndenge tozosalela bansango na bango mpe ndenge tozozwa bandakisa ya bavirisi mpe serologie.
This is based on coding described in Table 4.
Esalemi na kolanda bakode tolimboli na Tablo 4.
Definite case will be presented on our dashboard as “cases” of COVID-19.
Bato oyo bayebani ete baza na maladi, na tablo tokokoma “bato” ya COVID-19.
Possible cases will be presented as “Under investigation” (investigating).
Bato oyo bakoki kozala na yango, tokokoma “Tozolandela” (kolandela).
“Not a case” will be presented as “Excluded”.
Mpo na “eza yango te” tokoloba “Tolongoli”.

Online data has been established within the initial few weeks in the COVID-19 Observatory (Figure 5), indicating the overall number of patients and rate per 10,000 patients of cases confirmed or under investigation, as well as where the virus is excluded.

Totye bansango na internet na kolanda botaleli ya bamposo moke ya ebandeli ya COVID-19 Oyo tomoni (Motango 5), ezomonisa bato nyonso ya maladi mpe taux na kotalela bato ya maladi 10 000 oyo baza na yango to oyo tozolandela, ata mpe baoyo tolongola virisi na nzoto.
We have the option to move to twice weekly surveillance reports with a scope to change this to daily reporting.
Toza na likoki ya kokoma kosala rapore ya kokengela mbala mibale na mposo na likanisi oyo kobanda kosala yango mokolo na mokolo.
We will continue virology sampling from our sentinel practices, rather than discontinuing as seasonal influenza declines.
Tokokoba kotalela bandakisa ya bavirisi na kolanda mayele na biso ya kolandela, na esika ya kotika yango ntango grippe ebimaka mbala na mbala elembi.
Additionally, we will recruit more surveillance practices.
Lisusu, tokozwa na mosala bato mingi ya kokengela.
The RCGP RSC virology practices will aim to undertake 200-300 nasopharyngeal swabs per week across the RCGP RSC sentinel network, collecting specimens across all age bands.
Mosala ya RCGP RSC mpo na bavirisi eza na likanisi ya kozwa bilembo na zolo ya bato 200-300 mposo nyonso na nzela ya lisanga na biso ya RCGP RSC, tokozwa yango na bato ya mbula nyonso.

In addition to the inclusion criteria for influenza virology surveillance (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), participating practices will take nasopharyngeal swab samples from any people showing acute symptoms of LRTI if the onset of symptoms is within 7 days.

Longola kobakisa ba critere mpo na kokengela virisi ya grippe (ILI, bronchite/bronchiolite ya makasi), bato oyo bazosangana na bokengeli bakozwa bilembo na zolo na moto nyonso oyo aza na bilembo ya maladi makasi ya mpema LRTI soki eza na eleko ya mikolo 7 banda bilembo ebandaki komonana.
RCGP RSC research officers and practice liaison staff will manage practices to achieve a total national sample of 200-300 swabs per week.
Bakonzi ya bolukiluki ya RCGP RSC mpe bato basalisaka bango bakokamba bato oyo bazosangana mpo na kokokisa mokano ya bato 200-300 na mboka mobimba na mposo moko.
This could be increased if PHE modelers require more samples.
Ekoki kokoma mingi soki bakambi ya PHE basengi bandakisa mingi.
Samples from each practice would be spread across the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years and older
Ba echantilon euti na moto nyonso azosangana ekokabolama na bituluku ya bambula oyo: < mibu 5, mibu 5-17, mibu 18-64, mpe mibu 65 mpe koleka
Samples (swabs or serum) collected will be sent via prepaid envelopes addressed to the appropriate PHE laboratory for analysis.
Ba echantillon (ecouvillon to serum) oyo bazwi ekotindama na nzela ya ba-amvelope basi bafutela mbongo oyo ekokende na laboratoire PHE mpo na ekzame.
All samples collected will be tested for the presence of influenza and COVID-19.
Ba echantillon oyo bazwi, bakomeka yango mpo na koyeba soki eza na grippe to COVID-19.
Additionally, PHE will retrospectively test any influenza virology samples collected between early and mid-February 2020 for COVID-19.
Lisusu, PHE ekozongela baekzame ya ba echantillon nyonso oyo bazwaki mpo na grippe oyo bazwaki banda ebandeli mpe katikati ya sanza ya mibale 2020 mpo na COVID-19.

Practices will still follow the PHE protocol for COVID-19 with respect to people at risk of infection who should be signposted down the containment pathway, rather than physically attend their practice.

Bato bazosangana bakokoka kosalela malako oyo PHE ebimisa mpo na COVID-19 na oyo etali bato oyo baza na likama ya kozwa malamu oyo basengeli kotya bango bilembo mpo na kobatela bango, olie ya baya bango moko na ekzame.
Direct testing of those who attend surgery remains permitted, but we have also rolled out self-swabbing at home.
Ndingisa ezali ya kolanda kosala ekzame na bato oyo bayei mpo na lipaso, kasi topekisa kosala ekzame ya bilembo ya mongongo yo moko na ndako.
Summary of processes are detailed in Multimedia Appendix 3.
Bokuse ya bametode elimbolami na Appendice ya Multimedia 3.

Everyone with an ILI or a respiratory illness who contacts a GP (eg, phones for an appointment) should be asked specifically about recent travel to China and other countries flagged in current PHE advice, or if they have had contact with other people with COVID-19.

Moto nyonso oyo aza na ILI to maladi ya mpema oyo akutani na GP (na ndakisa, kozwa rendez-vous na telefone) bakotuna malamu soki asalaki kala te mobembo na Chine mpe na mikili mosusu oyo batye bilembo na toli ya sika ya PHE, to soki bakutanaki na bato mosusu oza baza na COVID-19.
If these screening enquiries are positive, the patient would be advised to not come to the practice but instead to follow the PHE flow sheet.
Soki ba ekzame oyo emonisi ete maladi eza, bakoyebisa moto wana aya te ye moko kasi asala makambo ndenge PHE alimboli yango.
This can be by a reception or clinician staff, depending on individual practice protocol.
Ekoki kozala na moto asalaka na reception moto ya lopitalo, na kotalela malako bapesa mpo na moto mokomoko.
These calls should be coded into the GP CMR system and can be reported as part of the RCGP RSC weekly return.
Basengeli kokotisa masolo wana na systeme ya GP CMR mpe bakoki kokotisa yango na rapore ya mposo na mposo ya RCGP RSC.
We have developed training material to support this coding (Multimedia Appendix 4).
Tobongisa mateya ya kopesa formation mpo na kosalela bakode wana (Appendice Multimedia 4).
These include prompt cards for:
Etali mpe bakarte ya kosenga kopesa biyano mpo na:
Practice reception or triage staff: for coding of any patients calling the practice with symptoms of acute respiratory infection with a history of travel to important areas based on PHE advice

Bato bayambaka bato to bato baponaka: mpo na bakode ya moto nyonso ya maladi oyo azobenga mpe aza na bilembo ya maladi makasi ya mpema, mpe eybani ete asalaka mobembo na bisika ya ntina na kotalela toli ya PHE
Administrative staff or clinicians who code: to encourage consistent coding of results for any suspected cases, including coding of negative results for exclusion
Bakonzi to minganga oyo bazotia kode: mpo na kolendisa na kosala bakode ya malamu ya ba resultat ya bato oyo bakoki kozala na maladi, ata mpe ya bato oyo baza na yango te mpo na kolongola yango
Practices participating in virology surveillance will opportunistically collect blood samples from patients coming into the practice for a routine blood test.
Bato bazosangana na bokengeli ya virisi bakozala na libaku ya kozwa ba echantillon ya makila ya bato oyo bayei mpo na ekzame na bango moko ya makila.
Patients who attend their practice for a routine blood test will be asked to provide an additional sample for serology.
Bato ya maladi oyo bazoya na bokutani na bango ya normal mpo na ekzame ya makila, basengeli kotuna bango bapesa echantillon mosusu mpo na serologie.
We have conducted initial searches within the RCGP RSC database to look at the number of full blood count (FBC) results and overall rates in adults and children (Figures 6-​-9).9).
Tosalaki bolukiluki ya liboso na bansango ya TRCGP RSC mpo na kotala motango nyonso ya resultat ya makila (FBC) mpe taux nyonso na mikolo mpe bana (Mitango 6-​-9).9).
An FBC is one of the most common tests performed, and we hope this will give an approximate indication of overall numbers of blood tests performed.
FBC eza moko ya ba ekzame oyo basalaka mingi, mpe tozolikya ete ekosalisa na koyeba motango ya ba ekzame nyonso ya makila oyo basali.

The sampling rate, per 100,000 patients was highest for children 15-17 years of age and 60 year or older in adults, with the lowest rates in children 0-4 years of age and 18-29 years of age in adults (Figures 6-​-99).

Taux ya ba echantillon, na kotalela bato ya maladi 100 000 ezali na likolo mingi mpo na bana ya mibu 15-17 mpe mikolo ya mibu 60 to koleka, taux ya nse ezalaki na bana ya mibu 0-4 mpe na mikolo ya mibu 18-29 (Mitango 6-​-99).
We will provide 1000 serology baseline samples across all ages that reflect the varying rates of attendance by age.
Tokopesa ba echantillon 1000 ya serologie na bato ya bambula nyonso oyo ezomonisa bokeseni ya taux ya bato oyo bayaki na kolanda mbula na bango.
Additionally, we will test if we can obtain these all from virology practices to enhance the yield.
Lisusu, tokomeka kotala soki kozwa makambo wana nyonso etali bavirisi ekosalisa mpo na kobongisa rendement.
A good geographical spread is important, so PHE can advise on areas where serology will most usefully be collected.
Kopanzana ya makasi na esika bato bafandi eza ntina, yango wana PHE akoki kopesa toli na bisika oyo bakoki mpenza kozwa serologie.
This will be followed by 800 samples monthly.
Na nsima na yango, tokosalela ba echantillon 800 sanza nyonso.
The sample will be stratified with 200 specimens for prepandemic survey (100 for monthly) in the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years or older.
Echantillon ekotyama na bituluku ya 200 mpo na anketi oyo ekosalema liboso ya maladi mabe (100 na sanza) na bituluku ya mbula oyo elandi: < mibu 5, mibu 5-17, mibu 18-64, mpe mibu 65 mpe koleka.
The younger patients, in many practices younger than 14 years, and in nearly all for children younger than 8 years will require pediatric serology surveillance.
Bato ya maladi oyo baza bilenge, mbala mingi bazalaki na nse ya mibu 14, mpe na bana nyonso oyo bakokisaki nanu te mibu 8, ekosenga bokengeli ya serologie mpo na bana.
We will develop a new request form for practices to capture recent travel and exposure to COVID-19.
Tokosala formilere ya sika ya bosengi mpo na koyeba bisika ya sika oyo moto akendaki mobembo mpe soki akutanaki na moto to bato ya COVID-19.
We will pilot a scheme for collecting convalescent serology from people with confirmed cases and who have had an acute virology sample at the time of their infection.
Tokokamba misala ya kosangisa serologie ya bato bazobika na bato oyo babelaki mpenza mpe oyo bazwaki bango echantillon ya virisi ya makasi na ntango bazalaka kobela.
This is to identify a carrier state in patients who have recovered from the virus but may continue shedding the virus.
Eza mpo na koyeba lolenge virisi yango eza na bato oyo basi babika na virisi wana kasi bakoki kolanda kopanza yango.
If there are a small number of cases, this may assist in developing a test kit for patients to take to their own GP and explore its acceptability to patients.
Soki motango ya bato eza moke mpenza, ekoki kosalisa na kosala eloko ya kosalela ekzame mpo bato ya maladi basala GP na bango bango moko mpe kotala soki bato ya maladi bakoki kozwa yango.

If there are a large number of COVID-19 cases nationally, convalescent samples could be collected from RCGP RSC practices where there are confirmed cases, with the ability to link to the full medical record.

Soki bato oyo bazobela COVID-19 baza mingi na mokili moko, bakoki kozwa ba echantillon ya bato bazobika na RCGP RSC esika baza na bankombo ya bato oyo baza na yango mpenza, mpe baza na makoki ya kotala dosie mobimba ya makambo ya monganga.

This process may include checking pseudonymized NHS numbers for positive individuals at RCGP RSC practices, checking current PHE guidance regarding considerations of infectiousness for confirmed cases, and offering the patient an appointment following the previously mentioned process.

Ekoki kosenga kotalela motango ya NHS mpo na bato oyo bakanga maladi epai ya lisanga RCGP RSC, kotalela litambwisi ya sika ya PHE na oyo etali kotalela bato oyo baza mpenza na maladi, mpe kopesa bato ya maladi rendez-vous na kolanda metode tolobeli likolo.
This needs to be carefully coordinated nationally across the network and may require PHE to ensure individuals are not contacted by multiple agencies.
Esengeli balandela yango malamu na mboka mobimba na nzela ya resaux mpe ekoki kosenga ete PHE etalela soki masanga mingi ezoluka te kokutana na bato.
RCGP RSC could provide a useful structure to channel the initial contact once PHE has made a request.
RCGP RSC ekoki kobimisa mwango mpo na kolandela bokutani ya liboso nsima ya lisengi ya PHE.
The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of a LRTI.
Bato ya RCGP RSC oyo basanganaka na bokengeli ya mbula na mbula ya virisi ya grippe babandi kozwa ba echantillon ya bato ya maladi oyo baza na bilembo ya LRTI.
All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
Ba echantillon nyonso oyo tozwaki bazosala yango ekzame mpo na koyeba soki eza na grippe mpe COVID-19.
The RCGP RSC will explore ways to collect convalescent samples from any patients tested positive for COVID-19 through the extension of the virological surveillance.
RCGP RSC ekoluka lolenge ya kosangisa ba echantillon ya bato oyo baza na kobika ya bato nyonso oyo bakangaki maladi ya COVID-19 na nzela ya bokengeli ya molai ya virisi.
From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.
Banda na ebandeli, tokotalela malamu bansango mpo na koyeba soki ekosalisa mpenza na bolukiluki na mikolo ezoya.
Our clinical data will be linked to virology.
Bansango oyo toza na yango toko lier yango na virologie.
We will curate our data using the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles.
Tokobongisa bansango na biso na kolanda mitinda ekoki kozwama, ekoki komonana, ekoki kokabolama, ekoki kosalelama.
To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.
Mpo na kolembisa mosala, totye bansango elongo na bansango ya bolukiluki ya kolongono ya nzoto ya Royaume-Uni mpe resaux ya bilembetli ya bansango ya kolongono ya nzoto ya Eropa.

The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.

Metode oyo ya kozwa bansango esimbami na mayele ya kolandela kopanzana ya maladi, esika oyo babengaka intervention nonpharmaceutique (NPIs) esalelamaka mpo na kobundisa maladi mabe ya mbalakaka na likanisi ya kosilisa yango.
This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.
Mokano ya mayele oyo eza ya kokitisa taux na kati ya bato mpe kosala ete virisi epanzana mingi.
To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.
Mpo na kosalela yango, guvernema ya Royaume-Uni emonisaki kala te mposa ya komeka mayele ya kosalisa bato bamifandela.

By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.

Na kolandelaka motango ya kobotama (R) (moyene ya bato oyo bazozwa maladi mpe kopesa yango na bato mosusu) mpe koluka kokitisa R na nse ya 1, mayele oyo ezoluka kokitisa motango na nse ya banivo to (ndenge tomonaki na virisi ya sika ya maladi makasi ya mpema mpe Ebola) mpo na kokanga nzela ete bato bapesa yango te na bato mosusu.
As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.
Ndenge makambo esalemaki na maladi ya 2009 H1N1 emonisi yango, NPIs ekoki kosalisa mingi na kolembisa maladi mabe.

Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.

Eloko ekosalisa biso mingi na bolukiluki oyo eza ntango oyo bato mingi mpenza bakozwa maladi mpe kokoba kolandela yango na kozwaka bansango mpe kolandela bokoli na yango mpe ntango mosusu oyo bato mingi mpenza bakozwa yango na ntango tozolongola mibeko ya komifandela.
There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.
Mikanda mingi esi ebimi oyo ezolobela ntina ya kotya mibeko kokanga virisi nzela na oyo etali kobima ya COVID-19 mokili Chine.
A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.

Mwango mosusu ya ntina mpo na kobundisa maladi mabe eza eleko oyo moto azwaka virisi kino ntango oyo moto yango akomaka na likoko ya kopesa yandi na basusu mpe eleko oyo azalaka kaka na likoki ya kopesa basusu.
These factors, if estimated accurately, will give good predictions for the likely length of the pandemic, the final number of infected cases.
Makambo oyo, soki totaleli yango malamumalamu, ekosalisa na koyeba malamu ntango oyo maladi mabe ekoumela, motango ya nsuka ya bato oyo bazwi maladi yango.
We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.

Toza na likanisi ya kosalela bosukisi ya Bayesian (ABC) na (mbala mosusu bokeseni ya monene) Oyo bakoki kozwa yango -Oyo bakutanaki na bato baza na yango- Oyo bazwi maladi-Oyo balongoli yango (SEIR) lolenge ya kolandela maladi oyo eyebani mpenza te.
Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
Mayele ya boye ekoki kosalisa na kosala bokokanisi mpe basi basalela yango na ba domaine mingi ata mpe na koyeba ndenge maladi elongwaka na moto moko mpe epesamaka na moto mosusu.
They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
Ebongi mpenza na ntango oyo mosala na yango ezala te mpe ezosenga kosalela mayele ya kala na ndakisa na Markov chain Monte Carlo.

Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.

Emonana ete mayele ya boye esimbaka na bokengeli ya bansango ya ASPREN, reseaux moko oyo elandelaka GPs mpe ba-infirmier oyo basalaka rapore ya ba ILIS oyo bamoni mpe ya maladi mosusu, mpe kuna basi balonga kosilisa makambo neti kobungisa bansango mpe ntina ya kobongisa lolenge ya kosala botaleli.
Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.
Lisusu, bametode ya kokabola esi eyeba ntango oyo bato mingi mpenza bazwaka maladi.

Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.

Tokoki koyeba ba parametre ya lolenge ya SEIR na bansango ya mingi mpo na metode ya bokokanisi, mpe bametode oyo basi basalela yango na babiblioteke mingi ya R; toza na likanisi ya kosalela babiblioteke ABSEIR (oyo batyaka na GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) mpe bisaleli abc (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) mpo na kolandela mposa nyonso mibeko batye mpo na kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te.
Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.
Banda tosalelala modele ya SIR ya maladi mabe na kolanda ABC, tozokanisa ete ekosalisa mpo bansango ya sika oyo tokozwa mposo nyonso ezala moke mpenza.

For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.

Na ndakisa, tala metode ABC oyo basalelaki na bansango ya maladi ya malili ebengami Tristan da Cunha ya mobu 1967, esika motango I (motango ya bato bazwi maladi wana) mpe R (motango ya bato oyo babiki) eza mbala mingi bazomi.
Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.
Na nsuka, longola metode touti kolobela, tokosalela metode ya Kaplan-Meier na ba résultat mibale (bato bakufi mpe bato babiki) mpo na koyeba taux ya liwa.
This approach is independent of the ABC methodology and will allow comparisons between estimates from the two modelling approaches to judge robustness of results.
Mayele oyo eza na boyokani te na metode ABC mpe ekosalisa na kosala bokesenisi na kati ya motango euti na bametode mibale ya koyeba bokasi ya ba résultat.
RCGP RSC’s surveillance with PHE is defined as Health Protection under Regulation 3 of The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
Bokengeli ya RCGP RSC elongo na PHE eza libateli ya kolongono ya nzoto na kolanda mobeko 3 ya misala ya kolongono ya nzoto (Kobatela bansango ya moto ya maladi) Mibeko ya 2002.
This has been confirmed by PHE’s Caldicott Guardian’s Office.
Yango endimisama na biro ya PHE Caldicott Guardian.
We do not see any increased risk to practices or practitioners taking part in this surveillance.
Tozomona te bokoli ata ya likama moko na ndenge minganga to ba infirmier ya sika bazosangana na bokengeli oyo.
Infection prevention and control advice will follow extant national guidance.
Kokanga maladi nzela mpe batoli ya kobatela yango ekosalema na kolanda litambwisi ya mboka.
Any cases identified will be managed according to the PHE/NHS guidance in force at the time, including advice for identified contacts.
Lokola tokolandela maladi nyonso oyo emonani na kolandela litambwisi ya PHE/NHS oyo tozosalela sikoyo, ata mpe batoli mpo na koyeba ndenge bato oyo bakutanaki.
However, our training will include reminders about safe handling of specimens and revision of infection control measures anticipated to be high in our practices.
Kasi, formation na biso ekozala mpe na makundoli etali kosalela ba echantillon na bokengi mpe ete mwango ya kolandela maladi ezala likolo mingi epai ya minganga na biso.
It is a key part of Regulation 12 about safe care and treatment, periodically inspected by the Care Quality Commission.
Eza eteni ya ntina ya Mobeko 12 oyo ezolobela kosalisa bato ya maladi na bokengi; balandelaka yango mbala na mbala na departema elandelaka makambo ya kosalisa bato ya maladi.
Travel History and Clinical Descriptors of the COVID-19 Infections
Lisolo ya mobembo mpe ndenge ya kolimbola maladi ya COVID-19
The RCGP RSC practices have been advised on the clinical coding that has been made available for COVID-19 across all CMR systems.
Bayebisi bato ya RCGP RSC oyo bazosala bakode ya bansango ya bato ya maladi ete basi babimisi yango mpo na COVID-19 na ba systeme nyonso ya CMR.
This includes information on coding of clinical descriptors (Table 4) and any recent travel history.
Etaleli mpe bansango ya kotya bakode na ba echantillon ya bato ya maladi (Tablo 4) mpe mobembo nyonso asalaki kala te.
Establishment of Extended Virology Sampling
Kokomisa molai virologie ya ba echantillon
The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of LRTI.
Bato ya RCGP RSC oyo basanganaka na bokengeli ya mbula na mbula ya virisi ya grippe, babandi kozwa ba echantillon ya bato ya maladi oyo baza na bilembo ya LRTI.
All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
Ba echantillon nyonso oyo tozwaki bazosala yango ekzame mpo na koyeba soki eza na grippe mpe COVID-19.
This has led to initial early identification of background spread in low-risk patients.
Yango esalisa na kobanda koyeba esika maladi ebandaki kokotela bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama mingi te.
As of March 7, 2020, the surveillance system has detected 2 cases of COVID-19 in low-risk patients with no history of travel through extended virological sampling.

Na mokolo ya 7 sanza ya nsambo 2020, systeme ya bokengeli ekangaki bato 2 oyo bazalaki na COVID-19 oyo bazalaki na likama mingi mpe basala te mobembo mingi, tomonaka yango na nzela ya echantillon ya bato ya maladi.
This protocol describes how we have adapted a national influenza surveillance system to monitor community spread of an unexpected infection of COVID-19.
Metode oyo ezolimbola ndenge tomesana na systeme ya bokengeli ya grippe mpo na kolandela kopanzana ya COVID-19 na ndenge eyebani te.
We have rapidly created and incorporated new codes to allow data recording, and are collecting data to monitor the effectiveness of containment strategies.
Tosali na lombango mpe tokotisa bakode ya sika mpo esalisa biso na kokoma bansango, mpe tosangisaka bansango mpo na koyeba bokasi ya mibeko ezwami oyo ezosenga bato bamifandela.
Through this surveillance, we intend to find out more about the epidemiology of COVID-19 in ambulatory care.
Na nzela ya bokengeli oyo, likanisi na biso eza ya koyeba makambo mingi etali maladi COVID-19 na esika ebengami soins ambulatoire.
In particular, its rate of spread, both temporal and geographical.
Mingimingi, taux ya kopanzana na yango, na mokili mpe na bamboka.
Our testing of low-risk patients will also inform whether the containment strategy that is based on virology testing of high-risk patients and their contacts plus self-isolation is effective.

Kosala baekzame na bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama mingi te eyebisaka mpe soki mayele ya kosenga bato bamifandela oyo esimbami na kosala ekzame na bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama ya makasi mpe bato bakutanaki na bango mpe ete komifandela ezobota mbuma.
Containment should slow the spread, and there may be benefits in the management of spread from intense surveillance.
Komifandela esalaka ete epanzana mingi te, mpe bokengeli ya makasi ya kopanzana ya maladi ekoki kozala na matomba mingi.
However, there may come a point at which the virus spreads more widely into the population, as has happened in Italy.
Kasi, ekoki kozala na ntango oyo virisi ezopanzana mingi na kati ya bato, ndenge esalemaki na Italie.
Surveillance of low-risk patients should inform when we reach this tipping point and when infection rates start to remit.
Kokengela bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama mingi te esengeli koyebisa ntango tokomi na eleko oyo wana mpe ntango taux ya maladi ebandi kokita.
The epidemiology of COVID-19 remains emergent.
Maladi ya COVID-19 eza kaka makasi.
The registration-based nature of UK primary care means that we will be able to create a complete picture of the cumulative incidence and duration.
Ndenge bazokomisa bansango ya premiers soins na Royaume-Uni elimboli ete tokoyeba malamu motango nyonso ya bato oyo bazwi maladi mpe ntango oyo esali.
The surveillance system should be able to identify areas where COVID-19 spread is taking place that might be suitable for trials of antiviral therapy.
Ebongiseli ya kokengela esengeli kokoka koyeba bisika oyo COVID-19 ezopanzana oyo ebongi mpo na komeka mangwele na yango na bato.
We could also follow up on the effectiveness or any adverse reactions to these medicines or vaccinations.
Tokokí pe kolandela bolongi to bakpokoso ya mabe na bakisi yango to bamangwele yango.
Finally, early detection of a confirmed COVID-19 case has exemplified the rapid implementation of this enhanced surveillance in the national network.
Na suka, boyebi na tango malamu ya bokono ya cas ya COVID-19 kati ya moto ekopesa ndakisa ya kosalela na bombango bokengeli emata na reseau ekolo mobimba.
Safety of practices is our primary concern.
Bosembo ya bisaleli na biso totie liboso na motema.

The RCGP RSC has operated for over 50 years and has been involved in collecting samples to monitor disease and vaccine effectiveness through the Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, and the 2009 Swine flu pandemic.

RCGP RSC ebanda misala koleka mibu 50 pe azali kati ya likambo ya bokongoli ya ba echantillon pona kenge bavaccin malamu penza tango ya pandemie ya grippe ya Hong Kong na1968/69, grippe ya Russe ya 1977/78, pe pandemie ya grippe ya ngulu na 2009.
We are not aware of any increased risk to practice staff or other patients from involvement in surveillance.
Toyebi te likambo etali bobakisi ya likama na basali to bato ya bokono mosusu na bokotisi bango na bokengeli.
Pandemic preparedness is part of the role of the RCGP RSC.
Komilengela pona pandemi ezali ndambo ya mosala ya RCGP RSC.

It is plausible that enhanced coding of information from contacts with the practices in RCGP RSC will reduce the likelihood of people who may be suspected COVID-19 cases being brought to the surgery inadvertently.

Ezo monana na miso polele ete kocoder nsango na bokangani na bisaleli na RCGP RSC ekokitisa mabe na bato baye bakoki kokaniselama bazali na bokono ya COVID-19 bamemama na disuku ya bopasoli pona kozanga boyebi.
Where cases are detected unexpectedly, it is probably helpful for that patient, their contacts, and the practice to know.
Bisika bacas ezomonana kozanga bozeli na yango, ekoki kozala na lisalisi pona mobeli wana, bacontacki naye, na esaleli bayeba.
The impact on practices has been to close for a day, if a case is found, for deep cleaning and then reopen.
Kwokoso na esaleli ezalaki ete mokolo wana bakanga, soki cas emonani mpo basokola mozindo pe bafungola.
The principal limitations of our system are the number of data points.
Ndelo monene na systemi nabiso nde eza lotango ya bapoint ya badonnee.
We are collecting serology and virology data from 100 sites, which covers a small group of the population.
Tozo kongola badonnee ya serologie pe virologie epai ya basite 100, moto ezo talamela lotango moke ya bato.
This has been satisfactory for monitoring influenza, but we are not certain if this is a sufficiently large sample for the COVID-19 outbreak.
Oyo ezalaki nango malamu pona kokengela ba grippe kasi nde ezangi bosolo ya makasi soki monene nango ekoka penza na echantillon pona bobimi ya COVID-19.
Our sites (surveillance practices) are currently fixed, and it could be helpful to be able to rapidly onboard practices in regions where there are more cases.
Site nabiso (bisaleli ya bokengeli) ezali sik’oyo fixe, pe ekoki kozala likambo ya ntina monene ematisa masalisi na bombango na bingunda bacas mingi koleka ezali.
Currently, we will be reporting weekly.
Mikol’oyo to kobanda koraporter poso na poso.
Our existing system can be enhanced to twice weekly, but maybe daily or hourly data should be our current approach.
Systeme nabiso eko kobakisama na bolamu mpo ezala mbala mibale na mposo, kasi mbala mosusu ya mokolo to ya ngonga esengeli ezala nzela nabiso ya sik’oyo.
Opportunistic sampling for serology in children younger than 10 years might be limited due to the overall reduced rate of blood tests in children.
Echantillonage ya opportunite pona serologie na bana bilenge nase ya mibu 10 ekoki kozala na ndelo mpona boyekoli ya makila ya bana eza moke.
The extended surveillance using the RCGP RSC-PHE network for the emergent COVID-19 outbreak has been established rapidly.
Bobakisi ya bokengeli na bosaleli ya reseau ya RCGP RSC-PHE mpona bobimi ya COVID-19 esi ebelemi na bombango penza.
The model of getting the appropriate informatics to enable capture of the required data has already been a success, with data recording starting the week the codes were created.
Modele ya bozwi bainformatiki elongobani mpo esalisa na kocapter badonnee esengami esi elongi, bongo nde bokomi ya badonnee ebandaki mokolo ya mposo bacode ebongisamaki.
In addition, modifying the existing surveillance system to collect population data in a parallel way has also been effective.
Na kobakisa, bokesenesi ya systeme ya bokengeli oyo esi esalama pona kokongola badonnee ya bato na nzela ya paralleli ezalaki pe na bolongi.

However, we are at present unsure as to whether the scale of this surveillance provides sufficient data to drive local containment strategies or if reporting infrequently meets the need of our information age.

Kasi nde pona sik’oyo tozo yeba penza te soki to longola kaka bokengeli yango pona kopesa badonnee ekoka pona kobatela bastrategie ya confinement ya esika to kosala reportage ezo silisa posa ya koyeba nsango ya sik’oyo.
Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
Mis-à-jour ya boyebeli “cas bakaniseli” eza na bokono ya COVID-19 na “cas endimami” eza na ntina penza

On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.

Na 6 Février 2020, lisanga nabiso epubliaki lisungi ya toli ya bombango pona koyebela pe kobelisa bokono ya kpokoso ya coronavirus yasika 2019 (2019-nCoV), bongo lisungi yango epesaki lolenge ya biso toyebeli na bobelesi pona kobundisa pandemi oyo ya mokili mobimba.

However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.

Kasi, bokono ya coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) eza yasika, boyebi na bwania bwabiso mpona yango ezo mata moke-moke na botali makundoli mazo monana pe bisaleli ya cliniki bizo yebana; bongo wana nde eza bastrategie ya diaginositiki pe bobelesi ezo landama kotiama à jour.

In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.

Na mokanda oyo, topesaki eyano na commentaire moko na lisungi nabiso pe topesi critere ya boyebeli yasika-sika pona “cas bakaniseli” pe “cas endimami” na bolandi Diagnostiki ya suka penza lisungi ya kobelesa pona COVID-19 (version ya sambo) oyo ebimisami na bakonzi ya Comite National ya Sante ya Republika Populaire ya Chine.

In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

Na Decemba 2019, coronavirus yasika 2019, (2019-nCoV) ebimisi kpokoso, oyo ezo bengama na loyalo bokono ya coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) ebongo virus yango eye kobengama syndrome respiratoire acute coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
Na 11 Mars 2020, WHO elimboli COVID-19 mpo ebengama pandemie.
In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
Mpona kobunda na bokono ya SARS-CoV-2, lisanga nabiso ekolisi lisungi ya toli ya bombango bongo yango nde ezali publie na molongo ya Interneti na Bokundoli ya Medical ya Basoda ya 06 Fefrier 2020.
It has attracted a great attention since published.
Ebendi batangi mingi banda publication na yango.

Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.

Kasi nde yeba ete COVID-19 eza yasika, boyebi na bwania bwabiso mpona yango ezo mata moke-moke na botali makundoli mazo monana pe bisaleli ya cliniki bizo yebana; bongo wana nde eza bastrategie ya diaginosiitiki pe bobelesi ezo landama kotiama à jour.

For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.

Ndakisa masungi ya Diagnositiki na Bobelesi pona COVID-19 ebimisamaki na Comite National ya Sante ya Republika Populaire ya Chine (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), kati-kati ya 16 Janvier 2020 tii 3 Mars 2020, esi ebimisi ba edition sambo bongo nde bacontexte mosusu ezali kobongwana makasi.
Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
Sik’oyo lisungi nabiso ezwaki commentaire moko na Zhou et al., bakotisaki lolenge ya pete-pete ya kopesa bapoint na bolandi ya experience nabango ya cliniki.
Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
Mosala nabango ebakisi bilembo yasika mpo na lisungi pe esali botindi ya ntina pona pandemie mokili mobimba.
We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
Toyambi mosala nabango ya ntina monene pe totondi bango botondi.
However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
Kasi, mosala nabango pe ezo senga mis-à -jour na botali Masungi ya Diagnostiki pe Bobelesi yasika pona COVID-19 (Meka version ya sambo) mayekoli ma leki.

According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:

Na bolandi edition ya sambo (3 Mars 2020), pona kondima cas bakaniseli ezo senga bosangisi ya itemi moko ya lisolo ya bikila-kila ya epidemiologie na ba itemi mibale ya ba manifestation ya cliniki pona kosala analyse mobimba, to eza na posa etondisa ba itemi misato ya ba manifestation ya cliniki soki ezangi moi ya nsango ya epidemiologie:

Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).

Nsango ya Epidemiologie: (1) nsango ya mobembo to ya bofandi na mboka Wuhan pe pembeni nango, to masanga mosusu ya bacas ya COVID-19 esalami lapolo mikolo 14 eleki liboso basymptomi ebanda; (2) nsango ya bokangani na cas ya SARS-CoV-2 (teste positive ya noyau ya acide nucleiki); (3) nsango ya bokangani ma mobeli ya nzoto fievre to basymptomi ya kopema awuti na mboka Wuhan na bisika ya pembeni to lisusu masanga mosusu esika basali lapolo ya bacas ya COVID-19 na mikolo 14 eleki liboso ya basymptomi ya ebandeli; (4) nsango ya bokangani na liboke ya bacas endimami (≥ cas 2 na fievre pe/to basymptomi ya kopema kati ya poso 2 na bisika mike, ndakisa ndako, bilo, kelasi ya sikola, bnb).

Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.

Bamanifestation ya cliniki: (1) fievre pe/to basymptomi ya bopemi; (2) na bilembo ya bilili ya bokono ya COVID-19 ; (3) lotango ya baglobule ya pembe nionso ezo lakisa normale, ekita, to lotango ya lymphocyte ekita na tango ya ebandeli.

Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.

Diagnostiki ya cas endimami esengeli ezala nase ya cas bakaniseli na itemi ata moko ya ekenenge to evidence ya serologie evidence lokola elandi awa: (1) teste ya PCR ya temps reel positive pona SARS-CoV-2; (2) bolandi ya genome mobimba ezo lakisa homogeneite emata na ba coronavirus yasika eyebani; (3) eza positive pona IgM specifiki ya anticorps pe IgG anticorps na SARS-CoV-2 na teste ya serume; to mbongwana na IgM ya SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG anticorps uta negative ti positive, to kobuta ya titer ≥ mbala 4 na phase ya recouvrement likolo ya cas phase ya songe.
We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
Toko komona ete teste ya PCR ya temps reel pona acide nucleiki na nzela ya kopemela to echantillon ya makila ebakisamaki na ba edition ya mibale (18 Janvier 2020) pe ya misato (22 Janvier 2020).
The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.
Bokundoli ya ekenenge ya echantillon ya makila ebakisamaki na ba edition ya mine (27 Janvier 2020) pe ya mitano (8 Février 2020); pe evidence ya serologie ebakisamaki na edition ya sambo .

These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.

Bambongwana yango na botali ya bakundoli elandelaki mosala ete pona koluka bisaleli ya diaginositiki ya bombango pona bokundoli optimal ya acide nucleiki, elongo na echantillon ya nzela ya bopemeli tia nakati echantillon ya makila, mutu ebutisaki bobelemi ya ba endimeli ya ndenge ebele, pe esungaki bomemi ya resultat ya anticorps specifiki positive na bacritiki endimama.
Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
Lisusu, ba evidence ezo matisama oyo ezo rappeler biso ete to bimisa miso na babeli baza atypiki symptomatiki na asymptomatiki.
Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
Pona kolanda, graphiki ya Zhou et al. esengeli etiamama à jour, lokola batiaki moto azanga basymptome cliniki esika ya “riske ya moke“.
The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
Systemi ya ba point pe esengeli ezala vérifié na masaleli pe mayekoli ya cliniki ya kobakisa.
To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
Mpona kosukisa, toza na elikia ete ba evidence ya libela ekobakisama pe ebengi batangi bapesa ndenge bamoneli.
For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
Mpona diaginositiki ya “cas ekaniselami” pe “endimami” tozo belela kolanda pe kotosa nde masungi yasika mazo uta na bikolo na bango.
Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
Lisanga nabiso pe ekosala mis a jour na tango ekoka lisungi nabiso pona kopesa lisalisi.
Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
Bangladesh epesi rapor ete bato misato bakufi na COVID-19, koleka mikolo misusu
Yesterday, Bangladesh has confirmed five new deaths due to COVID-19 on the day.
Lobi, Bangladesh epesi sango ete bato mitano bakufi na COVID-19 na mokolo moko.
This is the highest number of fatalities in a day due to the virus.
Oyo ezali kufa ya likolo koleka na virisi oyo.

As of yesterday, Bangladesh's Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) reported the number of recorded infected cases included 114 active cases and 33 recovered cases who were staying home.
Lobi, Institut ya Bangladesh ya bapandemi, Kolandela Maladi na Bolukiluki (IEDCR) balobi ete motango bato bazali na maladi ezali 114 mpe 33 oyo bazalaki kofanda na ndako babiki.
A total of 17 deaths have been recorded.
Bato 17 bakufi.
In an online news briefing, the director of IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, said the fatalities included four males and one female.
Na basango ya internet, Directeur ya IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, alobi ete bato oyo bakufi ezali mibali mibale mpe basi mibale.
According to Dr Meerjady, two cases were aged above 60, two between 51 and 60, and one 41-50 years old.
Mpona Dr Meerjady, mibale bazali na mibu 60, mibale mibu kati na 51 te 60, mpe moko kati na mibu 41 te 50.
She also said two of the victims were from Dhaka.
Alobi mpe ete mibale ya bato oyo bakufi bawuti Dhaka.
The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11.
Organization Mondial ya Sante (OMS) ebengi COVID-19 pandemi mokolo ya 11 sanza ya liboso.

A hospital official told Anadolu Agency, a local news outlet, that one of the deceased was Jalal Saifur Rahman, a director of Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, who was cared for at the Kuwait Maitree Hospital.

Moto azali kosala na lepital alobi na Anadolu Agency, esika ya basango ya mboka, moko ya bato oyo akufi ezali Jalal Saifur Rahman, Directeur ya commission ya Kotelema-Moyibi, oyo azalaki na lepital ya Kuwait Maitree.

On Saturday, in an online video announcement, Bangladeshi Road Transport and Bridges Minister Obaidul Quader said public transport would be shut down for longer than initially planned, until this coming Saturday.
Na mokolo ya mposo, na video ya basango na internet, Ministre ya nzela na Bangladesh Obaidul Quader alobaki ete babis ekokanga mpona mikolo ebele, ti mokolo ya mposo oyo ezali koyaka.
This public transport shutdown had initially started on March 26 and was planned to end on Saturday, April 4.
Kokanga ya babis oyo ebandaki mokolo ya 26 sanza ya misato mpe esengelaki esila mokolo ya mposo, sanza ya minei na mokolo ya 4.
Transport of essential goods -- medical, fuel and food -- was still allowed.
Komema biloko oyo ezali na ntina – bankisi, mafuta ya mituka na ya bilei – ekoki koleka.
The first recorded incidents of COVID-19 infection in Bangladesh were on March 8, in two people who returned from Italy and also the wife of one of them.
Bamaladi ya liboso ya COVID-19 na Bangladesh ezalaki mokolo ya 8 sanza ya misato, na bato mibale oyo bautaki Italie mpe mwasi ya moko na bango.
As of March 19, these three had already recovered.
Na mokolo ya 19 sanza ya misato, bato oyo misato babikaki.
National Basketball Association suspends season due to COVID-19 concerns
Association national ya Basket esukisaki mpona likama ya COVID-19.
On Wednesday, the United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) suspended its professional basketball season due to concerns regarding COVID-19.
Na mokolo ya misato, Ekipi ya Basket ya Etats Unis (NBA) esukisaki saison mpona COVID-19.
The NBA's decision followed a Utah Jazz player testing positive for the COVID-19 virus.
Ekateli ya NBA ebandaki tango joeur ya Jazz na Utah abelaki na virisi COVID-19.
The NBA did not release the identity of the player in question in its announcement.
NBA epesaki nkombo ya joeur ten a basango na bango.
They did say he was not present at Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, where the Utah Jazz were to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.
Balobaki te soki ye azalaki na Chesapeake Energie na Arena ya egumba ya Oklahoma, esika oyo bajoueur ya Utah Jazz balingaki babeta na baThunder ya egumba ya Oklahoma.
According to its press release, the NBA was "suspending game play following the conclusion of [Wednesday's] schedule of games until further notice."
Kati na basango na bango, NBA ‘’esukisaki bajeux nsima ya kosilisa Masano (ya mokolo ya misato)’’
The Jazz's game was cancelled, as was another NBA game Wednesday between the Sacramento Kings and the New Orleans Pelicans.
Masano ya Jazz ekangaki, mpe mosusu ya NBA na mokolo ya misato kati na Sacramento Kings na baPelicans ya New Orleans.
Other games scheduled for Wednesday were still held, according to NBC News.
Masano oyo esengelaki ebetama na mokolo ya misato ebetamaki, ndenge Basango ya NBC elobaki.

The United States' other major basketball organization, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which runs college basketball, has cancelled its own tournament, March Madness, for both men's and women's leagues.
Organisation monene ya Etats Unis ya basket, Association ya ba athlete ya college, ekangi masano, Liboma ya Mars, mpona masano ya mibale mpe ya basi.
According to Johns Hopkins University, as of Wednesday, there were at least 1,279 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the United States.
Mpona universite ya John Hopkins, na mokolo ya misato, bazalaki na bato ya kobela na COVID-19 1,279 na Etats Unis.
CNBC reported there were at least 118,381 cases worldwide.
CNBC elobaki ete bazali 118,381 na mokili nyonso.
SARS-CoV-2 surpasses one million infections worldwide
SARS-Cov-2 eleki bamaladi moko na milio na mokili mobimba
On Thursday, the total number of cases of the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infections surpassed one million worldwide, Johns Hopkins University data indicated.
Na mokolo ya minei, motango ya ba oyo babeli na SARS-CoV-2 maladi ya coronavirisi elekaki milio moko na mokili, elobi makomi ya Johns Hopkins.
At least 52 thousand deaths were linked to COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
Kufa 52 ezalaki ya COVID-19, maladi oyo euti na coronavirisi.
The milestone came the same day Malawi confirmed its first coronavirus infections and Zambia had its first coronavirus-related death.
Molongi wana eye mokolo oyo Malawi na Zambie bazalaki na ya bango ya liboso oyo azalaki kobela coronavirisi.
North Korea claimed, as of Thursday, it was one of the few countries remaining free of coronavirus infections.
Na Corée ya Nordi balobaki ete, na mokolo ya minei, bazalaki mboka ya liboso kati na bamboka oyo bazalaki na bato ya kobela coronavirisi te.
By yesterday, the World Health Organization reported 1,051,635 confirmed cases, including 79,332 cases in the twenty four hours preceding 10 a.m. Central European Time (0800 UTC) on April 4.
Lobi, Organization Mondial ya Sante epesi sango ya 1,051,635 oyo bazalaki kobela mpe 79,332 na mokolo 1 uta 10h Ngonga ya Europe (0800UTC) na mokolo ya 4 sanza ya minei 4.
In the United States, over 244 thousand coronavirus cases were recorded, linking to at least 5,900 deaths.
Na États-Unis, koleka ya bato ya kobela nkoto 244 na coronavirisi, mpe kufa 5,900.
CBS News reported, citing Johns Hopkins University data, there were over 1,000 US deaths on Wednesday caused by coronavirus infections.
Basango ya CBS elobi ete, nsima ya Université ya Johns Hopkins, bato ya kokufa na maladi ya coronavirisi bazalaki 1,000 na mokolo ya misato.
Around the world, countries announced stricter measures to inhibit the disease from spreading.
Na mokili, bamboka batieli mibeko makasi mpona kosukisa kopalangana ya virisi.
On Thursday, Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, extended the city lockdown to May 1.
Na mokolo ya minei, Sergei Sobyanin, Maire ya Moscow, apusaki konfinema ti mokolo ya 1 sanza ya mitano.
Nationally, President Vladimir Putin declared Russians would continue to be paid without going to work until April 30.
Na mboka nyonso, Mokambi Vladimir Putin alobaki ete bato ya Russie bakotikala kozwa lifuti ata soki bazali kokende mosala te ti sanza ya minei mokolo ya 30.
The parliament of Portugal voted to extend the national state of emergency by 15 days; the vote passed with 215 votes in favor, ten abstentions, and one vote against.
Parlement ya Portugal aponaki kopusa konfinema na mikolo 15; vote elekaki na 215 vote, zomi bazalaki te, mpe moko aboyaki yango.
Saudi Arabia extended curfews in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina to last the entire day; previously, the curfew was only in effect between 3 p.m. and 6 a.m.
Na Arabie Saudi bapusaki konfinema na bamboka ya santu ya Mecca na Medina mpona mokolo mobimba; liboso, konfinema ezalaki kaka mpona 3h ya mpokwa ti 6h ya ntongo.
Thailand planned to implement a curfew between 10 p.m. and 4 a.m.
Thailand ebongamaki na couvre-fe na 10h ya mpokwa ti 4h ya ntongo.
The governor of Ohio, Mike DeWine, announced the state had extended its stay-at-home order until May 1.
Gouverneur ya Ohio, Mike DeWine alobaki ete egumba ekopusa kofanda-na-ndako ti mokolo ya 1 ya sanza ya mitano.
Stores in Australia lower toilet paper limits per transaction
Babutik na Australie basukisaki boni y aba papiergenik moto moko akoki ko somba

On Sunday and Saturday evening, Australian store chains Woolworths and Coles lowered their purchase restrictions on toilet paper to two and one package per transaction in all stores on national level, respectively.
Na mokolo ya lomingo mpe ya mposo nab utu, butik ya Australie babengi Woolworths na Coles batiaki mibeko na kosomba papiergenik na moko to mibale na moto na babutik nyonso ya mboka.
ALDI also introduced a one-pack limit, on Monday.
ALDI mpe akotisaki mibeko ya moko kaka na moto, na mokolo ya liboso.
These limitations were posted as messages on the checkouts, and on the chains' Facebook pages.
Mibeko oyo ekomamaki na mokanda libanda ya butik mpe na Facebook na bango.
Buyers were reportedly stocking up due to fears of COVID-19 in case people need to self-isolate.
Bato bazalaki kosomba ebele mpona bomo ete COVID-19 ekoki kotinda bato bakangama na ndako.
On Wednesday, Woolworths also limited toilet paper purchases for home delivery to one pack per order.
Na mokolo ya misato, Woolworths mpe ekotisi mibeko na misala ya livraison-domicile na papiergenik boni moto akoki kosomba.
These changes followed the previous four-pack per transaction restriction introduced by Woolworths and Coles on March 4 and 5 respectively.
Mibeko oyo elandaki ya minei kaka na moto na Woolworths na Coles mokolo ya 4 na 5 sanza ya misato.

Coles, in its March 8 media release, reported that with the four-pack restriction in place, "many stores are still selling out within an hour of delivery", and called the demand "unprecedented", while ALDI, in a Facebook post on Tuesday, called it "unexpected".

Coles, na basango na ye ya mokolo ya 8 sanza ya misato, alobaki ete mibeko ya minei-na-moto ekotaki, ‘’babutik misusu biloko ezali kosila kaka na ngonga moko soki biloko eye mpe abengi mposa ya bato ‘ya koleka’, ntango ALDI, na Facebook na mokolo ya mibale abengaki yango ‘Ya koleka’.
Sales went up in a "sharp increase" last week, according to a Woolworths spokesperson.
Koteka ‘emataki makasi’ mposo oyo eleki, elobi moto ya Woolworths.
Costco's store in Canberra also limited the allowed amount to two packs last week.
Butik ya Costo a Canberra mpe asukisaki na mibale na moto mposo oyo eleki.

To further alleviate the shortage, Coles ordered bigger packages from suppliers and increased delivery frequency, Woolworths ordered extra stock, while ALDI made stocks for a planned Wednesday special available early.
Mpona kosepelisa mitungisi oyo biloko ezalaki kosila, Coles asengaki biloko mingi, Woolwoths asengaki mpe mingi, AlDI asengaki biloko ya mokolo ya misato oyo ezali koyaka mikolo mingi liboso.
Russell Zimmerman, executive director of the Australian Retailers Association, said that retailers try to raise stock, but local council restrictions on the timing of truck-deliveries make it hard.
Russell Zimmerman, Executive Directeur ya Association ya Bateki na Australie alobaki ete, bateki bazali komatisa biloko ya koteka, kasi mibeko ya mboka ezali kotungisa bango makasi.
He expects rising production costs, as suppliers try to meet demand, and fewer specials.
Bato bayeba ete makasi ya kosala biloko esengeli emata mpona kotondisa mposa ya bato.
On Tuesday, ALDI announced that following the early release of stock, some stores can't run the Wednesday special.
Na mokolo ya mibale, ALDI alobaki ete nsima oyo babimisaki biloko mikolo liboso, babutik misusu bako zala na Special ya mokolo ya misato te.
In a News.com.au report, Dr Gary Mortimer, retail expert from Queensland University of Technology, said the stores fill the stock every night.
Na rapor ya news.com.au, Dr Gary Mortimer, moteki ya koyeba makasi na Universite ya Technologu na Queensland alobaki babutik ekotisaka biloko batu nyonso.
He remarked toilet paper is a bulky item, leading to low quantity of stocks in numbers, and, when sold out, leaves vast shelf spaces empty, hardening the feeling of a shortage.
Amonaki ete papiergenik ezali eloko ya monene, mpona bongo te ekotaka mukie, mpe ekendeke noki, ekikaka bisika ya butik pamba, yango nde ekotisaka lisusu kobanga ya kosila ya biloko.

"Coles and Woolworths have a view [that] if there was plenty of stuff on the shelf, if product like toilet rolls and sanitiser could be [bought] and are there in quantities, you would probably minimise the panic" said Russell Zimmerman per ABC News.

‘’Coles na Woolworths balobi solo (ete) soki biloko ezalaki mingi na butik, soki biloko lokola papiergenik na kisi ya kosokola maboko ekokaki (kosombama) na mingi, nkasi bomo mpe ekiti’’ elobi Russell Zimmerman na Basango ya ABC.
Recycled toilet paper producer Who Gives a Crap said on last Wednesday they'd run out of stock.
Moto oyo asalaka ba Papiergenik nkombo Who Gives a Crap alobi na mokolo ya misato oyo eleki bazalaki lisusu na biloko te.
Kimberly-Clark, which makes Kleenex Toilet Tissue, and Solaris Paper which makes Sorbent, emphasized they were working 24/7 to maintain the supply, according to the News.com.au report.
Kimberly-Clark, oyo asalaka papier ya Kleenex, na mosali ya papier ya Solaris oyo esalaka Sorbent, balobaki ete bazali na mosala 24/7 mpona kotondisa mposa ya bato, nsima ya basango ya news.com.au.

Domain.com, a real estate site, reported some property sellers offering free toilet paper to the first bidder on auctions in Melbourne, when fewer auctions were held because of buyers having time off on the long weekend of Labour Day.

Domain.com, bato ya mosala ya ba ndako balobaki ete bakolo ndako misusu bazalaki kopesa paiergenik ya ofele na moto ya liboso oyo akopesa talo mpona kosomba ndako, ntango bato bazalaki kosomba lisusu mingi te mpo ete bazalaki na eloko te ya kosala na suka ya mposo ya mokolo ya basali.
The Thursday edition of NT News, a daily printed in Darwin, included an eight-page insert meant to be cut up and used as toilet paper.
Basango ya mokolo ya minei ya NT News, basanga ya kotanga ya Darwin, ezalaki na papier mwambe oyo bato bakokaki kokata mpona kosalisa lekola papiergenik.
The stores were originally reluctant to impose restrictions, according to a report from ABC Australia on March 3 in which they said they had no plans to introduce restrictions on the purchases.
Liboso babutik balingaki te kokotisa mibeko, rapor ya Australi ya ABC elobi mokolo ya 3 ya sanza ya misato bazalaki na mposa te ya kosukisa biloko boni bato bazalaki kosomba.
Russell Zimmerman added that other products are also in high demand, including masks, sanitiser, dried goods, handwash and flour.
Russell Zimmerman alobaki ete bato bazali mpe na mposa makasi ya biloko misusu, lokola bamask, bakisi ya bopeto, bilei ya kokauka, ya kosokola maboko mpe farine.
Similarly, outside of Australia, on Sunday evening online British supermarket Ocado was observed limiting purchases of Andres toilet paper to two 12-roll packs.
Mpe, libanda ya Australie, na mokolo ya loming nab utu na butik ya Ocado na Angleterre bamonaki ete bato bazalaki kosomba lisusu mingi ya papiergenik ya Andre te na mibale ya packet ya 12.
US President Trump declares COVID-19 national emergency
Mokambi ya US Trump abengaki COVID-19 likama national
On Friday, United States President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.
Na mokolo ya mitano, Mokambi ya Etats Unis Donald Trump abengaki likambo ya kopalangana coronavirisi likama national.
The move came two days after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak, which causes the COVID-19 disease, to be a pandemic.
Ezalaki mikolo mibale nsima ya Organisation Mondial ya Sante abenga yango Likama, oyo esali ete maladi ya COVID-19 ezala pandemi.
The move gives the federal government access to around US$50 billion in extra funding to combat the pandemic, according to NBC News.
Epesi gouvernema federal babimisa US$50 bilio ya mbogo ya kobomba mpona kobunda pandemic, elobi basango ya NBC News.

The proclamation specifically said "the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States constitutes a national emergency" and said the national emergency began on March 1, almost two weeks before the proclamation itself.

Na monoko na bango moko balobaki ‘’Kopalangana ya COVID-19 na Etats Unis ezali Likama national’’ mpe balobi ete likama national ebandaki sanza ya misato mokolo ya 1, mposo mibale liboso ya kopesa yango nkombo.
The United States Department of Health and Human Services declared the outbreak a "public health emergency" on January 31.
Departema ys Etats Unis mpona Kolongono mpe kosalisa bato ebengaki yango kopalangana ya likama ya kolongono ya bato’’ sanza ya liboso mokolo ya 31.
Trump did not place the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in charge of the government's response to COVID-19, which Politico reported left some experts in disaster management disappointed.
Trump apesi nguya te na Federation ya Kolandela Likama (FEMA) mpona kolandela mosala ya gouvernema na etumba ya COVID-19, oyo Politico alobaki etikaki bayeko mingi na kati ya kobunga.

Politico quoted Tim Manning, formerly a deputy administrator at FEMA, as saying "FEMA has an important role in coordinating the larger response to the crisis" and "[i]f there's an emergency, FEMA needs to be involved."

Politico alobaki nini Tim Manning alobaki, oyo azalaki depute ya FEMA ya kala, alobi ‘FEMA ezali na mosala ya ntina na kolanda mosala ya etumba oyo’’ mpe ‘’Soki likama ezali esengeli ete FEMA ayeba.’’
Trump made the decision under provisions of the National Emergencies Act, amongst other governing authorities.
Trump akatelaki na kati na Act ya Likama National, mpe kati ya mibeko misusu.

The Trump administration also announced other efforts in response to COVID-19, including waiving the interest it collects on federal student loans and increasing U.S. strategic oil reserve oil purchases.
Biro ya Trump ebandaki misala misusu mpe mpona kobundela COVID-19, lokola kolandela banyongo ya bana kelasi mpe komatisa mafuta ya ekolo ya U.S.
World Health Organization declares COVID-19 pandemic
Organization Mondial ya Sante ebengi COVID-19 pandemi
On Wednesday, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19 — the disease caused by coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 — to be a pandemic.
Na mokolo ya misato, Organisation Mondial ya Sante (OMS) ebengaki kopalangana ya maladi oyo ya COVID-19 – Maladi oyo euti na coronavirisi ya SARS-CoV-2 – ezali pandemi.
Although the word "pandemic" only refers to how widely a disease has spread, not how dangerous specific cases are, the WHO noted the need to drive governments to action:
Ata ete nkombo ‘pandemi’ elandi kaka ndege nini malady etamboli molayi, kasi makasi na yango te, OMS emonaki ntina ya bagouvernema babanda mosala:
"All countries can still change the course of this pandemic.
‘’Bamboka nyonso bakoki kosukisa pandemic oyo.
If countries detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilize their people in the response," said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the Director-General of the WHO.
Soki bamboka bamoni, basali baekzame, ba salisi bato, batie konfinema mpe balandeli mpe basangani bato mpona etumba,’’ elobi Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, irector-general ya OMS.
"We are deeply concerned both by the alarming levels of spread and severity and by the alarming levels of inaction."
‘’tozali na kobanga na ndenge nini ezali kopalangana mpe na ndenge nini eloko te ezali kosalema.’’
According to Dr. Tom Frieden, formerly the director of the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the pandemic is "unprecedented."
Elobi Dr. Tom Frieden, oyo azalaki directeur ya kala ya Esika oyo Elandelaka bamaladi mpe Esukisaka yango mpona Etats Unis, pandemic ezala ‘ya bikamwa.’
He said, in remarks published by CNN in February, "other than influenza, no other respiratory virus has been tracked from emergence to continuous global spread."
Alobi ete, na oyi basango ya CNN epesaki na sanza ya mibale, ‘’libanda ya influenza, maladi mosusu te ya mpema elandanaki na likama to na kopalangana na mokili.’’
Ghebreyesus expressed a similar view, saying "we have never before seen a pandemic sparked by a coronavirus."
Ghebreyesus alobaki mpe bongo, alobaki ‘’nani totikali komona pandemi oyo salami na coronavirisi te’.’
He continued, "and we have never before seen a pandemic that can be controlled at the same time."
Alobi lisusu, ‘’mpe nani tomona te pandemi oyo ekoki kosukisama.’’
The new status as a pandemic follows the WHO's decision in January to declare the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern.
Ebengami ya pandemi euti na ekateli ya OMS na sanza ya liboso kobenga yango likama ya kolongono mpona mokili mobimba.
The United States' National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease's director, Dr. Anthony Fauci, said of the outbreak, "bottom line, it's going to get worse."
Dr ya Institu ya BaAlergie a Etats Unis na ya ba Maladi Anthony Fauci, alobaki ‘’nsima makambo eko beba makasi.’’
As of Thursday, Associated Press reported there were at least 126,000 cases of COVID-19 worldwide, resulting in over 4,600 deaths.
Na mokolo ya minei, Basango ya Bomoko bapesi rapor ete kati 126,000 ya ba oyo babelaki COVID-19 na mokili 4,600 bakufaki.
The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic is an ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Na 2019-20 Pandemi ya coronavirisi ezali pandemic ya coronavirisi ya 2019 (COVID-19), euti na maladi ya mpema ya coronavirisi 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
The outbreak was identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019, declared to be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 30 January 2020, and recognized as a pandemic on 11 March 2020.
Maladi emonanaki na Whuhan, Chine, na sanza ya zomi na mibale 2019, ekomaki likama ya kolongono ya bato mokolo ya 30 sanza ya liboso 2020, mpe ebengami pandemi mokolo ya 11 sanza ya misato 2020.
As of 10 April 2020, approximately 1.61 million cases of COVID-19 have been reported in 210 countries and territories, resulting in approximately 97,000 deaths.
Na sanza ya minei mokolo ya 10 2020, bato 1.61milio bazalaki na COVID-19 ezalaka na bamboka mpe bisika 210, oyo ememaki kufa 97,000.
About 364,000 people have recovered.
Bato 364,000 bakiki.
The case fatality rate has been estimated to be 4% in China, while globally ranging from 13.04% in Algeria to .08% in New Zealand.
Kufa ezali na 4% na Chine, na mokili ezali na 13.04% na Algerie mpe .08% na Nouvelle Zealand.
Common symptoms include fever, cough and shortness of breath.
Basymptomi ezali, fefele, kosukosu na mpema ya mokuse.
Complications may include pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
Bacomplication ezali pneumonia, mpasi na kopema.
The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days, but may range from two to fourteen days.
Soki malady ekoteli nzoto lelo, ekozwa mikolo mitano to zomi na mibale mpona basymptom ebanda.
There is no known vaccine or specific antiviral treatment.
Vaccin to kisi na yango eyebani te.

Primary treatment is symptomatic and supportive therapy.Recommended preventive measures include hand washing, covering one's mouth when coughing, maintaining distance from other people, and monitoring and self-isolation for people who suspect they are infected.

Liboso bako salisa basymptom mpe kosunga yo obika. Mpona kosukisa maladi esengeli yo osokola maboko, kanga zolo to monoko soki ozali kokosola, fanda mosika na bato, mpe kososola na komona ba oyo bazali na konfinema mpo ete bazalaki esika moko na moto oyo azwaki maladi yando.
Authorities worldwide have responded by implementing travel restrictions, quarantines, curfews, workplace hazard controls, and facility closures.
Mikonzi na mokili mobimba batie mibeko mpona kokanga ba nzela, konfinema, ngonga ya kokota mpe kobima ndako, biloko ya kobatela nzoto na bisika ya mosala, mpe kokanga bisika.

The pandemic has led to severe global socioeconomic disruption, the postponement or cancellation of sporting, religious, political and cultural events, and widespread shortages of supplies exacerbated by panic buying.

Pandemi emonisi nkita ya mokili mpasi, kopusa to kokata masano, ba eklesia, makambo ya politik na ya kosepela, mpe ndenge biloko ezali lisusu mingi te na mokili mpo ete bato bazalaki kosomba mingi na bomo.
Schools and universities have closed either on a nationwide or local basis in 193 countries, affecting approximately 99.4 percent of the world's student population.
Bakelasi na ba universite bakangi na mokili mobimba to na ba egumba na ba mboka 193, etungisi bana ya kelasi 99.4 pourcent ya population.

Misinformation about the virus has spread online, and there have been incidents of xenophobia and discrimination against Chinese people, other people of East and Southeast Asian descent and appearance, and others from areas with significant virus cases.

Kozanga koyeba maloba ya solo na virisi etandani na internet, mpe xenophobie emonani mingi na koyina ya bachinois, mpe bato ya Est na Sud ya Est ya Asie mpe ba oyo ya pene, mpe ba oyo na bisika oyo virisi ezali.
Due to reduced travel and closures of heavy industry, there has been a decrease in air pollution and carbon emissions.
Nsima ya kokanga ba nzela, carbone na mopepe ekiti.
Health authorities in Wuhan, China (the capital of Hubei province) reported a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown cause on 31 December 2019, and an investigation was launched in early January 2020.

Bakonzi na Wuhan, Chine (egumba ya monene ya Hubei) bamonaki kobela mingi ya pneumonia mokolo ya 31 sanza ya zomi na mibale 2019, mpe etid ebandaki mpona kososola yango ebandeli ya sanza ya liboso 2020.
The cases mostly had links to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market and so the virus is thought to have a zoonotic origin.
Ba oyo babelaki bautaki nzando ya banyama ya Huanan mpe elobami ete virisi euti kuna mpe ezali zoonotic.

The virus that caused the outbreak is known as SARS-CoV-2, a newly discovered virus closely related to bat coronaviruses, pangolin coronaviruses, and SARS-CoV.The earliest known person with symptoms was later discovered to have fallen ill on 1 December 2019, and that person did not have visible connections with the later wet market cluster.

Virisi oyo ememi maladi ebengami SARS-CoV-2, virisi ya sika oyo euti na coronavirisi ya bangembo, coronavirisi ya bapagolin na SARS-CoV. Moto ya liboso oyo azalaki na basymptomi abelaki mokolo ya 1 sanza ya zomi na mibale na 2019, mpe moto wana bayebaki te soki ye awutaki nzando wana.
Of the early cluster of cases reported in December 2019, two-thirds were found to have a link with the market.
Na ba oyo babelaki na 2019, mingi ya ndambo na bango eyabanaki ete bautaki zando.

On 13 March 2020, an unverified report from the South China Morning Post suggested that a case traced back to 17 November 2019, in a 55-year-old from Hubei province, may have been the first.On 26 February 2020, the WHO reported that, as new cases reportedly declined in China but suddenly increased in Italy, Iran, and South Korea, the number of new cases outside China had exceeded the number of new cases within China for the first time.

Na mokolo ya 13 sanza ya misato 2020, rapor euti Sud ya Chine na Morning Post elobaki ete kobela ebandaki na mokolo ya 17 sanza ya zomi na moko 2019, na moto ya miaka 55 na Hubei. Na mokolo ya 26 sanza ya mibale 2020, OMS elobaki bato ya kobela ekitaki na Chine kasi ebandaki komata na Italy, na Iran mpe na Core ya Sud, bato ya kobela balekaki oyo ya Chine.
There may be substantial underreporting of cases, particularly among those with milder symptoms.
Ekoki koloba ete toyebi te bato boni bazali na kobela kati na ba oyo bazali na basymptomi mukie.

By 26 February, relatively few cases had been reported among youths, with those 19 and under making up 2.4% of cases worldwide.The United Kingdom's chief scientific adviser, Patrick Vallance, estimated that 60% of the British population would need to become infected before effective herd immunity could be achieved.

Na mokolo ya 26 sanza ya mibale, bato ya kobela mukie bazalaki bajeune, ba oyo ya miaka 19 ekiti bazalaki 2.4% na mikili. Mokonzi ya etid ya science na Angleterre, Patrick Vallance, amonaki ete 60% ya population na Bretagne esengeli bazwa maladi mpo ete nzoto ya bato ebanda kolenda yango.
Cases refers to the number of people who have been tested for COVID-19, and whose test has been confirmed positive according to official protocols.
Bacas ezali boni ya bato bazali na COVID-19, ba oyo baekzame elobi ete bazali na yango, elobi mibeko.

As of 23 March, no country had tested more than 3% of its population, and many countries have had official policies not to test those with only mild symptoms, such as Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, and Switzerland.

Na mokolo ya 23 na sanza ya misato, mboka moto te esalaki baekzame koleka 3% ya population na bango, mpe bamboka mingi batiaki mibeko ya kosala ekzame te na bato oyo bazali na basymptomi mukie, lokola Italy, Netherland, Espagne na Switzerland.

A study published on 16 March found that in China, up to 23 January, an estimated 86% of COVID-19 infections had not been detected, and that these undocumented infections were the infection source for 79% of documented cases.

Etid moko oyo babimisaki mokolo ya 16 sanza y amisato na Chine ti mokolo ya 23 sanza ya libobo, emoni ete 86% ya ba oyo bazalaki kobela na COVID-19 bayebanaki te, mpe bango moto bapanzaki malady na 79% ya ba oyo bayebani.
A statistical analysis published 30 March estimated that numbers of infections in Italy were considerably greater than the reported cases.
Ba limero moko oyo babimisaki na mokolo ya 30 sanza ya misato emonaki ete bamaladi na Italie bazalaki ebele koleka oyo balobaki.
The initial estimates of the basic reproduction number (R0) for COVID-19 were 1.4 to 2.4.
Kopalangana ya (R0) COVID-19 ezali 1.4 to 2.4.
A study published by the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that it may be 5.7.
Etid moko oyo babimisaki na esika ya kolandela Maladi mpe kopekisa yango na US elobi ete ekoki kozala 5.7.
Most people with COVID-19 recover.
Bato mingi oyo bazali kobela COVID-19 bazali kobika.
For those who do not, the time from development of symptoms to death has been between 6 and 41 days, with the most common being 14 days.
Mpona ba oyo bazali kobika te, ngonga ya basymptomi mpe na ya liwa ezali mikolo 6 ti 41, na oyo ya mingi mikolo 14.
As of 10 April 2020, approximately 97,000 deaths had been attributed to COVID-19.
Na mokolo ya 10 sanza ya minei 2020, bato 97,000 bakufi na COVID-19.

In China, as of 5 February about 80% of deaths were in those over 60, and 75% had pre-existing health conditions including cardiovascular diseases and diabetes.Official tallies of deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic generally refer to dead people who tested positive for COVID according to official protocols.

Na Chine, na mokolo ya 5 sanza ya mibale 80% y aba oyo bakufaki bazalaki na miaka 60 to mingi, mpe 75% bazalaki na bamaladi misusu lokola malady ya motema na diabetes. Ba oyo bakufi na COVID-19 ezali ba oyo ekzame elakisaki ete bazali na COVID ndenge mibeko elobi.
The number of true fatalities from COVID-19 may be much higher, as it may not include people who die without testing - e.g. at home, in nursing homes, etc.
Limero ya solo ya bato oyo bakufi na COVID-19 ekoki kozala mingi koleka, kasi emoni te bato oyo basali ekzame te – lokola, na ndako, na ndako ya bakoko, mpe mingi.
Partial data from Italy found that the number of excess deaths during the pandemic exceeded the official COVID death tally by a factor of 4-5x.
Etid ya ndambo oyo euti Italie emoni ete bato oyo bakufi na COVID eleki 4-5x oyo bango basosolaki.

A spokeswoman for the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) acknowledged "We know that [the stated death toll] is an underestimation", a statement corroborated by anecdotal reports of undercounting in the U.S. Such underestimation often occurs in pandemics, such as the 2009 H1N1 swine flu epidemic.The first confirmed death was in Wuhan on 9 January 2020.

Moto ya U.S ya Esika ya Kolandela Maladi mpe kopekisa yango (CDC) emoni ete ‘’To yebi ete (balimero ya kufa ya mboka) ezali ya solo te mpo ezali mukie’’, elobami bayekoli ya barapor ya U.S. Balimero ya mukie boye esalemaka mingi na bapandemi, lokola na pandemi ya 2009 na H1N1 kosukosu ya bangulu. Kufa ya libosso na Wuhan ezalaki na mokolo ya 9 sanza ya liboso na 2020.
The first death outside mainland China occurred on 1 February in the Philippines, and the first death outside Asia was in France on 14 February.
Kufa ya libosso na Chine ezalaki mokolo ya 1 sanza ya mibale na Philippines, mpe kufa libanda ya Asie ezalaki na France mokolo ya 14 sanza ya mibale.
By 28 February, outside mainland China, more than a dozen deaths each were recorded in Iran, South Korea, and Italy.
Na mokolo ya 28 sanza ya mibale, libanda ya Chinne, bato mingi na zomi na mibale bakufaki na Iran, Core ya Sud mpe na Italie.
By 13 March, more than forty countries and territories had reported deaths, on every continent except Antarctica.Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.
Na mokolo ya 13 sanza ya misato, bamboka ntuku minei bazalaki na bato oyo bakufaki na maladi, na ba mboka nyonso kasi na Antartik te. Misala mingi ezali kosalema mpona koyebani bato boni bakufi.

These numbers vary by region and over time, and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak, and population characteristics such as age, sex, and overall health.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.
