Mibeko bakonzi bazwaki ya kokanga biteyelo mpe kopekisa bato basangana esalaki ete taux ya bato oyo bazwaki grippe ekita na 29% ti 37%.
Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
Bokangi ya biteyelo noki-noki na États-Unis, esalaki ete maladi mabe ya grippe H1N1 2009 emata mpenza te.

Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.

Atako kokanga biteyelo esalisi mingi, bolukiluki moko na oyo etali kokanga biteyelo na Michigan emonaki ete “kokanga biteyelo na etuka na bango esalaki eloko te. Na ntango ya grippe ya bangulu ya 2009 ebimaki na Royaume-Uni, nkoma moko babengi "Kokanga biteyelo na ntango ya maladi mabe ya grippe” oyo babimisaki na Lancet Infectious Diseases, lisanga moko ya ba epidemiologiste balobaki kokanga biteyelo eza malamu mpo na kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te, mpe kozwa ntango ya kosala bolukiluki mpe kobimisa mangwele.

Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.

Nsima ya koyekola maladi mabe ya gripe ata mpe grippe ya 1918, grippe ya 1957 mpe ya 1968, balobaki mpasi oyo kokanga biteyelo ememaki na nkita mpe na mosala, mingimingi mpo minganga na ba infirmer mingi baza basi, mpe katikati na bana na bango bakokisi nanu te 16.
They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.

Batalaki mpe makasi ya bopalangani ya grippe na France ntango bana ya kelasi ya France bazalaki na congé mpe balobaki ete grippe ekitaki ntango bakangaki biteyelo mpe ekomaki lisusu makasi ntango bafungolaki yango.

They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.

Balobaki ete ntango balakisi na Israele basalaki greve na ntango ya grippe ya 1999-2000, bavisite epai ya minganga mpe motango ya bato ya maladi ya mpema ekitaki na ndambo moko na kati ya mitano mpe ndambo mibale na kati ya mitano.

For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.

Mpo na biteyelo mpe bisika babatelaka bana, Ba centre oyo ebundisaka maladi mpe ebatelaka bato na maladi wana elobaki bakanga yango na ntango mokuse mpo na kotya bopeto to kolongola mbindo soki moto moko azalaki na lopango ya eteyelo ata soki epanzani ndenge nini na mboka.

When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.

Soki bokono ezopanzana mingi mpenza te na kati ya bato, bokoki kosalela mayele ya kopekisa bato bakutana na ndakisa kopekisa mibembo, mayangani, mpe makita mosusu ya minene na ndakisa education physique to korale na biteyelo to kolya na restaurant, ata mpe distance ezokabola babiro, kozelazela na ntango ya koya to ya kokende, koboya bavisite ezangi ntina, mpe kosalela babiro ya minganga ekeseni mpo na bana oyo bazali na bilembo ya grippe.
When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
Soki bokaboli ya bokono ezali makasi na esika bofandi, longola mayele ya kosenga bato bazala mosika na basusu, bokoki kokanisa kokanga biteyelo.
On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.
Na mokolo ya 26 sanza ya yambo, Chine atyaki mibeko mpo na kobundisa maladi COVID-19 ata mpe kobongola date ya fete ya Printemps mpo na kokanga yango nzela epanzana te.
Universities and schools around the country closed.
Bakangaki ba iniversite na biteyelo ya mboka wana.
On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.
Na mokolo ya 23 sanza ya mibale, ministere ya santé ya Iran elobaki bakangi ba iniversite, biteyelo ya likolo na biteyelo na bingumba mpe bituka.
On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.
Na mokolo ya 3 sanza ya misato, UNESCO abimisi motango ya liboso ya biteyelo oyo bakangaki na mokili mobimba mpe bana kelasi oyo kelasi ekatanaki.
It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.

Balobaki ete mikili 13 babimisaki mibeko ya kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te na ndakisa kokanga biteyelo mpe ba iniversite mpo na ntango moke, yango epesaki mpasi na bana kelasi bamilio 290,5 na mokili mobimba.
In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.
Yango wana, UNESCO esengaki mikili basalisa bana kelasi oyo bazwi mpasi mpe mabota na bango mpe basalisa bango na kozwa mateya na nzela ya baprograme ya boyekoli ya mosika.
On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.
Na mokolo ya 4 sanza ya misato, guvernema ya Italie epesaki mobeka bakanga biteyelo mpe ba iniversite nyonso na Italie mpo bato 100 basi bakufaki.
In doing so, Italy became one of 22 countries on three continents which had announced or implemented school closures.
Na kosalaka bongo, Italie ekomaki moko ya mikili 22 oyo elobaki ete bakanga biteyelo to bakokanga yango.
On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.

Na mokolo ya 5 sanza ya misato, bayekoli mingi oyo bazwaki mokakatano mpo na mibeko ya lombangu bazwaki mpo na COVID-19 bazalaki na Chine, bayekoli bamilio 233 bazwaki mokakatano wana, na nsima na Japon motango na bango ezalaki bamilio 16,5 mpe Iran bamilio 14,5.
By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.
Na mokolo ya 10 sanza ya misato, mwana kelasi moko na kati ya mitano na mokili mobimba “ezalaki kokende kelasi te mpo na COVID-19" ebongo moko na kati ya minei bazalaki kokende biteyelo ya minene te.
On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.

Na mokolo ya 13 sanza ya misato, baguvernema ya mikili 49 balobaki to bakangaki biteyelo, kati na yango mikili 39 oyo ekangaki biteyelo na mboka mobimba mpe mikili 22 oyo ekangaki biteyelo oyo bango moko baponaki.
By 16 March, this figure increased from 49 to 73 countries according to UNESCO.
Na mokolo ya 16 sanza ya misato, UNESCO alobaki ete motango wana elongwaki na 49 mpe ekomaki mikili 73.

By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.

Na mokolo ya 19 sanza ya misato, bana ya kelasi 50% na mokili mobimba bazwaki mokakatano mpo na bokangi biteyelo, emonisi ete na mikili 102 bakangaki biteyelo ya mboka mobimba mpe mikili 11 bakangaki biteyelo ndambu; bana mpe bilenge bamilio 850 bazwaki mokakatano mpo na yango.
By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.
Na mokolo ya 20 sanza ya misato, bayekoli koleka 70% na mokili mobimba bazwaki mokakatano mpo na bokangi wana; mikili 124 bakangaki biteyelo nyonso ya mboka na bango.

On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.
Na mokolo ya 23 sanza ya misato, guvernema ya Nigeria ekangaki biteyelo nyonso, bazando mpe bakompani mpe baboti bapekisaki bana na bango na kobima libanda ya bandako.
On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.
Na mokolo ya 26 sanza ya misato, biteyelo mpe ba iniverisite nyonso ya Nouvelle Zélande ekangamaki na mboka mobimba.
The government has imposed a two-week holiday, allowing schools to transition to forms of distant teaching as soon as possible.
Guvernema epesaki bango congé ya bamposo mibale; epesaki biteyelo nzela ya kobanda kosalela lolenge ya koteya na mosika soki likoki ezali.
Universities have closed for one week, but resumed with online teaching afterwards.
Bakangaki ba iniversite nyonso mpo na mposo moko, kasi ezongaka na nsima na koyekola na nzela ya internet.
Other school services remain open, but teaching is restricted to distant learning.
Misala mosusu ya biteyelo ekobaki, kasi koteya esukaki kaka na nzela ya internet.
By 27 March, nearly 90 percent of the world's student population was out of class.
Na mokolo ya 27 sanza ya misato, pene ya 90 pourcent ya bayekoli na mokili mobimba bazalaki kokende lisusu kelasi te.
Regions with schools remaining open included Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, and some U.S. states.
Bituka oyo biteyelo ekangamaki te ezalaki Taïwan, Singapour, Australie, Swede, mpe bituka mosusu ya États-Unis.
By 29 March, more than 1.5 billion children and other students were affected by nationwide school closures.
Na mokolo ya 29 sanza ya misato, bana mpe bayekoli mosusu pene ya 1,5 miliard bazwaki mokakatano na mokili mobimba mpo bakangaki biteyelo.
Others were disrupted by localized closures.
Basusu bazwaki mokakatano mpo na bakangaki biteyelo moke.
Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.
Kino na mokolo ya 6 sanza ya misato, biteyelo nyonso ya secondaire ya Turkmenistan ezalaki na congé.
An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.
Ministre ya santé abimisaki mobeko moko mpo na kokanga maladi ya mpema epanzana te na kolanda etinda ya OMS mpo na coronavirisi.

10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates 473,933,356 learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.

Mikili 10 ekangaki biteyelo oyo baponaki, UNESCO elobi ete bayekoli 473 933 356 bakoki kozala na likama (maternelle kino na secondaire) mpe bayekoli 77 938 904 baza na likama eza baoyo ya nivo ya tertiaire.

Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.

Likebisi: Mitango ekokani na motango ya bayekoli bakomisaki na maternelle, primaire, secondaire ya nse, mpe secondaire ya likolo [banivo SCED 0 kino na 3], mpe eteyelo ya tertiaire [banivo SCED 5 kino na 8] oyo bakoki kozala na mokakatano soki bakangaki biteyelo na mokili mobimba.
Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.
Motango ya bayekoli bamikomisa na kotalela bansango ya sika ya institut de statstique UNESCO.
School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.
Kokanga biteyelo mpo na maladi mabe ya COVID-19 esalisi na koyeba makambo mingi oyo ekangaka bato nzela bayekola, mpe komonisa polele makambo ya mpasi ya mbongo.

As of March 12, more than 370 million children and youth are not attending school because of temporary or indefinite country wide school closures mandated by governments in an attempt to slow the spread of COVID-19.

Na mokolo ya 12 sanza ya misato, bana mpe bilenge koleka bamilio 370 bazalaki kokende te kelasi mpo bakangaki biteyelo mpo na ntango moke to mpo na ntango eyebani te na mokili na bango na kolanda mobeko baguvernema bazwaki mpo na kokanga COVID-19 nzela epanzana te.
As of 29 March, nearly 90% of the world's learners were impacted by closures.Even when school closures are temporary, it carries high social and economic costs.

Na mokolo ya 29 sanza ya misato, pene ya bayekoli 90% na mokili mobimba bazalaki na mokakatano mpo na bokangi wana. Ata ntango bakangi yango mpo na ntango mokuse, ezalaki mpasi mingi na makambo ya bomoi mpe ya nkita.

The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.

Bampasi na yango ekomelaka bato ya mikili mingi, kasi ezalaka mpasi mingi mpo na bana ya babola mpe mabota na bango mpo yango ekataka boyekoli, bana bazangaka bilei, bazangaka babateli mpe esengaka mabota oyo ezosala te babimisa mbongo.
Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.
Baboti oyo basalaka bazangaki mpenza mosala soki biteyelo ekangami mpo esengaka babatela bana na bango, yango esalaka bazanga basalere mpe mosala esalemaka malamu te.
Localised school closures place burdens on schools as parents and officials redirect children to schools that are open.
Kokanga biteyelo oyo baponi etyaka kilo mingi na mapeka ya baboti mpe bakonzi mpe bakomisa bana na biteyelo oyo ekangami te.
Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.
Mbala mingi basi bazalaka motango monene ya bato oyo babatelaka bana mpe mbala mingi bakoki te kokende mosala mpo basengeli kobatela bana oyo biteyelo ekangami.
This means that many medical professionals are not at the facilities where they are most needed during a health crisis.
Elimboli ete minganga mingi baza te na bisika na bango ya mosala esika oyo baza mpenza na mposo na bango mpo na maladi oyo.
Lack of access to technology or fast, reliable internet access can prevent students in rural areas and from disadvantaged families.
Kozanga technologie to internet ya malamu ekoki kokanga bayekoli ya bamboka nzela mpe kozala mpasi mpo na mabota ya bobola.
Lack of access to technology or good internet connectivity is an obstacle to continued learning, especially for students from disadvantaged families.
Kozanga technologie to internet ya malamu eza likama mpo na kokoba koyekola, mingimingi mpo na bayekoli oyo baza na mabota ya bobola.

In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.

Mpo na kokanga biteyelo na ntina ya COVID-19, UNESCO alobi basalela baprograme ya koyekola na mosika mpe bafungola ba-application mpe bisika oyo biteyelo na balakisi bakoki kosalela mpo koteya na mosika mpe kosala ete bato mingi te bakata koyekola. Mpo na kosalisa mpo COVID-19 epanzana mingi, bakangi babiblioteke mosusu mpo na ntango moke.
In the United States, numerous major cities announced public library closures, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York City, affecting 221 libraries.
Na États-Unis, bingumba mingi ya minene elobaki bakangi babiblioteke na ndakisa Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, mpe New York City; bakangi babiblioteke 221.
For students without internet at home, this increases the difficulty of keeping up with distance learning.
Mpo na bayekoli bazangi internet na ndako, yango ezomatisa mokakatano ya kolanda koyekola na mosika.
School closures puts a strain on parents and guardians to provide childcare and manage distance learning while children are out of school.
Kokanga biteyelo etya kilo mingi na baboti mpe babateli mpo babatela bana mpe kokoba koyekola na mosika ntango bana bazokende kelasi te.

In the absence of alternative options, working parents often leave children alone when schools close and this can lead to risky behaviours, including increased influence of peer pressure and substance abuse.

Soki makoki mosusu eza te, mbala mingi baboti oyo basalaka batikaka bana bango moko ntango biteyelo ekangaka mpe yango ekoki kosala ete bana bakoma na bizaleli mabe, ata mpe baninga mabe mpe kosalela bilangwiseli.
Many children worldwide rely on free or discounted meals at schools.
Bana mingi na mokili mobimba balyaka biloko ya ofele oyo bapesaka na biteyelo.

When schools close, nutrition is compromised.Nutrition plays a critical role in cognitive development and academic performance for children.In Washington State, around 45% of the states 1.1 million students enrolled in traditional public and charter schools qualify for subsidised school meals.

Soki biteyelo ekangami, bana wana balyaka na mpasi. Kolya ezalaka ntina mingi na bokoli ya bana mpe mayele na bango na kelasi. Na etuka ya Washington, pene ya bato 45%, elingi koloba bayekoli 1,1 milio bamikotisa na bakelasi ya traditionnel mpe biteyelo mosusu mpo na kozwa mwa bilei.

At least 520,000 students and their families may be affected by food insecurity as a result of school closures.School lunch programmes are the second-biggest anti-hunger initiative in the United States after food stamps.

Pene ya bayekoli 520 000 na mabota na bango bakoki kokoma na mokakatano y bilei mpo biteyelo ekangami. Baprograme ya kolya ya midi ya biteyelo eza mwango ya monene ya mibale na États-Unis oyo esalisaka na kobundisa nzala.

Every year, nearly 30 million children rely on schools to provide free or low-cost meals including breakfast, lunch, snacks, and even dinner.In Alabama, where state-wide school closures as of 18 March have affected over 720,000 students, the state Superintendent announced that staff in schools disproportionately affected by poverty would create meal distribution networks to provide food for students who rely on school lunches.

Mbula nyonso, pene ya bamilio 30 ya bana balyaka mingimingi bilei ya ofele to ya ntalo moke oyo biteyelo epesaki mpo na ntongo, midi, mboka mpe butu. Na Alabama, esika kokanga biteyelo na etuka mobimba na mokolo ya 18 sanza ya misato epesi mokakatano na bayekoli koleka 720 000, mokengeli ya etuka alobaki ete bana oyo basalaka na biteyelo oyo baza na mokakatano makasi mpo na bobola bakosala bibongiseli mpo na kopesa bilei na bayekoli oyo bilei ya midi eutaka na biteyelo.
School closures negatively impact student learning outcomes.
Kokangama ya biteyelo eza na bopusi mabe na résultat ya bana kelasi oyo yango ememeli mokakatano.
Schooling provides essential learning and when schools close, children and youth are deprived opportunities for growth and development.
Biteyelo epesaka mateya ya ntina mpe soki ekangami, bana na bilenge bazangaka mabaku ya kokola malamu.

The disadvantages are disproportionate for under-privileged learners who tend to have fewer educational opportunities beyond school.Student drop-out rates tend to increase as an effect of school closures due to the challenge of ensuring all students return to school once school closures ends.

Makama eza mingi mpo na bayekoli oyo baza na mpasi, oyo bazalaka na mabaku mingi te ya kotanga nsima ya eteyelo. Kokangama ya biteyelo esalaka ete motango ya bana balingi kelasi ekita mpo na bampasi ya kosalisa bana nyonso bazonga na kelasi soki efungwami lisusu.
This is especially true of protracted closures.Schools are hubs of social activity and human interaction.
Eza soli mingimingi mpo na bokangi ya ntango molai. Biteyelo eza bisika ya makambo ya bomoi mpe ya bokutani na bato mosusu.

When schools are closed, many children and youth miss out of on social contact that is essential to learning and development.When schools close parents are often asked to facilitate the learning of children at home and can struggle to perform this task.

Soki biteyelo ekangami, bana mpe bilenge mingi bazangaka libaku ya kokutana na bato mosusu oyo eza ntina mpo na mayele na bango ya koyekola mpe bokoli na bango. Soki biteyelo ekangami mbala mingi basengaki baboti basalisa na koteya bana na ndako kasi ezalaka mpasi mpo basala yango.
This is especially true for parents with limited education and resources.
Eza solo mingimingi mpo na baboti oyo batanga mingi te mpe baza na bozwi mingi te.
Potential impacts of school closures and reliance on distance learning are not addressed in federal acts of legislation at this time.
Bampasi ya kokangama ya biteyelo mpe ya koyekola na mosika, mibeko ya leta elobeli yango te kino sikoyo.
Formal education — as opposed to informal education or non-formal education — tends to refer to schools, colleges, universities and training institutions.
Boyekoli ya formel — soki tokesenisi yango na boyekoli ya informel to oyo eza formel te — mbala mingi ezali biteyelo, ba collège, ba iniversite mpe bisika bateyaka bato.

A 1974 report by the World Bank defined formal education as the following:Formal education: the hierarchically structured, chronologically graded ‘education system’, running from primary school through the university and including, in addition to general academic studies, a variety of specialised programmes and institutions for full-time technical and professional training.The majority of data collected on the number of students and learners impacted by COVID-19 has been calculated based on the closure of formal education systems.

Na 1974 rapore ya Work Bank elobaki ete boyekoli formel ezali: Boyekoli formel: esika ebongisami malamu, bakelasi oyo ‘bamataka,’ banda na primaire kino na iniversite mpe, longola boyekoli ya ba academie, eza na baprograme mingi ya ntina oyo epesaka mateya ya technique mpe ya professionnel. Bansango ya bana kelasi mpe ya bayekoli mingi oyo tozwi, baoyo bakutani na mokakatano mpo na COVID-19, to calculer yango na kotala bokangami ya biteyelo ya formel.

The UNESCO Institute for Statistics provides figures on students impacted by COVID-19 corresponding to the number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8].

Institut de stastique UNESCO epesi motango ya bayekoli oyo bakutani na mokakatano mpo na COVID-19 na kolanda motango ya bayekoli oyo bakomisa bankombo na maternelle, primaire, secondaire ya nse, mpe secondaire ya likolo [banivo SCED 0 kino na 3], mpe eteyelo ya tertiaire [banivo SCED 5 kino na 8].
Early childhood educational programmes are usually designed for children below the age of 3 and may refer to preschools, nursery schools, kindergartens, and some day care programmes.
Biteyelo ya ebandeli mpo na bana, basala yango mingi mpo na bana oyo bakokisi nanu te mibu 3 te mpe bakoki kobenga yango maternelle, gardienne mpe baprograme mosusu ya kobatela bana.
While many primary and secondary schools have closed around the world due to COVID-19, measures impacting early childhood educational programmes have varied.
Ata biteyelo mingi ya primaire mpe ya secondaire ekangami na mokili mobimba mpo na COVID-19, mibeko oyo etye bipekiseli na baprograme ya bana mike ekeseni.

In some countries and territories, preschools and day cares are considered necessary services and have not closed in tandem with broader school closure measures.In the United States, the Washington State Department of Children, Youth, and Families encouraged child care and early learning centres to stay open.

Na mikili mpe bisika mosusu, biteyelo ya maternelle mpe ya kobatela bana bamonaka yango misala ya ntina mpe bakangi yango te mpo na mibeko ya kokanga bakelasi oyo bazwi. Na États-Unis, ministere ya bana, bilenge mpe mabota ya etuka ya Washington, elobaki ete bakanga te bisika ya kobatela bana mpe bacentre ya koyekola.
Some school districts may offer alternative child care options, prioritising the children of first responders and healthcare workers.
Biteyelo mosusu ya etuka ekoki kopesa makanisi mosusu mpo na libateli ya bana, kotya na esika ya liboso bana ya minganga mpe ba infirmier.

The governor of Maryland mandated that specific child care services remain open for the children of emergency personnel while Washington State and California have left it to the discretion of care providers.

Guverneur ya Maryland alobaki ete misala ya kobatela bana esengeli kokoba mpo na bana ya bato oyo bazosalisa, kasi etuka ya Washington mpe ya Californie, minganga na ba infirmier bazwa ekateli bango moko.
California Governor Gavin Newsom explained his state's position, saying “We need our child care facilities, our daycare centers, to operate to absorb the impact of these school closures.”

Guverneur ya Californie Gavin Newsom alimbolaki ekateli na ye, alobaki “Toza na mposa ya bisika na biso ya kobatela bana, ba centre ya kobatela bana, esala mpo bopusi ya kokanga biteyelo eza mingi te.”

Colorado has encouraged the development of "tool kits" for parents to use at home to emulate the lessons children would have received in their early learning programmes.In Japan, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe closed all schools throughout the country until April 8, however, children's daycare facilities were excluded.

Colorado elendisaki kosala “bisaleli” mpo baboti baselela yango na ndako mpo na komekola mateya oyo balingaki kozwa na baprograme ya koyekola na maternelle. Na Japon, premier ministre Shinzo Abe akangaki biteyelo nyonso na mboka mobimba kino na mokolo ya 8 sanza ya minei, kasi akangaki te bisika babatelaka bana.
In early March, five adults associated with a nursing facility for preschool children in Kobe tested positive for coronavirus.
Na ebandeli ya sanza ya misato, mikolo mitano oyo basalaka na bisika oyo babatelaka bana ya maternelle na Kobe, bakangaki bango maladi ya coronavirisi.
After testing over one hundred children at the facility, a preschool student was found to be carrying the virus.
Nsima ya kosalisa bana nkama moko ya esika wana ekzame, bazwaki mwana moko ya maternelle maladi wana.
Primary or elementary education typically consists of the first four to seven years of formal education.
Biteyelo ya primaire to ya elementaire ezali kelasi ya liboso kino ya minei na bakelasi nsambo ya biteyelo ya formel.

The International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) canceled the examinations for its Diploma Programme and Career-related Programme candidates scheduled between 30 April and 22 May 2020, reportedly affecting more than 200,000 students worldwide.

International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) elobaki bakosala te ba-ekzame mpo na programe na yango ya kozwa maplome mpe ya kosalisa na kozwa misala oyo esengelaki kosalema kati na mokolo ya 30 sanza ya minei kino na mokolo ya 22 sanza ya mitano 2020, epesi mokakatano na bayekoli kolela 200 000 na mokili mobimba.

The IBO stated that it would award candidates their diplomas or certificates based on "their coursework" and "the established assessment expertise, rigor, and quality control already built into the programme."
IBO alobaki ete ekopesa bakandida maplome na bango to ba certificat na kotalela “banoti na bango ya kelasi” mpe “botaleli ya mayele, makasi, qualité oyo bazalaki na yango deja na programe.”
Tertiary education, also known as higher education, refers to the non-compulsory educational levels that follow completion of secondary school or high school.
Biteyelo ya tertiaire, oyo eyebani neti biteyelo ya likolo, eza biteyelo ya obligatoire te oyo basalaka nsima ya kosilisa eteyelo ya secondaire to ya likolo.
Tertiary education is normally taken to include undergraduate and postgraduate education, as well as vocational education and training.
Biteyelo ya tertiaire etalelaka mpe cycle ya liboso mpe cycle ya misato, ata mpe mateya mpe formation professionnel.
Individuals who complete tertiary education generally receive certificates, diplomas, or academic degrees.
Mbala mingi bato oyo basilisi eteyelo ya tertiaire bazwaka certificat, diplome to degree académique.
Undergraduate education is education conducted after secondary education and prior to post-graduate education, for which the learner is typically awarded a bachelor's degree.
Eteyelo ya cycle ya liboso eza mateya oyo bazwaka nsima ya eteyelo ya secondiare mpe ya liboso ya cycle ya misato, mpo na bayekoli bapesaka bango diplome ya licence.

Students enrolled in higher education programmes at colleges, universities, and community colleges are often refereed to in countries such as United States as "college students."The closure of colleges and universities has widespread implications for students, faculty, administrators, and the institutions themselves.

Bana ya kelasi oyo bakomisami na baprograme ya biteyelo ya likolo ya ba collège, iniversite, mpe ba collège mosusu, babengaka bango mbala mingi na mikili neti États-Unis “bayekoli ya collège.” Bokangami ya ba collège mpe ba iniversite eza na bopusi makasi mpo na bayekoli, faculté, bakonzi, mpe bibongiseli yango moko.
Colleges and universities across the United States have been called upon to issue refunds to students for the cost of tuition and room and board.
Ba collège mpe ba iniversite na États-Unis bazolobela likambo ya kosenga mosolo na bana kelasi mpo na mbongo ya kelasi, bandako mpe bateyi.
In the United States of America, Colleges and universities operate as "mini-cities" which generate significant revenue for cities, states, and regions.
Na États-Unis ya Amerika, ba collège na ba iniversite esalaka neti “bingumba ya mike” oyo ememelaka bingumba, bituka mpe bamboka mbongo mingi.
For example, Princeton University contributed $1.58 billion USD to the New Jersey economy and students spent about $60 million in off-campus spending.
Na ndakisa, iniversite Princeton epesaka mbongo 1,58 miliard ya badolare na etuka ya New Jersey mpe bana ya kelasi bafutaka mbongo pene ya bamilio 60$ mpo na kelasi na bango.

College and university closures have a domino effect on economies with far-reaching implications.According to Linda Bilmes of the Harvard Kennedy School, "local hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, car rental agencies and other local businesses obtain a significant share of annual revenue from graduation week and college reunions...

Kokanga ba collège mpe ba iniversite eza mpe na bopusi na nkita ya mboka. Na kotalela eteyelo Linda Bilmes of the Harvard Kennedy, "ba hotel, ba restaurant, malewa, baboutique, ba agence oyo edefisaka mituka mpe mimbongo mosusu ezwaka mbongo mingi na mposo ya kopesa maplome ya makita ya ba collège...

these communities will suffer a lot of economic damage if the colleges remain closed at that time."Small towns which rely on college students to support the local economy and provide labour to local businesses are especially impacted by school closures and the exodus of students from campus.

nkita ya bisika oyo ekonyokwamaka makasi soki ba collège efungwami te na ntango wana. "Bingumba ya mike oyo bazalaka na mposa ya lisalisi ya bana kelasi ya ba collège mpo na nkita na yango mpe kopesa mosala na bato ya mombongo ya mboka ndenge bana mingi ya kelasi bazolongwa na ba campus.
In Ithaca, New York, Cornell University students spent at least $4 million a week in Tompkins county.
Na Ithaca, na New York, bana ya kelasi ya iniversite ya Cornell babimisaka mbongo pene ya milio 4$ na mposo moko na Tompkins.

In the wake of Cornell's decision to keep students home following spring break and transition to virtual instruction, the Mayor of Ithaca called for "immediate and forceful federal action — we will see a horrific economic impact as a result of Cornell University closing."

Nsima ya ekateli ya Cornell ya kotika bana kelasi na ndako nsima ya kopema ya printemps mpe babanda koyekola na internet, maire ya Ithaca asengaki "bazwa ekateli ya noki mpe ya makasi mpo na etuka — tokozala na mpasi monene ya mbongo ndenge Cornell akangi iniversite."
UNESCO is sharing 10 recommendations during this period:
UNESCO epesi batoli 10 na eleko oyo:

Examine the readiness and choose the most relevant tools: Decide on the use high-technology and low-technology solutions based on the reliability of local power supplies, internet connectivity, and digital skills of teachers and students.

Botalela komibongisa mpe bopona bisaleli ya malamu koleka: Pona kosala technologie ya makasi mpe ba technologie ya mosolo mingi te esimbami na bokasi ya courant ya mboka, connection ya internet, mpe mayele ya kosalela internet ya balakisi mpe ya bana kelasi.
This could range through integrated digital learning platforms, video lessons, MOOCs, to broadcasting through radios and TVs.
Ekoki kozala na kati ya bibongiseli ya koyekola na intenet, mateya na bavideo, MOOCs, to kolekisa baprograme na baradio to ba TV.

Ensure inclusion of the distance learning programmes: Implement measures to ensure that students including those with disabilities or from low-income backgrounds have access to distance learning programmes, if only a limited number of them have access to digital devices.

Kokitisa baprograme ya koyekola na mosika: Kosalela mayele mpo na kosalisa bana ya kelasi ata mpe bibosono to baoyo bauti na mabota ya bobola mpo bazwa likoki ya kokola na baprograme ya koyekola na internet, soki moke mpamba na kati na bango baza na ba appareil digital.
Consider temporarily decentralising such devices from computer labs to families and support them with internet connectivity.
Kotalela mayele ya ntango moko ya kolongola ba-application wana na ba-ordinatere komema yango na maboko mpe kosalisa bango na likambo ya internet.
Protect data privacy and data security: Assess data security when uploading data or educational resources to web spaces, as well as when sharing them with other organisations or individuals.
Kobatela bansango ya sekele mpe libateli ya bansango: Kotalela libateli ya bansango to mateya na internet, mpe ntango ozopesa yango na bibongiseli to mpe na bato.
Ensure that the use of applications and platforms does not violate students’ data privacy.
Bosala nyonso mpo kosalela ba-application mpe bisika mosusu ebuka te mobeko ya kobatela bansango ya bana kelasi.
Prioritize solutions to address psychosocial challenges before teaching: Mobilize available tools to connect schools, parents, teachers, and students with each other.
Kotya likebi mingi mpo na kobongisa makambo ya physchosocial liboso ya mateya: Basangisa bisaleli boza na yango mpo na kosangisa biteyelo, baboti, balakisi, mpe bana kelasi bango na bango.
Create communities to ensure regular human interactions, enable social caring measures, and address possible psychosocial challenges that students may face when they are isolated.
Bosala bituluku mpo na kosalisa bato na kozala na boyokani mbala na mbala, kosalisa na kosalisana, mpe kosilisa mikakatano ya psychosocial oyo bana kelasi bakoki kozala na yango soki baza bango moko.

Plan the study schedule of the distance learning programmes: Organise discussions with stakeholders to examine the possible duration of school closures and decide whether the distance learning programme should focus on teaching new knowledge or enhance students’ knowledge of prior lessons.

Bobongisa baprograme ya manaka ya koyekola na mosika: Bongisa masolo elongo na basangani mpo na kotalela eleko ya bokangami mpe bozwa ekateli soki baprograme ya koyekola na mosika esengeli kolobela mingi technologie ya sika to kokolisa mayele ya bana na mateya ya kala.
Plan the schedule depending on the situation of the affected zones, level of studies, needs of students needs, and availability of parents.
Bongisa manaka na kotalela bisika oyo maladi eza mingi, nivo ya boyekoli ya bana, mposa ya bana mpe mposa ya baboti.
Choose the appropriate learning methodologies based on the status of school closures and home-based quarantines.
Bopona bametode ebongi ya koteya oyo esimbami na ndenge bakangaki eteyelo mpe quarantaine na ndako.
Avoid learning methodologies that require face-to-face communication.
Bosalela te bametode ya koteya oyo esengaki kosolola miso na miso.
Provide support to teachers and parents on the use of digital tools: Organise brief training or orientation sessions for teachers and parents as well, if monitoring and facilitation are needed.
Bosalisa balakisi na baboti na kosalela ba-apareyi electronique: Bobongisa formation ya mokuse to oyo ezolakisa balakisi na baboti ndenge ya kosalela yango, soki baza na mposa ya lisalisi.
Help teachers to prepare the basic settings such as solutions to the use of internet data if they are required to provide live streaming of lessons.
Bosalisa balakisi na kobongisa bisika ebongi na ndakisa ndenge ya kosalela bansango na internet soki basengli kopesa mateya na nzela ya live streaming.

Blend appropriate approaches and limit the number of applications and platforms: Blend tools or media that are available for most students, both for synchronous communication and lessons, and for asynchronous learning.
Bosangisa bametode ebongi mpe bosalela te ba-application mingi mpenza: Bosangisa bisaleli mpe media oyo bana kelasi mingi baza na yango, mpo na masolo ya elongo to mateya, mpe masolo ya elongo te.
Avoid overloading students and parents by asking them to download and test too many applications or platforms.
Balembissa te bana ya kelasi na baboti na kosengaka bango bazwa mpe bameka ba-application mingi koleka.
Develop distance learning rules and monitor students’ learning process: Define the rules with parents and students on distance learning.
Batya mibeko ezolobela koyekola na mosika mpe botala ndenge bana kelasi bazokola: Bolimbolela baboti na bana mibeko etali koyekola na mosika.
Design formative questions, tests, or exercises to monitor closely students’ learning process.
Bobongisa mituna, ba-ekzame, mpe bangalasisi ebongi mpo na kolandela bokoli ya bana kelasi.
Try to use tools to support submission of students’ feedback and avoid overloading parents by requesting them to scan and send students’ feedback
Bomeka kosalela bisaleli mpo na kosalisa bana kelasi bapesa bakomantere mpe bopesa te baboti mosala mingi na kosengaka bango ba scanner bakomantere ya bana mpe batinda yango

Define the duration of distance learning units based on students’ self-regulation skills: Keep a coherent timing according to the level of the students’ self-regulation and metacognitive abilities especially for livestreaming classes.

Bopona ngonga oyo mateya ekozwa na kotalela mayele ya koyekola ya bana kelasi: Bozala na ngonga ebongi na kotalela makoki ya bana ya kokanga makambo mpe ya koyekola mingimingi na bakelasi ya live streaming.
Preferably, the unit for primary school students should not be more than 20 minutes, and no longer than 40 minutes for secondary school students.
Ekozala malamu, liteya mokomoko ya bana kelasi ya primaire elekisa te minita 20, mpe ya bana kelasi ya secondaire elekisa te miniti 40.

Create communities and enhance connection: Create communities of teachers, parents, and school managers to address sense of loneliness or helplessness, facilitate sharing of experience and discussion on coping strategies when facing learning difficulties.

Bosala bituluku mpe bosalisa bango na kosolola: Bosala bituluku ya balakisi, baboti, mpe bakambi ya eteyelo mpo na kobundisa mayoki ya kozala yo moko to ya kozanga elikya, bosalisa bango na kobeta masolo mpe kolobela mayele ya kolonga mikakatano ya koyekola soki bakutani na yango.
290 million students out of school due to COVID-19: UNESCO releases first global numbers and mobilizes response, UNESCO.
Bana kelasi bamilio 290 bazokende kelasi te mpo na COVID-19: UNESCO ebimisaki motango ya liboso mpe esengaki tokanga maboko te, UNESCO.
Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19
Biloko ya komibatela na makama na mosala COVID-19
Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19 are the application of occupational safety and health methodologies for hazard controls to the prevention of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
Biloko ya komibatela na mosala mpo na COVID-19 eza kosalela mayele etali libateli mpe kolongono ya nzoto mpo na kokanga nzela ete maladi ya coronavirisi 2019 (COVID-19) epanzana te.

The proper hazard controls in the workplace depend on the worksite and job task, based on a risk assessment of sources of exposure, disease severity in the community, and risk factors of individual workers who may be vulnerable to contracting COVID-19.

Lolenge ya malamu ya komibatela na mosala etaleli esika mosala esalemaka mpe mosala yango, etaleli makama ya komitika na makambo ya makama, ndenge maladi ekoti esika bofandi, mpe makama oyo bato ya mosala bakoki kozala na risque ya kozwa maladi ya COVID-19.

According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers, for which basic infection prevention measures are recommended, including hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.

Na kotalela ministre ya libateli mpe santé ya États-Unis (OSHA), mosala eza na makama moke eza mosala oyo esengaka kokutana na bato mosusu mpe baninga ya mosala mingi te, oyo esengaka kosalela mayele ya ntina ya libateli, na ndakisa kosokola maboko, kolendisa bato ya mosala na kotikala na ndako soki bazobela, babelaka maladi ya mpema, mpe kozala na ezaleli ya kotya bopeto mpe ya kopetola esika ya mosala.

Medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact with people who are not known or suspected with COVID-19, but may be infected due to ongoing community transmission or international travel.

Mosala ya likama ya katikati eza misala oyo esengaka kokutana mbala mingi to na pembeni na bato oyo oyebi to baoyo bakoki kozala na COVID-19, kasi bakoki kozala na maladi mpo bakutanaka na bato mingi to basalaka mibembo na mikili mingi.
This includes workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.
Yango etali bato ya mosala oyo bakutanaka na bato mingi na ndakisa na biteyelo, na bisika ya mosala oyo bato bazalaka mingi, mpe na bisika mosusu oyo bato bazalaka mingi.

Hazard controls for this group, in addition to basic infection prevention measures, include ventilation using high-efficiency air filters, sneeze guards, and having personal protective equipment available in case a person with COVID-19 is encountered.

Komibatela na makama na etuluku oyo, longola makambo bato nyonso basalaka mpo na komibatela na maladi, esengeli kosalela ventillateur oyo eza na bafiltre ya makasi mpenza, komibatela liboso ya kosala itche, mpe kozala na bisaleli ya komibatela soki okutani na moto oyo aza na maladi ya COVID-19.

OSHA considers healthcare and mortuary workers exposed to known or suspected person with COVID-19 to be at high exposure risk, which increases to very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected person with COVID-19.

OSHA etalelaka minganga mpe bato basalaka na morgue ete baza bato oyo bayebani to likoki ezali bakutana na moto aza na COVID-19 baza na likama ya monene, mpe esalaka ete bato oyo basalaka misala ya aerosol to basimbaka to bazwaka ba échantillon, ya bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to baoyo bakoki kozala na yango.
Hazard controls appropriate for these workers include engineering controls such as negative pressure ventilation rooms, and personal protective equipment appropriate to the job task.

Komibatela malamu na makama mpo na bato yo basalaka misala oyo ekoki kozala komibatela na bandako oyo eza na mopepe ya mabe ya ventillateur, mpe kozala na bilamba ya malamu ya libateli mpo na mosala wana.
COVID-19 outbreaks can have several effects within the workplace.
Kobima ya COVID-19 ekoki kozala na makama mingi na esika ya mosala.
Workers may be absent from work due to becoming sick, needing to care for others, or from fear of possible exposure.
Bato ya mosala bakoki kozala te na mosala mpo bazobela, bazobatela bato mosusu, to bazobanga mbala mosusu bakokutana na moko aza na maladi wana.
Patterns of commerce may change, both in terms of what goods are demanded, and the means of acquiring these goods (such as shopping at off-peak hours or through delivery or drive-through services).

Lolenge ya kosala mombongo ekoki kobongwana, ekoki kozala na biloko bato bazoluka kosomba, mpe ndenge ya kozwa biloko yango (na ndakisa kosomba na ntango bato baza mingi to na nzela ya misala ya livraison à domicile).
Lastly, shipments of items from geographic areas severely affected by COVID-19 may be interrupted.An infectious disease preparedness and response plan can be used to guide protective actions.
Ya nsuka, bakoki kopekisa kokende kotika biloko na bisika oyo maladi ya COVID-19 eza mingi. Komibongisa na maladi ekoki kosalisa na koyeba nini tokosala mpo na komibatela.

Plans address the levels of risk associated with various worksites and job tasks, including sources of exposure, risk factors arising from home and community settings, and risk factors of individual workers such as old age or chronic medical conditions.

Baplan ezolobela nivo ya likama oyo eza na bisika ya mosala mpe misala, ata mpe bato oyo okokutana na bango, makambo ezosala makama ekoma mingi na ndako mpe bisika mosusu, mpe makama oyo bato ya mosala na ndakisa mibange to bato oyo baza na maladi esilaka te baza na yango.
They also outline controls necessary to address those risks, and contingency plans for situations that may arise as a result of outbreaks.
Ezolobela mpe ndenge ya kolandela mpo na kobongisa makama wana, mpe lolenge ya kobongisa makambo oyo ekoki kobima mpo na maladi oyo.
Infectious disease preparedness and response plans may be subject to national or subnational recommendations.
Komibongisa na maladi mabe mpe makambo ya kosala mpo na kobundisa yango ekosalema na kolanda mibeko ya ekolo to ya mboka.

Objectives for response to an outbreak include reducing transmission among staff, protecting people who are at higher risk for adverse health complications, maintaining business operations, and minimizing adverse effects on other entities in their supply chains.

Lolenge malamu ya kobundisa yango etali makambo mpo na maladi oyo etali na ndakisa kokitisa ndenge ekoki kopanzana kati ya bato ya mosala, kobatela bato oyo baza na likama monene mpo baza na maladi ya kala, kokoba kosala mosala, mpe kosala makambo mpo ebebisa te mosala ya bakompani mosusu oyo basalaka elongo na bino.
The disease severity in the community where the business is located affects the responses taken.
Makambo bokosala ekotalela ndenge oyo maladi yango ekoti na bongo na bino.
The hierarchy of hazard controls is a framework widely used in occupational safety and health to group hazard controls by effectiveness.
Koyeba ndenge moto na moto akosala makambo mpo na komibatela na makama eza mwango endimami mpo na kobatela bato ya mosala mpe kolongono ya nzoto ya bato mingi na kotalela bokasi na yango.
Where COVID-19 hazards cannot be eliminated, the most effective controls are engineering controls, followed by administrative controls, and lastly personal protective equipment.

Bisika bakoki kolongola te makama ya COVID-19, lolenge ya malamu koleka ya kobundisa yango eza kotalelaka ba mashine, nsima kotalela ya bakonzi, mpe na nsuka kopesa moto na moko bisaleli ebongi mpo na komibatela.
Engineering controls involve isolating employees from work-related hazards without relying on worker behavior, and can be the most cost-effective solution to implement.
Kotalela ba mashine elakisi kotya bato ya mosala mosika na makama ya mosala kozanga kobebisa bizaleli malamu ya mosala, mpe ekoki kozala lolenge ya malamu ya kosala makambo.
Administrative controls are changes in work policy or procedures that require action by the worker or employer.
Botaleli ya bakonzi ezali kobongola lolenge ya kosala mosala oyo ezosenga patron to moto ya mosala abongola ndenge na ye ya kosala.
Personal protective equipment (PPE) is considered less effective than engineering and administrative controls, but can help prevent some exposures.
Bisaleli ya komibatela (PPE) eza makasi mingi te soki tokokanisi yango na botaleli ya ba mashine to ya bakonzi, kasi ekoki kosalisa na kokima makama mosusu.

All types of PPE must be selected based upon the hazard to the worker, properly fitted as applicable (e.g., respirators), consistently and properly worn, regularly inspected, maintained, and replaced, as necessary, and properly removed, cleaned, and stored or disposed of to avoid contamination.

Bosengeli kopona lolenge nyonso ya PPE na kotalela makama oyo eza mpo na moto ya mosala, soki ebongi mpenza (na ndakisa biloko esalisaka na kopema), kolata yango malamu mpe ntango nyonso, kobatela yango, mpe kotya ya sika, soki esengami, mpe kolongola yango malamu, kosokola yango, kobongisa to kobwaka yango mpo emema maladi te.
According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers.
Na kotalela ministere ya libateli mpe kolongono ya nzoto (OSHA), makama ya moke na mosala eza oyo esengaka kokutana na bato mingi te mpe baninga ya mosala mingi te.

Basic infection prevention measures recommended for all workplaces include frequent and thorough hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette including covering coughs and sneezes, providing tissues and trash receptacles, preparing for telecommuting or staggered shifts if needed, discouraging workers from using others' tools and equipment, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.

Lolenge ya malamu ya komibatela mpo maladi epanzana te na mosala oyo endimami eza kosokola maboko mbala na mbala, kolendisa bato ya mosala na kotikala na ndako soki bazobela, soki babelaka maladi ya mpema, kozipa monoko to zolo soki bakosoli to basali itche, kozala bilamba ya kopangusa mpe esika ya kobwaka yango, kobongisa bisaleli ya kosolola na mosika to mosusu soki eza ntina kopekisa bato ya mosala basalela bisaleli ya bato mosusu, mpe kobatela bizaleli ya kotya bopeto mpe kopetola esika ya mosala.
Prompt identification and isolation of potentially infectious individuals is a critical step in protecting workers, customers, visitors, and others at a worksite.
Koyeba noki bato oyo bakoki kozala na maladi mpe kotya bango mosika na basusu eza lolenge ya malamu mingi ya kobatela bato ya mosala, basombi, bapaya, mpe bato mosusu na esika ya mosala.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness are to stay home until they are free of fever, signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines, and that sick leave policies are flexible, permit employees to stay home to care for a sick family member, and that employees are aware of these policies.

Ba centre ya kobundisa maladi mabe mpe kobatela bato na yango (CDC) ya États-Unis ezolendisa ete bato ya mosala oyo baza na bilembo ya maladi ya makasi ya mpema batikala na ndako kino fievre, bilembo ya fievre, mpe bilembo mosusu ekosila ata na bangonga 24 kozanga kosala nkisi ya kokitisa fievre to nkisi mosusu mpo na bilembo mosusu, mpe batya mibeko malamu mpo na congé ya malamu, kopesa bato ya mosala nzela ya kotikala na ndako mpo na kobatela bato ya libota oyo bazobela, mpe ete bato ya mosala basengeli koyeba mibeko wana.

According to OSHA, medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact within six feet (1.8 m) of people who are not known or suspected COVID-19 patients, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 due to ongoing community transmission around the business location, or because the individual has recent international travel to a location with widespread COVID-19 transmission.

Na kotalela OSHA, likama ya katikati na mosala etali makambo neti bato oyo bakutanaka na bato mingi to bazalaka pene ya bametre 1,8 ya bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to oyo bazokanisa bakoki kozala na yango, kasi bakoki kozwa SARS-CoV-2 mpo maladi yango ezopanza mingi na esika bofandi na esika ya mosala, to mpo bato basalaki mobembo kala te na mikili mosusu esika COVID-19 ezopanzana mingi.

These include workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.Engineering controls for this and higher risk groups include installing high-efficiency air filters, increasing ventilation rates, installing physical barriers such as clear plastic sneeze guards, and installing a drive-through window for customer service.Administrative controls for this and higher risk groups include encouraging sick workers to stay at home, replacing face-to-face meetings with virtual communications, establishing staggered shifts, discontinuing nonessential travel to locations with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks, developing emergency communications plans including a forum for answering workers’ concerns, providing workers with up-to-date education and training on COVID-19 risk factors and protective behaviors, training workers who need to use protecting clothing and equipment how to use it, providing resources and a work environment that promotes personal hygiene, requiring regular hand washing, limiting customers' and the public's access to the worksite, and posting signage about hand washing and other COVID-19 protective measures.Depending on the work task, workers with at least medium exposure risk may need to wear personal protective equipment including some combination of gloves, a gown, a face shield or face mask, or goggles.

Etali bato ya mosala oyo bakutanaka na bato ya ndenge na ndenge na ndakisa na biteyelo, na esika ya mosala oyo bato bazalaka mingi mpenza, mpe na bisika mosusu ya bato mingi. Kobatela ya ba mashine mpo na bato ya boye esengaka kotya bafiltre ya makasi ya mopepe, kosala ete ba ventilateur ebaluka makasi, kotya biloko ekabolaka bato neti biloko oyo elekisaka te mopepe ya itche, mpe kotya madesu na fenetre mpo na baoyo bazoyamba bakiliya. Libateli ya bakonzi mpo na bituluku ya likama mingi ezosenga kolendisa bato ya mosala oyo bazobela batikala na ndako, kosala makita na internet na esika ya kozala na esika moko, kotya mibeko mpo na kolongola mibembo ezangi ntina na bisika oyo COVID-19 ezali, kosala mayele ya kosolola ata mpe ba forume mpo na kolandela mikakatano ya bato ya mosala, kopesa bato ya mosala bansango ya sika mpe formation ebongi mpo na makama ya COVID-19 mpe makambo ya kosala mpo na komibatela, kopesa formation na bato ya mosala oyo basengeli kosalela bilamba ya komibatela mpe koyebisa bango ndenge ya kosalela yango, kopesa bango bisaleli mpe basala na esika oyo eza peto, ezosenga kosokola maboko mbala na mbala, kosala ete bakiliya na bato mosusu bakotaka mingi te na esika ya mosala, mpe kotya bilembo ya kosokola maboko mpe bibongiseli mosusu ya komibatela na COVID-19. Na kotalela mosala bazosala, bato ya mosala oyo baza na likama ya katikati basengeli kolata bilamba na bango ya komibatela na ndakisa bagan, blouse, masque ya elongi, to maneti ya komibatela.
Workers in this risk group rarely require use of respirators.
Bato ya mosala oyo baza na etuluku oyo, esengaka mpenza te basalela biloko esalisaka na kopema.

If a person becomes sick on an airplane, proper controls to protect workers and other passengers include separating the sick person from others by a distance of 6 feet, designating one crew member to serve the sick person, and offering a face mask to the sick person or asking the sick person to cover their mouth and nose with tissues when coughing or sneezing.

Soki moto moko abeli na avion, lolenge ya malamu ya kobatela bato ya mosala mpe bato mosusu ezali kokabola ye na bato mosusu na distance ya 6 pied, kopona moto moko ya equipage mpo akipe moto wana ya maladi, mpe kopesa masque ya elongi to kosenga moto wana ya maladi azipa monoko na zolo na ye na elamba ntango azokosola to azosala itche.

Cabin crew should wear disposable medical gloves when tending to a sick traveler or touching body fluids or potentially contaminated surfaces, and possibly additional personal protective equipment if the sick traveler has fever, persistent cough, or difficulty breathing.

Bato ya mosala oyo baza na cabine basengeli kolata bagan ntango bazosalisa moto azosala mobembo oyo azobela to kosimba mai ya nzoto to esika nyonso oyo ekoki kopesa bango maladi, mpe komibatela mingi lisusu soki moto yango ya maladi azobela fievre, kosukosu oyo ezosila te, to azopema na mpasi.

Gloves and other disposable items should be disposed of in a biohazard bag, and contaminated surfaces should be cleaned and disinfected afterwards.For commercial shipping, including cruise ships and other passenger vessels, hazard controls include postponing travel when sick, and self-isolating and informing the onboard medical center immediately if one develops a fever or other symptoms while on board.

Bagan mpe biloko mosusu oyo babwaka nsima ya kosalela esengeli kobwakama na esika ebongi, mpe bosengeli kopetola mpe kolongola mikrobe na bisika oyo ezwi mikrobe. Mpo na maswa ya mombongo, ata mpe bato de croisière mpe bato mosusu oyo baza nakati, komibatela elimboli koboya kosala mobembo soki ozobela, mpe komifandela mpe koyebisa minganga oyo baza nakati mbala moko soki moto moko oyo aza na kati aza na fievre to bilembo ya maladi mosusu.

Ideally, medical follow-up should occur in the isolated person's cabin.For schools and childcare facilities, CDC recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.

Eza malamu kolandela santé ya moto wana ya maladi na esika oyo batye ye. Mpo na biteyelo to bisika ya kobatela bana, CDC ezosenga kokanga esika wana na ntango moke mpo na kopetola to kolongola mikrobe soki moto moko ya maladi azalaki na lopango ya eteyelo ezala maladi epanzani mingi to te esika bofandi.

When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as canceling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.

Soki bokono ezopanza mingi mpenza te na kati ya bato, bokoki kosalela mayele ya kopekisa bato bakutana na ndakisa kopekisa mibembo, mayangani, mpe makita mosusu ya minene na ndakisa education physique to korale na biteyelo to kolya na restaurant, ata mpe distance ezokabola babiro, kozelazela na ntango ya koya to ya kokende, koboya bavisite ezangi ntina, mpe kosalela babiro ya minganga ekeseni mpo na bana oyo bazali na bilembo ya grippe.

When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.For law enforcement personnel performing daily routine activities, the immediate health risk is considered low by CDC.

Soki maladi epanzani mingi esika bofandi, longola mayele ya koyebisa bato bamifandela, bokoki kokanga biteyelo mpo na ntango ya mwa molai. Mpo na bapolisi oyo bazosala mosala na bango bo momeseno, CDC elobi ete likama na bango eza na nivo ya se.

Law enforcement officials who must make contact with individuals confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 are recommended to follow the same guidelines as emergency medical technicians, including proper personal protective equipment.

Bakonzi ya bapolisi oyo basengeli kokutana na bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to oyo bakoki kozala na yango, esengeli batosa mibeko ya ndenge moko na oyo minganga batosaka, ata mpe kolata bisaleli malamu mpo na komibatela.

If close contact occurs during apprehension, workers should clean and disinfect their duty belt and gear prior to reuse using a household cleaning spray or wipe, and follow standard operating procedures for the containment and disposal of used PPE and for containing and laundering clothes.

Soki bosimba moto ntango bozokanga ye, bato wana basengeli kopetola mpe kolongola mikrobe na nkamba na bango ya mosala mpe na bisaleli na bango liboso ya kosalela yango, bakosala yango na lisalisi ya aspirateur mpe kolanda mibeko etali komibatela mpe kobwaka biloko oyo PPE epesi mpe ya kobatela mpe kosokola bilamba.
OSHA considers certain healthcare and mortuary workers to be at high or very high categories of exposure risk.
OSHA etalelaka bato mosusu oyo basalaka mosala ya monganga mpe oyo basalaka na morgue ete baza na likama makasi to baza na kati ya bato oyo baza na likama makasi.
High exposure risk jobs include healthcare delivery, support, laboratory, and medical transport workers who are exposed to known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
Misala ya likama makasi eza na ndakisa kobotisa, kosalisa, laboratoire, mpe bato oyo bamema bato ya maladi oyo baza na COVID-19 to bakoki kozala na yango.
These become very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
Bakomaka na likama makasi soki bazosala misala ya aerosol, to bazozwa to bazosalela ba échantillon euti na bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to bakoki kozala na yango.
Aerosol-generating procedures include intubation, cough induction procedures, bronchoscopies, some dental procedures and exams, or invasive specimen collection.
Misala ya aerosol eza misala neti intubation, kosalisa kosukosu, bronchoscopie, to misala to ba ekzame mosusu ya mino, to kozwa ba écahntillon.

High exposure risk mortuary jobs include workers involved in preparing the bodies of people who had known or suspected cases of COVID-19 at the time of their death; these become very high exposure risk if they perform an autopsy.Additional engineering controls for these risk groups include isolation rooms for patients with known or suspected COVID-19, including when aerosol-generating procedures are performed.

Likama makasi ya misala ya morgue etali bato oyo basalaka mosala ya kobongisa bibembe ya bato oyo bakufaki na COVID-19 na ntango bakufi to oyo bato oyo bakanisi ete bazalaki na yango; bazalaka na likama makasi soki basali ekzame na nsima mpo na koyeba soki bakufaki na maladi nini. Likama mosusu mpo na bango eza soki bazosalisa bato oyo baza na COVID-19 to oyo bakanisi baza na yango na bashambre na bango, ata mpe ntango bazosala misala ya aerosol.
Specialized negative pressure ventilation may be appropriate in some healthcare and mortuary settings.
Kotinda mwa mopepe ya ventilateur ekoki kozala malamu na balopitalo mosusu mpe na ba morgue.
Specimens should be handled with Biosafety Level 3 precautions.
Esengeli kosalela ba échantillon na kolanda nivo ya libateli ya bio 3.

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that incoming patients be separated into distinct waiting areas depending on whether they are a suspected COVID-19 case.In addition to other PPE, OSHA recommends respirators for those who work within 6 feet of patients known to be, or suspected of being, infected with SARS-CoV-2, and those performing aerosol-generating procedures.

Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) elobi ete eza malamu kokabola bato ya maladi na bisika ya kozela ekeseni na kotalela soki bozokanisa baza na maladi ya COVID-19 to te. Longola likanisi ya kosala biloko esalisaka na kopema oyo PPE, OSHA elobeli mpo na bato oyo bazosala na distance ya 6 pied na bato oyo bayebani baza na SARS-CoV-2, oyo bozokanisa baza na yango, to oyo bazwi yango, mpe kosala misala mosusu ya aerosol.

In the United States, NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirators or better must be used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams.

Na États-Unis, biloko esalisaka na kopema N95 oyo endimami na NIOSH to ya malamu koleka esengeli kosalelama mingi na makambo ya komibatela na maladi ya mpema na ndakisa test ya ajustement, formation, mpe ba-ekzame ya monganga.

Other types of respirators can provide greater protection and improve worker comfort.The WHO does not recommend coveralls, as COVID-19 is a respiratory disease rather than being transmitted through bodily fluids.

Lolenge mosusu ya biloko esalisaka na kopema ebatelaka mingi mpe esalisaka bato basala malamu. OMS endimaka te biloko ezipaka elongi mobimba, mpo COVID-19 eza maladi ya mpema mpe epanzanaka te na nzela ya mai ya nzoto.
WHO recommends only a surgical mask for point-of-entry screening personnel.
OMS ezosenga kaka kosalela masque ya minganga mpo bato oyo bazosalisa ba ekzame.

For those who are collecting respiratory specimens from, caring for, or transporting COVID-19 patients without any aerosol-generating procedures, WHO recommends a surgical mask, goggles, or face shield, gown, and gloves.

Mpo na bato oyo bazozwa ba échantilllon ya maladi ya mpema na bato ya maladi, kobatela bango, to komema bato oyo bazobela COVID-19 kozanga kosala misala ya aerosol, OMS ezondima kosalela masque ya minganga, maneti ya libateli, to eloko ya kobatela elongi, blouse, mpe bagan.
If an aerosol-generating procedure is performed, the surgical mask is replaced with an N95 or FFP2 respirator.
Soki bosali misala ya aerosol, na esika ya masque ya minganga, bokosalela eloko esalisaka na kopema N95 to FFP2.

Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.

Mpo biloko nyonso oyo PPE ezopesa ekoki te, OMS azondima kosalela mingi te PPE na telemedecine, bipekiseli mpo bato bakutana te na ndakisa bafenetre ya polele, kopesa nzela na minganga na kokota na shambre ya moto oyo azobela COVID-19, kosalela kaka PPE oyo eza ntina mpo na mosala ya sikisiki, kokoba kosalela eloko kaka moko esalisaka na kopema kozanga kolongola yango ntango azosalisa bato mingi oyo bazobela maladi moko, kobatela mpe kosalela malamu ba PPE mosusu, mpe kolendisa te kosalela bamasque mpo na bato oyo baza na bilembo te.
WHEREAS on March 4, 2020, I proclaimed a State of Emergency to exist in California as a result of the threat of COVID-19;
KASI na mokolo ya 4 sanza ya misato 2020, nalobaki ete urgence eza na etuka ya Californie mpo na maladi ya COVID-19;
and WHEREAS in a short period of time, COVID-19 has rapidly spread throughout California, necessitating updated and more stringent guidance from federal, state, and local public health officials;
mpe ATA na eleko ya ntango moke, COVID-19 epanzani mingi na Californie, mpe esengaki kobimisa mibeko ya sika mpe ya makasi mingi mpo na minganga ya ekolo, ya etuka, ya engumba mpe ya mboka;

and WHEREAS for the preservation of public health and safety throughout the entire State of California, I find it necessary for all Californians to heed the State public health directives from the Department of Public Health.

mpe ATA mpo na kobatela kolongono ya nzoto mpe libateli ya bato nyonso na etuka mobimba ya Californie, namoni eza ntina ete bato nyonso ya Californie batosa mibeko ya etali kolongono ya nzoto oyo euti na ministere ya santé.

NOW, THEREFORE, I, GAVIN NEWSOM, Governor of the State of California, in accordance with the authority vested in me by the State Constitution and statutes of the State of California, and in particular, Government Code sections 8567, 8627, and 8665 do hereby issue the following Order to become effective immediately:

SIKOYO, NGAI, GAVIN NEWSOM, guvernere ya etuka ya Californie, na boyokani na bokonzi epesameli ngai na mibeko ya leta mpe na mibeko ya etuka ya Californie, mpe mingmingi, biteni 8567, 8627, mpe 8665 ya mibeko ya boyangeli, nabimisi etinda oyo esengeli kosalela banda sikoyo:
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT:
NAZWI EKATALI OYO:

1) To preserve the public health and safety, and to ensure the healthcare delivery system is capable of serving all, and prioritizing those at the highest risk and vulnerability, all residents are directed to immediately heed the current State public health directives, which I ordered the Department of Public Health to develop for the current statewide status of COVID-19.

1) Kobatela kolongola ya nzoto ya bato mpe libateli na bango, mpe kosala nyonso mpo minganga bazala na makoki ya kosalisa bato nyonso, mpe kobanda libosoliboso na bato oyo baza na likama mingi mpe baza makasi te, mpe bato nyonso basengeli kotosa mibeko ya sika etali kolongono ya nzoto oyo leta abimisi, oyo nasengaki ministere ya santé ebimisa mpo na maladi ya COVID-19 na etuka mobimba.
Those directives are consistent with the March 19, 2020, Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response, found at: https://covid19.ca.gov/.

Mitinda oyo eyokani na mobeko epesamaki na mokolo ya 19 sanza ya misato 2020, oyo etaleli koyeba misala ya ntina mingi oyo esengeli kosala na ntango ya kobundisa COVID-19, ezali na: https://covid19.ca.gov/.
ORDER OF THE STATE PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER
ETINDA YA MOKONZI YA LETA ATALAKA MAKAMBO YA KOLONGONO YA NZOTO

To protect public health, I as State Public Health Officer and Director of the California Department of Public Health order all individuals living in the State of California to stay home or at their place of residence except as needed to maintain continuity of operations of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, as outlined at https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

Kobatela kolongono ya nzoto ya bato, Ngai, mokonzi ya kolongono ya nzoto mpe diretre ya ministere ya santé ya Californie nasengi bato nyonso oyo bafandi na etuka ya batikala na ndako to na bisika bafandaka longola kaka soki basengeli kosala mpo misala ya ntina mingi ya etuka ekoba kosalema, ndenge balimboli yango na https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

In addition, and in consultation with the Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services, I may designate additional sectors as critical in order to protect the health and well-being of all Californians.

Lisusu, na boyokani na diretere ya biro ya guvernere oyo azolandela makambo ya urgence, nakoki kopona misala mosusu ete eza ntina mpo na kobatela kolongono ya nzoto ya bato nyonso ya Californie mpe bolamu na bango.

Pursuant to the authority under the Health and Safety Code 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 and 120150, this order is to go into effect immediately and shall stay in effect until further notice.

Na kolandela mibeko ya kolongono ya nzoto mpe ya libateli 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 mpe 120150, etinda esengeli kobanda kosalelama kaka sikoyo mpe ekozala na ngala kino tokobela yango lisusu.

The federal government has identified 16 critical infrastructure sectors whose assets, systems, and networks, whether physical or virtual, are considered so vital to the United States that their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating effect on security, economic security, public health or safety, or any combination thereof.

Boyangeli ya leta eponi ba secteur 16 oyo biloko na yango, ba systeme na yango, mpe réseaux na yango, ezala ya physique to na internet, eza ntina mingi mpo na États-Unis ete soki batiki yango ekobebisa libateli, makambo ya nkita, kolongono ya nzoto to libateli, mpe mokomoko to mingi na yango.
I order that Californians working in these 16 critical infrastructure sectors may continue their work because of the importance of these sectors to Californians' health and well-being.

Napesi etindi ete bato ya Californie oyo basalaka na ba secteur 16 wana bakoki kokoba kosala mosala na bango mpo ba secteur wana eza ntina mingi mpo na kolongono ya nzoto mpe bolamu ya bato ya Californie.
This Order is being issued to protect the public health of Californians.
Nazobimisa etinda oyo mpo na kobatela kolongono ya nzoto ya bato ya Californie.
The California Department of Public Health looks to establish consistency across the state in order to ensure that we mitigate the impact of COVID-19.
Ministere ya santé ya Californie ezoluka kotya mibeko ya ndenge moko na etuka mobimba mpo tolembisa bopusi ya COVID-19.
Our goal is simple, we want to bend the curve, and disrupt the spread of the virus.
Mokano na biso eza ya pete, tozolinga kobongisa makambo, mpe kokanga virisi nzela epanzana te.
The supply chain must continue, and Californians must have access to such necessities as food, prescriptions, and health care.
Mpo misala ekoba kosalema, mpe bato ya Californie bazala na biloko oyo ya ntina na ndakisa bilei, bankisi, mpe bato bakokipe santé na bango.

When people need to leave their homes or places of residence, whether to obtain or perform the functions above, or to otherwise facilitate authorized necessary activities, they should at all times practice social distancing.

Soki bato basengeli kolongwa na bandako to na bisika bafandaka, ezala mpo na kosala to kozwa misala tolobeli likolo, to kosalisa na ndenge mosusu misala epesami nzela, basengeli ntango nyonso kotosa mibeko ya kozala mosika na basusu.

2) The healthcare delivery system shall prioritize services to serving those who are the sickest and shall prioritize resources, including personal protective equipment, for the providers providing direct care to them.
2) Balopitalo esengeli kotya likebi libosoliboso na bato oyo bazobela makasi mpe basengeli kotya likebi na bisaleli, na ndakisa bisaleli ya kobatela bato, mpo na bato oyo bazosalisa bango mpenza.
3) The Office of Emergency Services is directed to take necessary steps to ensure compliance with this Order.
3) Mokonzi ya misala ya urgence asengeli kosala makambo ebongi mpo na kotosisa Etinda oyo.
4) This Order shall be enforceable pursuant to California law, including, but not limited to, Government Code section 8665.
4) Etinda oyo, tosengeli kotosa yango na kolanda mibeko ya Californie, ata mpe, kasi esuki te, na eteni 8665 ya mobeko ya boyangeli.
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that as soon as hereafter possible, this Order be filed in the Office of the Secretary of State and that widespread publicity and notice be given of this Order.
NAPESI LISUSU ETINDA ete nokinoki nsima na yango, batya etinda oyo na dosie ya secretere ya leta mpe bapanza yango na bato nyonso mpe bayebisaka bango etinda oyo.

This Order is not intended to, and does not, create any rights or benefits, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity, against the State of California, its agencies, departments, entities, officers, employees, or any other person.

Mokano ya etinda oyo eza te, mpe esengeli te, kobimisa balotomo to matomba, mayele to metode mosusu, kotosisama yango, oyo eyokani te na etuka ya Californie, bibongiseli na yango, badepartema na yango, bakonzi na yango, bato na yango ya mosala, to moto nyonso mosusu.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF I have hereunto set my hand and caused the Great Seal of the State of California to be affixed this 19th day of March 2020.
NA LITATOLI OYO natye loboko mpe nandimi batya kashe ya etuka ya Californie na etinda oyo na mokolo ya 19 sanza ya misato 2020.
FROM: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
EUTI NA: Katherine Maher, CEO ya fondation Wikimedia
TO: All Wikimedia Foundation staff
NA: Basali nyonso ya fondation Wikimedia
SUBJECT LINE: [Covid-19] Lightening the load and preparing for the future
MOTO YA LIKAMBO: [Covid-19] Kongengisa nzela mpe komibongisa mpo na mikolo ezoya
SEND DATE/TIME: 14 March, 2020, 00:24 UTC
DATE/NTANGO ETINDAMI: Mokolo ya 14 sanza ya misato 2020, 00:24 UTC
LICENSING: CC0: No rights reserved
NDINGISA: CC0: Eza na lotomo moko te
We find ourselves in remarkable circumstances this month.
Na sanza oyo tokutani mpenza na makambo ya kokamwa.
The COVID-19 epidemic is something that makes clear our global human interconnectedness and the responsibilities we have to one another.
Maladi ya COVID-19 emonisa mpenza polele ete toza ya kosangana bamoko na basusu mpe toza na mikumba mpo na bato mosusu.

We don’t have precedent for its challenges, but we do know that our best response relies on the sort of global empathy, cooperation, and community building that sits at the heart of this organization.
Toyebi te bampasi oyo ekobimisa te, kasi toyebi ete milende na biso ya malamu ya kobundisa yango esimbami na makasi, boyokani, mpe bato ya mboka oyo baza ntina mingi na lisanga oyo.
The camaraderie and care we have seen among all of our colleagues over email, calls, and chats is a remarkable validation of the incredible humans we are fortunate enough to work with.
Boninga mpe bolingo oyo tomoni na kati ya baninga na biso nyonso na ba email, kobenga na telefone, mpe masolo ezondimisa mpenza ete tosalaka na bato ya malamu mpenza.
I couldn’t be more grateful and proud to count you all as colleagues.
Napesa bango bino baninga nyonso matondi mingi mpe nazanga na esengo ya kotyela bino motema.
Last week, someone shared with me their appreciation for our work.
Na mposo eleki, moto moko ayebisaka ngai ndenge basepelaka na mosala na biso.
They reminded me how meaningful it is for the world to be able to turn to Wikipedia right now, and what a powerful symbol it is for this critical resource to remain online and available to all.

Ekundwelaki ngai ndenge eza ntina mingi ete bato bakende na Wikipedia kaka sikoyo, mpe eza elembo makasi emonisi ete misala ya ntina esengeli kozala na internet mpe bato nyonso bazala na likoki ya komona yango.
Your work makes this possible, whether you keep the sites stay up or our colleagues paid or our communities safe.
Mosala na bino nde esalisaka mpo esalema bongo, ezala bozotya bansango ya sika na basite to kofuta baninga na biso to kobatela mboka na biso.
The world needs the information that Wikipedia provides, now more than ever.
Sikoyo mpenza, mokili eza na mposa ya bansango oyo Wikipedia epesaka.
This is a moment in which not only what we do, but how we do it, will make a meaningful impact on the world.
